DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (WORKS AND HOUSING) ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Beale had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill, the House condemns the Government for pursuing incompetent economic and tax policies which-
(a) have resulted in a continuing high level of interest rates, and
(b) have reduced the incentive for private investors to put funds into the private rental market by the imposition of the iniquitous capital gains tax and the removal of negative gearing provisions.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the adjournment, the House was discussing the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill, which seeks to give effect to certain arrangements agreed at the Loan Council meeting held on 13 June 1986 for the payment of certain moneys in interest-free capital grants to the States as part of their Loan Council programs for the current year and the prepayment of certain funds for next year, and the alteration of the amounts the States and the Northern Territory may nominate from their approved borrowing programs for public housing in 1986-87. To this the Opposition moved an amendment, the effect of which was to condemn the Government for pursuing incompetent economic and tax policies which have resulted in a continuing high level of interest rates and have reduced the incentive for private investors to put funds into the private rental market by the imposition of the iniquitous capital gains tax and the removal of negative gearing provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is moving this amendment because we believe that the Government's economic policies have failed. In an unbelievable swanning around the world, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is trying to tell other Western countries that the performance of the Australian economy has been better than the performance of the economies in those other countries. Yet in the past few years he has presided over the Australian economy, during which time we have suffered the greatest fall in the value of our currency in our history. Real interest rates are several times higher than those of our trading partners. We have a balance of payments crisis, with a deficit of about $1.25 billion a month. We have the highest level of Federal taxes in our peacetime history. We have an inflation rate several times that of our trading partners. Unemployment in Australia is trending up while unemployment in the economies of our trading partners is trending down, and we have a tax regime that has encumbered Australians with the most complex and discordant legislation on fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax. Referring to the fringe benefits tax the Daily Telegraph this morning reported having conducted a poll, the effect of which was to find that only 15 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. I am reluctant to take this point of order, but it is clear that the subject matter with which the member is now dealing has no possible relevance to this Bill.
—Have a look at the amendment.

—Further to the point of order; that was precisely the second point I was about to make. It is not appropriate for Opposition members to take advantage of the opportunity to move an amendment in such a way to legislation of this kind simply to provide themselves with a vehicle for departing from the essence of the legislation. Quite clearly, that is the tactic Opposition members have chosen to adopt, and it is not appropriate.
—Order! I appreciate the thought the honourable member for Charlton has given to this matter, but the amendment has been moved and the member concerned has the right to speak to it.

—This morning's Daily Telegraph is reported as having conducted a poll, which shows that only 15 per cent of respondents to the poll believe that the Government should continue with the fringe benefits tax. This contrasts sharply with the assertions by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday that the majority of Australians favour this tax. Without wishing to dwell on the fringe benefits tax, let me say, as has been said before, that the Opposition in government will repeal the fringe benefits tax lock, stock and barrel. Government economic policies have failed because, firstly, there have been no real cuts in spending and government functions. In fact, taxes increased in the last Budget. Taxes on milk increased, as did taxes on citrus products and on petrol; the Medicare levy also increased. Secondly, interest rates are still far too high to encourage the necessary investment for the private sector to recover. Thirdly, personal taxation levels are still far too high. Fourthly, government debt is still growing; it increased by a further $3.5 billion in the Budget. Fifthly, consumption is still growing faster than production. Sixthly, the Government's wages policy is in disarray.
—It is in tatters.

—Yes, it is in tatters. Accord mark 1 went out the window, now we have accord mark 2 and the newspapers are ablaze with stories of accord mark 3 and what that will mean. The Government has no idea where it is going on wages policy. Seventhly, our overseas debt continues to rise, putting further pressure on our productive sector and increasing inflationary pressures.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government must face the fact that it must be more export oriented. To encourage domestic investment it must reduce personal taxation, it must reward for effort and provide incentives to the citizens of Australia to go out and create wealth for us all. The Government must abolish its new punitive taxes-the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax-which have the effect of discouraging investment. It must reduce interest rates and in order to do that it must curtail further the growth of its expenditure. It must make its wages policy more flexible. It must provide a framework to bring our wages into line with those of our overseas competitors and it must curtail the use of restrictive work practices. It is worth noting that the Prime Minister is a very late convert to getting rid of restrictive work practices because it was he, in his time as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, who was responsible for introducing many of those practices. The Government must do something about demarcation disputes which sap our productive effort to no real effect. It must provide a framework to improve the quality and the price of our exports in order to resolve our damaging current account problem.

This Government has introduced policies which are having a dramatic effect on housing. The housing package is falling apart. On 2 April the Prime Minister promised that there would be 135,000 housing starts in the current year. In June the Indicative Planning Council, which is the Government's advisory body on housing, said that there would not be 135,000 starts as the Prime Minister had promised, there would only be 130,000. Last week the Indicative Planning Council, in its report to the Australian Housing Council, advised that housing starts this year would be between 120,000 and 125,000 and it chose the median level of 122,500.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another broken promise.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Denison says, another broken promise by this Government which is noted for its broken promises. It promised that there would be no capital gains tax, it promised that interest rates would come down and it promised 135,000 housing starts in the current year and we are now to have at least 12,500 fewer housing starts than the Prime Minister promised on 2 April. The Prime Minister also said when he was making that promise that for each 10,000 fewer starts there would be a loss of 15,000 jobs. Now that we are losing 12,500 starts that means that there will be about 20,000 fewer jobs in the housing industry than there would have been had the Government met its target of 135,000 starts. To put that in perspective, it means that the housing industry will have about $1 billion less activity in the current year than it would have had if the Government had met its promise. I wish to quote from `Housing Industry Prospects for 1986-87', the paper prepared for the Australian Housing Council by the Indicative Planning Council. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The recovery over the course of the year is weaker than forecast in the June Report . . . and, as a consequence, total commencements for 1986-87 are forecast to be lower at between 120,000 and 125,000.

It also says that the gross domestic product is forecast to grow by 2 1/4 per cent for the year and that the inflation rate in 1986-87 will be maintained largely by the flow-on effects of the depreciation of the Australian dollar. The assumptions on which the Indicative Planning Council is basing its forecast of 122,500 starts are suspect. There is not a responsible economic commentator who does not think the forecast of growth in the gross domestic product of 2 1/4 per cent is optimistic. It may very well be that we will see even fewer housing starts than the current forecast by the Indicative Planning Council of 122,500. The report goes on to say:
Prospects for interest rates remain uncertain.
It also states:
. . . the general level of interest rates is assumed to start to fall before the end of 1986.

Again there are no responsible economic commentators who think that interest rates will fall significantly before the end of this year. We are seeing that this Indicative Planning Council report is based on the best possible forecasts for our economy. If they are not met, housing starts will be down even further. The same report says:
The Council's overall assessment is that underlying requirements for housing are still growing and are above the current activity level.

The significance of this is that, if the demand for housing is above the availability of housing, people seeking housing will have to go to the private rental market; if there is pressure on the private rental market, as I will shortly show, they must go to public housing, which puts even greater strains on government expenditure.
Let me quote from a couple of newspaper articles of recent days about the private rental market which is a disaster area. The Weekend Australian of 4-5 October says:
While Mr Keating plays the graceless yokel in Washington, the Australian rental market has collapsed . . .
The article goes on to say:

Mr Keating ended the use of Section 51 of the Income Tax Act, which defrays all expenses, including interest, incurred in gaining assessable income. This means there are few new home units being built for investment. This is a tragedy.
The Australian Financial Review, on 2 October, says:

Residential rents in Sydney have soared by about 20 per cent this year, and another 10 per cent hike is tipped before the end of this year. The average rental for a three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment on the lower North Shore is around $250 a week.

The private rental market is collapsing, along with investor confidence. With the abolition of negative gearing, the introduction of the capital gains tax and other taxes and proposed punitive landlord and tenant laws from the Labor States, the rental market is in dire straits. The capital gains tax, which has contributed significantly to the decline in investor confidence in the private rental market and which has led to sharply increased rents, is now starting to produce its unintended consequences, as did the fringe benefits tax. The Opposition in government will repeal the capital gains tax legislation. Housing demand is higher than housing supply, and that is forcing people to move to the private rental market.

Let me quote, just as an example, what has happened in Perth between June 1985 and June 1986. There the median rent for three-bedroom houses has increased from $89 a week to $135.50 a week, which is a staggering increase in that one-year period of 52 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —In just one year.

—In just one year, as my colleague the honourable member for Denison says. The Government stands condemned. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has finally admitted that the private rental housing market is deteriorating and that further subsidies may be necessary for the savings banks to try to prop up lending. The housing package has been completely unravelled and a new policy direction on housing is demanded.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's economic policies have led to higher interest rates, and the increases in our internal debt and external debt are causing the rental market to disintegrate. If the Government does not do something about that and does not give a new direction on housing, there will be even greater strains on the Government to provide more money for public housing. I commend the amendment to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my honour to second the amendment. I reserve my right to speak in the debate on the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is certainly moving in a new direction on housing, and that is the direction of public housing. The purpose of the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill is to obtain Parliament's approval for the amendment of the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act 1985 for, first, the payment in 1986-87 of interest free capital grants to the States of $429,426,000 as part of the 1986-87 State governments' Loan Council programs; and, secondly, the payment in 1986-87 of amounts that States may nominate from their Loan Council programs as being for the purpose of public housing and payable under the concessional loan terms and conditions of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The object of providing concessional loans for public housing of amounts nominated for that purpose is to provide an incentive for the States and the Northern Territory to increase the amounts that they direct to public housing. In accordance with the new arrangements agreed at the 13 July 1986 Loan Council meeting, the Federal Government agreed that the States could nominate up to 60 per cent from their Loan Council borrowing program for public housing in 1986-87. South Australia and Western Australia, as in previous years, will be able to nominate up to 100 per cent of their Loan Council State borrowings. If used for public housing, these funds are provided to the States at the highly concessional interest rate of 4.5 per cent, repayable over 53 years. There is $584.7m available in these loans for use by the States for public housing for 1986-87 compared with $459.4m used in 1985-86. In announcing these measures the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) urged the States to support the announced measures by taking up their full allocation under the Loan Council program, thus directing increased State resources to public housing.

By increasing the allocation of funds to new public housing construction, the housing industry overall will be assisted, and it will ensure that employment in the industry is maintained at a satisfactory level. It will be this maintenance of jobs in the public sector that will provide a secure future for the industry rather than reliance on the uncertain climate in the private housing sector. The 1986-87 allocation represents an increase of $164.6m over the sum provided in 1985-86 under the CSHA and through the Loan Council borrowing program. When State matching and other funds are added, total funds available for public housing in 1986-87 should be about $2 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—A total of around $2 billion. This is a clear indication of the Government's real concern for those thousands of needy Australian households which are unable to find adequate, affordable housing in the private sector. These people are our people. They look to the Federal Labor Government for assistance, and we are determined to make their housing needs a top priority. The States themselves are now recognising that public housing should be made a top priority.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that the pressure on the public housing sector is growing because of other factors in the overall housing situation. Of course, there are other factors. We do not ignore them. More and more ordinary Australians unable to find accommodation within the shrinking private rental market and unable to realise their dream of home ownership are relying on the public housing sector to satisfy their housing needs. We in the Government are very well aware of that. That is why we are providing increased funding for public housing. On the other hand, the Liberals, the Opposition, consider that we do not pander sufficiently to the self-interest of those who want to make a profit out of the housing market. They focus on the removal of the private tax advantages that are available to those wishing to make a profit. I shall focus on other actors in the scene-namely, the banks.

At a time when there is less disposable income, because of wage restraint, and at a time of high interest rates and spiralling purchase prices of homes, especially in New South Wales, it is true that the prospects of realising the great Australian dream of home ownership are becoming more and more remote. The decision to partially deregulate housing interest rates earlier this year has meant more money for housing. Indeed, banks are now lending at record levels. But that does not mean housing for many Australian families. The 15 1/2 per cent interest rate is not affordable to many who cannot take the risk, under deregulation, of interest rates going through the roof in a short time. The banks gave the Government no guarantee that they would not increase the average cost of a new loan. I shall focus on some of their activities.

Let us consider the response of the banks. What have they done to help in the area of housing? In spite of record profit levels, the banks told the Government earlier this year that savings bank housing funds had dried up and that they would not be able to continue their rate of lending for housing without substantial assistance from the Government. They have received that assistance. Although the banks got what they wanted, the prospects of ordinary Australians being able to afford a home loan are not looking as good as they could. Partial deregulation of housing loan interest rates, along with financial deregulation and the entry into Australia of foreign banks-I have not heard any criticism from the Opposition of those measures-have not done much to assist the average home buyer yet. The big winners in current circumstances in the game being played by the banks are those seeking large loans of $75,000 or more. Given the spiralling prices of houses everywhere, but especially in Sydney, people needing large mortgages make up a large proportion of borrowers. There is plenty of this money around, provided that one has sufficient salary to pay for it-those are the people about whom the Opposition is worried regarding taxation measures-and provided that one is willing to pay an interest rate of between 16 3/4 and 17 1/2 per cent.

A range of home loan options has already been offered by banks, such as the Westpac Banking Corporation, including several aimed at those large borrowers. More initiatives will be taken by the banks to win a bigger share of the market for large home loans. Why not? It is extremely profitable for the banks. The majority of Australians who cannot afford such huge mortgage repayments must consider the other options. Many cannot afford the 15 1/2 per cent interest on the average loan. It is true to say that most savings banks are now offering the option of low start loans. It is that option that will become more attractive to the average home buyer. But is it really a viable alternative? It needs considering closely. As anyone with a mortgage knows, the first few years of repayments make no impression at all on the amount outstanding. Under a low-cost start loan, not only would borrowers not be repaying any principal, but they would not even be paying all the interest due. The longer the loans, the more interest is toted up that eventually must be paid. But for many people desperate for a home of their own, this option is seen as the only one which could bring that home ownership within their reach. Let us not fool ourselves on who is benefiting most from low start loans. The loans cost more in the long run, and it is the banks that come out the real winners in the end.

Just six months after the Government deregulated the interest rates for new borrowers and extended a $140m subsidy to banks to boost their lending for housing, rumblings from some sections of the banking sector are already being heard again. It is said by some that the subsidy arrangement was negotiated against a background of an expectation of falling interest rates. Because that has not happened yet, they believe that total deregulation is the only answer to the problem.

The Minister stated in the House two weeks ago that he has made it perfectly plain to the Housing Industry Association that there will be no increase to the pre-2 April housing loan rate of 13 1/2 per cent. I believe that the savings banks should be responsible not just to their major shareholders; they should be responsible to their small investors as well, those ordinary Australians who invested their savings in pass book accounts with the banks because they believed their funds would be protected. These funds make up some 30 per cent of savings banks deposits at interest rates averaging around 4.5 per cent.

For many years in this country there has been a social contract whereby the savings of Australians on a priority basis would be made available for home lending at reasonable rates of interest. That social contract has now been broken, and the main beneficiaries are the banks. This Government wants some beneficiaries in housing. What is the Liberals alternative? They call for massive cuts in real income and living standards. It is difficult enough now for people trying to get a home of their own. It would be impossible under the Liberals because all they are catering to is the profit motive of private individuals. There would be chaos and disruption under them in the labour market. Just as there has been a growth of inequalities under Reaganomics since deregulation, which the Liberals support, there has also been a massive erosion of the American dream of home ownership. Now that we have a deregulated financial sector in Australia it is difficult to see the banks acting responsibly towards Australian home borrowers. As I said in the beginning, this Government is facing up to its responsibilities in the public housing sector. I just hope the banks will do the same in the private housing sector. I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very short and precise expose of doctrinaire socialism which is at the very heart of the Government's policy in relation to housing throughout Australia. Before turning to the amendment so ably moved by my colleague and friend the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), I want to acknowledge the presence in the chamber this morning of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and other Tasmanian representatives who are very concerned about the way in which our State has been treated by the Hawke socialist Government, particularly in the area of housing and works.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment moved by the honourable member for Deakin-I commend him on the manner in which he is performing his duties as shadow Minister for Housing and Construction-is indeed a substantive one to which I wish to address certain remarks later in my speech. Before I turn to the amendment I want to draw attention to one aspect of the second reading speech made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) on the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill, which has not been subject to very great comment. A decision was taken by the Hawke socialist Government which was forced on the Loan Council and which has had very substantial financial impact on Tasmania. Without staying to argue the rights or wrongs of the economic strategy, I draw attention to the fact that at the Loan Council meeting this year a decision was forced on the States, including Tasmania, to reduce the State governments' Loan Council program to $1,204m in 1986-87. That was a 23 per cent cut on the figure of 1985-86. When we are talking about housing in Tasmania it has to be borne in mind that since May of last year the Hawke socialist Government has cut funding to Tasmania in excess of $201.5m. That is an absolute disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —They hate Tasmania.

—As the honourable member for Franklin says, they hate Tasmania. It is in the context of that vicious financial maltreatment of Tasmania that the additional across the board decision by the Loan Council, forced on it by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to cut by 23 per cent the amount of money available to the States has had a very disastrous impact on Tasmania and has had a very disastrous impact on those who wish to purchase homes or build homes in our State.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the catastrophe of this year's Budget it is significant that we go back a further year and just ascertain what the treatment was in Tasmania in relation to the housing and works program. I remind the House that if one cares to check Budget Paper No. 12 for the 1985-86 Commonwealth civil works program, one will find that the entire civil works program as set out in Budget Paper No. 12 for the State of Tasmania represented a miserable $2.57m unexpended balance of works in progress as at 30 June 1985. Even if every dollar were spent in the financial year just ended, the treatment of Tasmania would have been pitiful. But what is more interesting in relation to the Government's so-called commitment to housing is the fact that in relation to new works a miserly $520,000--

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—A miserly $520,000 for the provision of six houses was tacked on so late that it did not even get into the Budget Papers. It was given in a roneoed handout from the Minister's office. Mr Deputy Speaker, now that you are in the chair I must ask: Why was this $520,000 tacked on for the provision of six houses? In passing, I would have to say that I would like to know why, under the Hawke socialist Government's policies, six houses will cost over half a million dollars. We do not know where they have been built. The honourable member for Franklin watches every house built in his electorate. I ask whether he has seen any of these millionaire houses. This is six houses at a cost of $520,000. What it means is that the Hawke socialist Government's civil works expenditure for the whole of Tasmania, for the whole of 1985-86, was less than one-tenth of the amount provided for Tasmania by the Fraser Government in the same program in 1982-83. If that does not prove beyond a shadow of a doubt that the Hawke socialist Government really does hate Tasmania and has given up any chance of winning any House of Representatives seat in Tasmania in the foreseeable future, I do not know what does.
—We will be back again.
—The honourable member will be back, of course, with an increased majority, because of the manner in which he serves his electorate.
—They will probably lose a senator, though.

—The shadow Minister for Housing and Construction is quite right. In fact, the pundits are predicting that at the next half-Senate election-of course, we may have a double dissolution on our hands; the way this Government is going anything is possible-for which six senators will come up for election from Tasmania, the Liberal Party of Australia will clearly win three seats, the Australian Labor Party will be struggling to win two and the sixth seat will go to a non-party member. The reason I had to make this point is that one can hardly imagine what it has done to the economy of Tasmania to have a cut of 90 per cent in its funding program. As I said, less than one-tenth has been provided--
—That is the reason for the price of petrol.

—Well, the price of petrol obviously comes into the issue. But the fact of the matter is that this Government provided in 1985-86 only one-tenth of what was spent by the Fraser Government in its civil works program in 1982-83. I turn specifically to the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill. What do we find provided for Tasmania under this Bill? Under proposed section 5a the maximum aggregate of payments to Tasmania is a miserable $30m. That is chickenfeed. It is an insult to Tasmania. Under proposed section 5b it is even worse-a paltry $15m. The Government is treating Tasmania as trash, it is not giving our State a fair go and once again we see this vicious Hawke-Keating axis persecuting Tasmania for purely political reasons.
—I do not know why.

—We do know why. It is because the Australian Labor Party cannot win a seat in the House of Representatives in Tasmania, and it will not because the Government has victimised Tasmania; it has intimidated Tasmania; it has stood over Tasmania; and it has bullied Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the national scene. What a tragedy it is that under the economic mismanagement of this Government-about the only good thing the housing and construction sector of this Government has going for it is the permanent head of its Department-we are going to see over 20,000 persons in the building industry losing their jobs and, as the honourable member for Deakin pointed out, a shortfall in spending in the housing sector of $1 billion. It is interesting that a number of people ask: `What is $1 billion?'. Some ask: `Is it $100m?' The fact is that it is $1,000m. This Government, by deliberate policies, has created a situation in which $1 billion worth of housing sector activity will not take place this year. The honourable member for Deakin pointed out dramatically how wrong have been the Government's predictions for this year under this incompetent Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) and under this incompetent housing policy. It started off with a firm commitment by the Prime Minister that there would be 135,000 new starts this financial year. That figure was varied to some extent by the Indicative Planning Council assessment of 130,000. But we now have the drop-down figure of 122,500 new starts.

I remind the House that two years ago the Prime Minister gave a firm electoral commitment that the Government would maintain the number of housing starts over the next two years. That was another broken promise. The figure that was then the accepted level of housing starts was 142,000. So, as the honourable member for Deakin has pointed out, there has been a drop from the cut-back figure of 135,000, but the original figure was 142,000. That means a drop of 20,000 new starts. Applying the job loss formula, that means a loss of 30,000 jobs. In case that is disclaimed by an incompetent Government endeavouring to wriggle out of its responsibilities in this matter, I remind the House that the estimate of job losses made by the honourable member for Deakin and by me is in fact less than the prediction by the building unions. Only a matter of 18 months ago a leading member of a leading New South Wales building union went on radio and at that point predicted job losses in excess of 20,000. On the updated figures, the union's estimate for job losses would be in excess of 30,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—It is shameful. The honourable member for Deakin, as shadow Minister, will be well aware that the one thing that the industry seeks more than anything else is some certainty as to where Government policy is going.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the amendment, I point to the incompetence of this Government, which publicly stated that the amount that would be raised through the capital gains tax, which is specifically referred to in the amendment, was $25m. Yet at the Australian Labor Party National Con- ference which was held in Denison-I do not think it will come back to Denison in a hurry, not because there is anything wrong with Denison but because the people of Denison have seen through this rotten, twisting, lying Government-the figure went from $25m to $300m. The Treasurer of Australia boasted to his colleagues that the revenue from the capital gains tax would be $300m. I remember that, when the matter was debated in the Parliament, I said: `Do you really believe that the Government would bring in a capital gains tax to get a mere $25m? Do you really believe that it will employ 1,000 extra tax inspectors for a mere $25m? I smell a rat'. I should have said that I smelt a bandicoot and a ferret but I said that I smelt a rat. The truth is now coming out. The figure that the Government is after is not $25m but $300m. That is for starters.

What will be the impact of that on the housing industry? I will quote from an article which appeared in the Australian only a day or two ago in which Mr Peter Knox, the Director of Taxes with the firm of Arthur Young and Co., a very big firm of chartered accountants in Sydney, stated:
More and more taxpayers are becoming aware of the potential impact the capital gains tax will have on their investments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including the family home in certain circumstances.

—I am about to come to that. As the honourable member for Deakin and the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) have pointed out, it has now been exposed-I use that word advisedly-that there are 15 ways in which a capital gains tax can be imposed on the family home.
—How many ways?

—Fifteen. At the time that the Government brought in the capital gains tax it told the people of Australia that the one thing that would be exempt would be the family home. That statement was not true because the law has now been exposed. There are 15 ways in which ordinary Australians will pay a capital gains tax on their home despite the fact that this Government repeatedly said that the family home would be exempt. Of course, this Government and this Prime Minister also said over and over again that there would be no capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: What credibility does this discredited Prime Minister have with the home owners of Australia, to whom he said publicly in the run up to the election: `So that there will be no misunderstanding, so that even those with the most limited intelligence will understand: There will be no capital gains tax'? That promise now lies in tatters and shreds. Worse still, the law which the Government brought in, which it promised would not encompass the family home, has been shown to be a fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—It is not rubbish. There are 15 ways by which the capital gains tax will apply to the family home-and I hope it applies to the honourable member.
—Explain one.

—I will give one straight off the cuff. If the family home passes through an estate to the son and because he is unable to continue to operate in that particular area, he sells it, capital gains tax will be payable. I hope that the first home in Australia slugged with the capital gains tax is the home of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). Let him have a bit of his socialist dogma right back in his teeth. I hope that he is the first to fall into the trap of the capital gains tax or, if not him, one of his family. I bear him no ill-will, but he is one of the most doctrinaire socialists in this House. If he moves further to the left, he will fall off the cliff of Australian politics; that is how far to the left he has gone. I come to the amendment moved so ably by the honourable member for Deakin, which I had the honour to second.
—I think he has been bitten by something, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—It is all right for the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) to make his interjections sotto voce from the other side of the chamber, but there is a bit of sense in what was put to him a few minutes ago by the honourable member for O'Connor. The plain fact is that, despite all of this Government's promises, on issues affecting housing the Government has been found guilty. It promised that interest rates would come down. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister said that interest rates would fall and would continue to fall, but that has not happened. The honourable member for Deakin was so right when he said that there is not a single economic expert in Australia who will say that interest rates are going to fall, as the Budget strategy demands that they must, by the end of the calendar year 1986. The home owners of Australia are now paying the highest interest rates in real terms since the Great Depression, and the pressure of interest rates is keeping young people out of homes. Worse still, particularly in areas of western Sydney, young people who got into their homes are now being forced out of them.
—They are in strife.

—The honourable member for Franklin is quite right. They are being forced to leave their homes because the policies of this Government have created an interest rate climate which those people simply cannot handle. That is bad enough in itself, but it is far worse when one realises that these policies are quite deliberate. These are deliberate economic policies of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer whereby they have created a situation as part of their economic strategy that interest rates will remain at a high level. That is a fundamental fact. It is a deliberate policy which is heartless and cruel. It is reminiscent of the words of Mr Dedman, who expressed the socialist dogma in the years after World War II when he said that he did not want to see all Australians own their own homes because that would create a nation of little capitalists. At every point where a purchaser wishes to obtain his or her home, this Government's policies are making it harder.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government was warned about the decision in relation to the quarantining of negative gearing. The Government's own consultative committee told it in January last year that if it moved to quarantine negative gearing, that would create a situation where there would be a shortfall in the provision of accommodation on the rental market. The Government was clearly warned at the time and was exposed by the then shadow Minister. The Government chose to ignore the advice of its own consultative committee. The matter was discussed at a meeting of Ministers in Perth in February of last year and the Government was warned by its own advisers. I say in passing, to be fair, that the Government was warned by some of the State Labor Ministers who attended that meeting that if it fiddled with negative gearing, it would create a situation in which the supply and stock of rental housing would deteriorate, and more importantly, as the honourable member for Deakin has pointed out, rentals would rise on the remaining stock that was available because it would be at a premium. I do not often hand a bouquet across the political fence, and rarely have I been known publicly to commend a member of the New South Wales Left, but I commend the Minister for Housing in New South Wales, Mr Walker, who last year and this year had the courage to stand up and speak the truth on certain of these issues. Whether one agrees with Mr Walker or not, I found it refreshing that at least one State Minister, being a member of the Australian Labor Party, saw through the economic irresponsibility of the policies of the Hawke socialist Government. Mr Walker has been sent to Coventry because he again told the truth in Hobart at the Australian Labor Party National Conference. A lot of what he said was not only true at the time but has been proven to be true since.

We have a disaster on our hands. The capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the quarantining of negative gearing have combined to create a situation where the option of home ownership is fading in front of the eyes of prospective home purchasers, most of whom are young. Many of them placed their faith in this rotten Hawke socialist Government. Many were sucked in by the promises that there would be housing for all. Many believed that under this Government they would have a chance to buy their own home. They have been cruelly and disgracefully betrayed. They will not forget that their dreams of owning a home in Australia became a nightmare under the policies of the Hawke socialist Government. The sooner that this rotten government is thrown out of office, the sooner that this incompetent Minister is removed, and the sooner we put in place policies of a Liberal-National Party government which will give Australians the chance to own their own homes, and more importantly to keep them, the better for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall find it necessary to depart to some extent from the essence of the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill to deal with some of the matters raised by Opposition members in what they claim to be an amendment in relation to this legislation. Of course, it is nothing of the kind. I have already indicated that the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) obviously is not happy with his shadow portfolio responsibilities. He wants to discard the responsibilities for housing and construction and is making a run for the shadow Treasurer's job. He has moved an amendment to this legislation which deals generally with economic questions and which has no direct relevance to this Bill at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to hear some of the rhetoric from the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). He referred to the number of people who are disadvantaged in housing. He tried to claim that in some way that resulted from some deficiency in the housing policies of the present Government. Let us examine that statement. Undoubtedly a large number of people in Australia have just heard that contribution. I do not mind political rhetoric but when the rhetoric is intentionally and deliberately designed to misrepresent the circumstances, to mislead the community and to apportion blame to a government where that blame should not lie, I shall take the amount of time that is necessary to refute that rhetoric.

Let us look at the record and see where the fault lies. When the Fraser Government came to office in 1975 the number of names on the public sector housing waiting list was 105,700 for the whole of Australia. After seven years of that Government that number had increased to 123,700. It was an increase of another 20,000 families in Australia who put their names on the waiting lists for public sector housing at a time when the economic policies of that Government were responsible for exceptionally high interest rates. It was claimed a short while ago that a similar thing was happening now. But what is happening now has nothing like the dimensions of the position at that time when people were being forced out of their homes. The Treasurer at that time, the honourable member for Bennelong and present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), used to refer to the fact that people were trading down their homes. What he meant was that people were being forced out of their homes because they were unable to meet their mortgage payments; they were trading down the quality of their homes.

What did the Labor Government inherit? It was not just a matter of 123,000 people on the public sector waiting lists for homes; we also inherited a situation, because of the policies of the Fraser Government, where according to a Federal Government report at the end of last year dealing with homelessness and inadequate housing about 40,000 Australians sleep out of doors or in refuges every night. An additional 60,000 are on the verge of homelessness as a result of the situation that developed during those seven disastrous years. When talking of the provision and adequacy of housing and about the great Australian dream, let us also recall that the number of housing commencements in the last year of the Fraser Government had fallen to about 100,000. In the first three years of the present Government we lifted that figure to about 150,000. The fact that there has now been some marginal reduction in the number of housing commencements expected for this year reflects in large part general economic circumstances, from which we take no comfort. But the home building industry would have collapsed to less than 100,000 commencements this year had it not been for the fact that the present Government took the problem and attacked it seriously, and of course very successfully. The anticipation was that without those measures having been adopted by the Government there would be about 95,000 commencements this year. Opposition members should not shake their heads. The expectation from the Indicative Planning Council, if interest rates had not been relaxed on new housing loans, was that the number of housing commencements this year would have been 95,000. Opposition members know nothing about the housing industry. If they are not aware of that fact they would have been better to prepare for this debate by equipping themselves with some of the information that was necessary to make a more successful contribution to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I claim to have been misrepresented and I challenge the honourable member to prove the truth of what he has just said.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—No proof is needed. That is known by every person in Australia, except the honourable member for Denison. The number of new commencements was expected to be 95,000. It will now be about 125,000 as a result of the relaxation of interest rate controls on new housing loans. In that way the housing industry was revived not only to the extent of 30,000 additional home commencements this year but also total private finance for housing, which was expected to collapse completely, is now back to in excess of $6,000m. I hope that the people who listened to the remarks of the honourable member for Denison will take that on board.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the public sector housing and at the Government's present housing program. Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agree- ment, which provides finance for a number of different housing programs including the Aboriginal rental housing program, the pensioner rental program, the mortgage and rent relief scheme, the crisis accommodation program and the local government and community housing program, the Federal Government-the Hawke Labor Government-will make available a total of $1.2 billion to the States this year. That is only a start. In addition to that, the Government will also allow the States to borrow an additional $584.7m for public housing through the Loans Council and, as the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) indicated earlier, this will be at a concessional rate of 4.5 per cent, repayable over 53 years. That means that this year the Hawke Government is providing $164.6m more than was made available last year. That represents an increase of 14.8 per cent for public sector housing which is significantly in advance of the increase in building costs and the general consumer price index. That increase will make it possible for the States increasingly to attack the shortage of homes for Australians. Increasingly, Australian families will be given decent accommodation. That is not the kind of situation that existed when honourable members opposite were in office, when people were being thrown out of their homes and were taking accommodation in tents and tin sheds and when 40,000 people had nowhere to sleep at night. They did not have a roof over their heads.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking rubbish.

—I know that honourable members opposite hate this, but I intend to take advantage of this opportunity to correct the impression that was given by the honourable member for Denison when he deliberately misrepresented these circumstances.
—Absolute rubbish.

— Order! The honourable member for Denison has continued to interject during the speech of the honourable member for Charlton. If he continues to do so, the Chair will have no option but to deal with the honourable member.

—Thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker, but our greatest protection against Opposition members is the truth and that is what they hate. While they can feed out these misrepresentations, while they can peddle these lies, they take advantage of their opportunity to do so--
—Order! I think that the honourable member for Charlton should withdraw the phrase `peddling lies'.
—While they peddle these deliberate untruths--
—I think that the honourable member for Charlton might withdraw that phrase too.
—While they peddle these untruths, these innocent untruths--
—Order!
—There is a limit, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—The honourable member for Charlton knows the forms of the House. He cannot suggest that another member is a liar and neither can he use some mechanism to get around that. The honourable member for Charlton will withdraw his phrase and continue with his speech.

—Certainly. I do not need to make those claims because the Australian people do not need me to tell them that, they know. They know exactly what the position is. Right from the start the Hawke Government made it perfectly clear that it would deal with the serious deficiencies that we inherited in public sector housing. Only two or three months after we were elected in March 1983 we started this process. In the May economic statement we tore out of the Budget for that year $1,000m of pork barrelling, sops and handouts to the supporters, benefactors and members of the Liberal Party of Australia. We tore $1,000m out of that Budget and one of the things that we replaced it with was $500m for additional public sector housing. There are families throughout Australia who are now living in dignity in decent homes, providing adequately for their families and giving them security as a result of the policies of this Government. Those people who lived in fear and insecurity, families who lived in tents, tin sheds, mobile homes and caravans, are increasingly being placed in decent housing accom- modation. This Government, the Hawke Government, has consistently made a firm commitment to the Australian people that it would not continue to tolerate a situation in Australia where the degree of equity was of the kind we inherited, where people would be disadvantaged because of circumstances that were beyond their control. It would not tolerate a situation in which kids would be made liable for the fact that their parents were disadvantaged economically, financially or socially. This Government has made a commitment to the more deprived and distressed sections of the Australian community and it will continue with that commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer also to the Opposition amendment that has been moved. Whatever might be said by the honourable member for Deakin, the honourable member for Denison and any other spokesman on the Opposition side, it is extremely important that the Australian people know the situation to which the Opposition again aspires. Let us have a look at part of the amendment. It complains that as a result of the Government's significant tax initiatives, incentives have been reduced for private investors to put funds into the private rental market. It claims that this has been brought about by the imposition of two additional initiatives in relation to the taxation system. I do not know how Opposition members can go out and defend this, apart from the misrepresentations we have heard. There are two things that the Opposition wants to do and I want to tell the Australian people exactly what that will mean. If those characters opposite get back into government they will do these two things, let us make no mistake about that. Let me tell 96 per cent of the Australian people that they will pay for the Opposition's policies. They know whom they will pay and how they will pay. Opposition members should hang their heads in shame. First, the Opposition wants to remove what it calls the iniquitous capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—There, I hope that that response has been heard. Let me point out that 95 per cent of Australian taxpayers pay taxes that subsidise those people who have been able to take advantage of capital gains. Ninety-five people out of every 100 have been subsidising the untaxed capital gains of those people who were sufficiently smart to convert their taxable income into untaxed capital gain. We have made sure that forever into the future, while ever a Labor Government has the opportunity to determine the direction of this nation, people will have their income taxed, whatever form that income may take. I will not be tolerant and this Government will not be tolerant about a situation in which wage and salary earners in my electorate pay their taxation to subsidise a limited number of people.
—That is rubbish.

—The honourable member for Dawson is interjecting, but he knows full well that most of his constituents are wage and salary plugs; so why does he come in here and defend a relatively small proportion of people in his electorate who are able to take advantage of untaxed capital gains? The same applies to the honourable member for Deakin.
—Your arguments are being torn to shreds like your fringe benefits tax.
—The same thing applies to the honourable member for Denison. Most of his constituents are wage and salary earners, so why does he not represent them instead of all the rip-off merchants?
—I do represent them and they keep re-electing me.

—The honourable member does not. He does not represent them either. He represents neither them nor their interests. Those people who were able to convert taxable income into untaxed capital gains under previous Liberal-National Party governments will not be able to do it any more. The claim that is being made that the family home will be taxed under that capital gains tax provision is just as spurious as some of the other points that were made by the honourable member for Denison. The next thing that they will want to do is to take out the removal of negative gearing provisions.
—Take them out.

—The honourable member for Groom says: `Take them out'. Let us see what that negative gearing means, so that the people who heard some of the earlier contributions to this debate will know exactly what it means. Negative gearing provided investors with the opportunity to raise large capital loans to buy an asset which was then leased or rented at an amount that was insufficient to cover the interest that was charged on the loan. They deliberately engineered an arrangement of that kind so that then they could take the extra interest off their taxable incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The attempt to shout down members on the Government side when they are trying to explain these circumstances is coming from cockies' corner. I hope that the people in the rural areas understand this as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Those investors attempted deliberately to gear up the amount of interest that they were paying on the loans, claim that against other income and, as a result of that, reduce the tax that they were paying. In effect, that meant that the ordinary wage and salary earner, in paying his or her tax, was subsidising the asset accumulation of those people who were able to take advantage of negative gearing. By moving an amendment, honourable members opposite have made it perfectly clear that if they are given the opportunity they will build back into the system all the rorts, ramps and rip-offs for which they were responsible before. The 95 per cent of the Australian people who, through taxation, finance untaxed capital gains and negative gearing should keep that very, very clearly in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —One becomes confused and bemused in following the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). In fairness to him, I think it would be reasonable to say that in this Parliament he has played many a great game and he has run many a great race. I recall with pride how he, as Chairman of the Economic Committee, quite appropriately and properly indicated to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the Prime Minister was wrong in his economic philosophies and policies, and the Prime Minister quite often accepted the honourable member's advice. I am not terribly sure whether the honourable member for Charlton is like the old footballer who has torn his cartilage or the greyhound that has ruptured its spleen, but on balance I think he is like the old racehorse that has been turned out to the back paddock and he is trying to get the vitamins and all those things out of his system. I say to him that he has run his last race.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take a few minutes to correct some of the things that he said. As the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren), who is sitting at the table, quite honestly knows, the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement was set up by a government probably four decades ago. The 4.5 per cent, which the honourable member tried to convey to the Australian public was the interest rate, was there long before Australia had to put up with a socialist government. It does not give me any great pleasure at all to indicate to the people that, quite frankly, the honourable member did not know what he was talking about in his speech. The most recent statistics indicate that by the June quarter 1986 dwelling commencements were running at an annualised rate of 117,000, compared with 136,000 last year and 152,000 the previous year. The Government's housing policies are going down the drain each and every year. Anyone who knows anything at all about macroeconomic policies knows that there are two reasons for this: This Government has allowed to develop a climate in which we have in real terms the highest interest rates known in this country and it has not seen fit to make the same arrangements with the building societies as it made with the banks.

The honourable member for Charlton did not have the courage-I am not saying that he did not have the honesty; he is the old racehorse out in the back paddock that has run its last race-to say that 20 per cent of all people renting houses in Australia are spending, before they can buy their bread and meat, 35 per cent of their incomes on rent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-five per cent?

—I know that the honourable member for Dawson is upset about it; I can understand that. Twenty per cent of all householders who are renting, under the socialists, are spending more than 35 per cent of their incomes on rent. What do the kids have with which to buy a cricket ball or bat or a football to kick around? Surely my colleague and my friend the honourable member for Charlton is not proud of what his Government has achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I am proud to rise in this debate on the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill to support the very comprehensive amendments that have been proposed by someone who obviously is a statesman to come up with these types of amendments. I particularly want to support those amendments as a Queenslander. As my colleague the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) said, as a previous Minister for Housing obviously I have concern for the welfare of people, and I have a great concern for the welfare of my State. As we are all aware, Queenslanders are a pretty independent lot. We have a proud history of encouraging free enterprise as a means of getting ahead and providing for one's needs. I know that historians record in the annals of history that Queensland has led the way in the latter part of the twentieth century by providing its people with the free enterprise spirit which pulled this country out of its recession bound slumber.

This spirit is apparent when one glances at the figures for the waiting lists for public housing throughout Australia. I am glad that the honourable member for Charlton at least has adopted the Westminster system and is staying to listen to the next speech. I know that he will be upset about it, but it is the truth. In New South Wales, a socialist State, almost 57,500 families-Australian families-are waiting for public housing; in South Australia, a socialist State, there are 39,500; in Victoria there are 32,644; and in Western Australia more than 11,000 are on the public housing list. In Queensland, a free enterprise State now and always, only 9,000 people need public assistance to put roofs over their heads. A member from New South Wales, where 57,700 of his fellow New South Welshmen are waiting for public housing, must look with envy at the great State of Queensland where only 9,000 people need public assistance to put roofs over their heads. Only Tasmania and the Northern Territory have lower figures, but they have much smaller populations and do not have the great influx of migrants from other States that Queensland has.

In addition-this is terribly important-Queensland has the shortest waiting time. The time between the date on which a needy family signs up for public housing and the date on which a home is made available is only a matter of weeks, usually a month. Like the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest), I am proud to boast that the Queensland housing authority is by far the most efficient in Australia in providing shelter. That is despite the mighty drift to the north of people from southern States. Queensland still manages to cope better with this growth than any other State. All this is occurring while Queensland has one hand tied behind its back because, as a State, it still does not receive its full per capita share of States grants for housing funding. During my stewardship as Minister for Housing and Construction, I succeeded in correcting this disproportionate allocation of funds to the States from the Commonwealth. As an honest Queenslander, I saw the need for justice to be done and I took the opportunity to grant funds according to the population base of each State. Since that time in the early 1980s there has been a gradual phasing in of per capita allocation of funds. To introduce per capita funding immediately would have caused massive disruption in many States and the plan to phase in per capita funding over 10 years will not be fully implemented until 1991. Regardless of this honest and innovative approach, however, Queensland has lost over $111m since 1981-82. How has Queensland managed with the loss of $111m to keep its public housing list down to only 9,000 and the time spent on the waiting list to one month? Deep down, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) must admire this approach. I know that he will not say that he does and I do not expect him to do so. However, when he is in the back paddock getting rid of his vitamins he will recognise that Queensland is a great State.

The House will recall that I have spoken of Queensland being the free enterprise State of Australia. When people from overseas and Australian businessmen who become fed up with all the socialist philosophy in the south look to invest in Australia, or relocate, where do they settle? Queensland, of course. Why do they bring their money and businesses to Queensland? They do so because Queensland gives them more encouragement in the form of lower taxes. We do not believe in death duties. I shall tell the railway workers in my electorate that the honour- able member for Charlton is putting capital gains tax on the family homes of workers. In Queensland we offer more encouragement in the form of lower taxes, lower workers compensation premiums and, above all, a Premier, the Hon. Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who will back up these policies.

Queensland led the way in the South East Queensland Electricity Board dispute for the nation. The outcome ensured that railway workers, meat workers, main road workers and council workers were able to have an electricity supply connected to their homes at a cheaper price. The honourable member for Charlton wants the people to have dearer electricity connections. The rest of Australia is just now catching up with the concept of giving management the right to manage, whether it be in the Pilbara or the Public Service in Canberra. We in Queensland have a sympathetic understanding for low income earners who, through their hard work and sweat, have made Queensland the great State that it is today, but for many of these people home ownership is a dream, something achievable only by a chance win in the lottery under the socialists. I remind the honourable member for Charlton that in the last years of the Fraser-Anthony coalition 72 per cent of Australian people either owned their own homes or were in the process of purchasing them. What is the figure under the socialists? We had the highest home ownership rate in the world but we cannot claim to have that now. That is because the socialists still aspire to the Calwell philosophy-and I quote from one of his speeches: `We do not believe in home ownership. We do not want little capitalists permeating Australia's society by owning their own homes.' I shall expose those blokes for what they are.

In Queensland we have a home ownership scheme which allows a family on a low income-this is why low income earners vote for the honourable members for Deakin (Mr Beale), for Denison (Mr Hodgman), for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), for Lyne (Mr Cowan), for Cowper (Mr Nehl), for Hinkler (Mr Conquest) and me. We are really interested in low income earners. In Queensland we have a scheme which allows low income earners to afford to buy a home of their own. I am talking about people who are earning less than $300 a week. The scheme came into existence in 1982 when we had meaningful relationships between the Commonwealth and the State. The Housing Commission has granted over 13,000 loans and it is interesting-I hope that the honourable member for Charlton is listening-that there have been only 50 repos- sessions. The scheme has kept our public housing waiting list at a low level and at the same time it has discouraged the poverty trap by giving families the ability to become the proud owners of their own homes.

We are all aware that the breakdown of the nuclear family has caused greater strains in the public housing sector, but there are other factors which influence the demand for state housing. The Labor Government's decision to discontinue negative gearing, the current high interest rates-due to the Hawke socialists' policies-and a gloomy economic outlook have led to a downturn in the construction industry. As a result, rents have skyrocketed. I hope that the honourable member for Charlton reads the newspapers. He does not keep in touch with his constituents, but if he reads the newspapers he will know that rents have skyrocketed. Some of the families which were home owners were, through no fault of their own, unable to keep up with their rising mortgage repayments. The socialists are not interested in helping building societies. In the difficult times in which we are living we need policies introduced into this Parliament that reflect and recognise the aspirations of all middle and low income earners. That is why I am privileged to support the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Deakin. It seeks to introduce the necessary policies, and if it is implemented it will do so.

The need for innovative policies is becoming more and more apparent with the call for financial restraint from all sectors of our economy. The cut in Federal money coming into the States' treasuries has brought about the need for both a change in the expenditure of scarce resources and a rethinking of the way in which we fund programs and capital works. I am interested that the socialists have not talked about the capital works section of the Bill. That is the section which deals with Commonwealth contributions to works, buildings which are not revenue producing but which provide services such as health and education facilities. These arrangements have been in existence for many years and it is interesting to note Commonwealth-State debts developments. I am not interested in the fact that something is happening in Queensland on 1 November, just the overall concept, but Queensland-I hope that the honourable member for Charlton and the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) are listening-has the lowest public sector debt per head of population--

TALK.START.PARA: —Of any State in Australia?

—Yes, of any State in Australia. Queensland has a debt of only $949 per person to pay compared with the overall average in Australia of $1,171. The Commonwealth debt was nearly $3,000 for every man, woman and child living in this country. I ask people of compassion and concern--
—That is us.

—Government members do not have a grain of compassion and concern, let alone an ounce. What are we doing to our future generations? Our gross foreign debt has risen dramatically from $9.1 billion at the end of June 1981 to about $88 billion at the end of June this year. This represents about $5,500 per head of population. When we tie in the interest payments on this gigantic debt, we find that it is about $5 billion, or about $390 on the head of each and every one of us. Our national consumer credit bill is now about $60 billion, representing a private debt of $8,000 for every Australian worker. How is this debt to be paid back? These people on the other side of the chamber have designed macroeconomic policies that are forcing a debt of over $8,000 on every baby that is born in Australia. It is an enormous debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth needs to reduce its demand for funds from the financial markets so that new investment can take up the opportunity to invest. All the push and shove that we see to lure investment in manufacturing will not bear results unless the market has access to cheaper money, a stable economy and security in its ventures. Again I am proud to say that my great State of Queensland has managed to keep its per capita tax rate the lowest in the country, and this is without a tax on liquor, petroleum and tobacco or a financial institutions duty. Those are the sorts of taxes that the socialists impose on the poor workers. They are not interested in the workers at all. It is no wonder that we have so many defectors from the south coming to sunny, warm, tax free Queensland.

I spoke earlier about the need to develop innovative approaches to our traditional way of funding works projects. Private tertiary education institutions represent such a concept. Where do we find this alternative approach to public education? We find it in Queensland, the home of free enterprise, the State with 3,000 would-be students, due to the policies of the Commonwealth, still on waiting lists, wanting to expand their education to make their home State even greater.

If we do not have the funding to expand existing facilities, if we do not have the resources from the Commonwealth to give our youth every opportunity they deserve, and if we cannot find places for them in the work force, due to socialist economic policies, why not let someone with entrepreneurial flair and guts to take on such a challenge do so? We need more people willing to embrace opportunities for making our nation stronger, smarter, and able to compete.

The Federal Government should absorb more of Queensland's free enterprise spirit and endeavour to build up this nation. It must not be timid or slow about it. It must recognise that education is a business just as any other, and it can be sold while still maintaining a high quality of output. If the leaders of this country do not begin to take up this entrepreneurial spirit, our indebtedness, on both a Commonwealth and State level, will continue to expand out of all proportion.

If the Commonwealth wants to imitate the Queensland way of doing things, I have complete support for that proposition and no objection whatsoever; in the long run, the nation will be much better off. The Premier of Queensland, the Honourable Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, through his actions--

TALK.START.PARA: —A good man!

—I am delighted that a Tasmanian understands that-Sir Joh is a good man and a great man. He has proved that the free enterprise spirit succeeds and succeeds well if it is allowed to do so. We in Queensland have ploughed the fertile fields, tended our crops and weeded out all the unnecessary regulations and restrictions. As a result, business has flourished and will continue to prosper. I ask the honourable member for Charlton, the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), who is at the table, and the socialists opposite: Is it not about time that they and their Government looked to its barren ploy and tried to do something about it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that the House is indebted to the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), a Minister in the previous Administration, for revealing to us this morning and to the people of Australia the facts about Queensland and its comparison with the other States of Australia. I say that because some of my comments will touch on the rights and responsibilities of the States concerning housing. It is encouraging to hear an honourable member bring forward the facts about a State that has encouraged private enterprise to supply its housing needs.

SPEECH.PARA: There are times when all honourable members on this side of the House, particularly myself, would love to get up and ask: `Why are we involved at all with housing, education and a few other fields that are virtually within the province of the States?'. The States have the power to deal with such matters, if they wish to exercise them. But they come to the Commonwealth and say: `We need the funding to subsidise housing and other areas that are within our province'. We as a Commonwealth have become involved in those areas. We have all been responsible for that. I believe that we would have done better had we said to the States: `Your rights are there'. I even go so far as to say that we should give them back their taxing powers. That would allow a decentralised system of administration in Australia, which is so important to the future of so large a continent. We have a great responsibility to develop our country, our rivers, and so on. The only way we shall do that is to encourage private enterprise to do it. The honourable member for Groom was quite forthright. Everything that he said was informative. We thank him. As he said, Queensland, with a smaller waiting list for housing compared with the lists of other States, illustrates the thought that the Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and members of his Administration have given to this very important matter.

The rights of the States are virtually all there now for them to tackle their responsibility in the service fields of education and housing. They have responsibility for such matters. The Commonwealth can virtually do without responsibility in that regard, although if a Liberal-National Party government were elected to office, it would not scrap such responsibilities because needs exist and we must try to help the States. I hope that, gradually, we can pass over to the States the responsibility for taxing and for other areas. I am sure that the nation would be much better for that.

The States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill is sound. It outlines the funds that the Commonwealth will make available to all the States for those who need housing. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) spoke earlier. I give him great credit for the fact that he is never afraid to get up in the House to argue the Government's case. He spends a lot of time in the chamber, for which I also give him credit. However, he was a little wrong in some of the cases that he put before the House this morning. In June 1983, after this Government came to power, about 124,000 people throughout the Commonwealth were waiting for government housing. By the end of 1985, the figure had increased to 155,753. It is no use honourable members saying that many new building commencements have taken place. The fact remains that since the Hawke Government came to office, there has been an increase in the number of Australians who require government housing. That is the important fact. This Government and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) have been unable to overcome the problem regarding government housing for the poorer people of Australia.

If we were to attack the housing problem as it should be attacked, I feel that there may not be any need for the first home owners scheme and other means of assistance provided by government throughout Australia. I am sure that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) agrees that if we were to provide the incentives for private enterprise and State governments to go ahead and do things, there would be no need for the Commonwealth to be involved. Instead, as has been revealed during the entire debate, it is necessary for us to point out to the Government that if the anomalies, additional taxes and impositions that have been imposed by the Government were lifted, free enterprise would be able to build houses, units, and so on, for the needy people of Australia.

I listened carefully to the honourable member for Charlton when he went into some detail to try to explain to the House the virtues of negative gearing. I see his point. He raised the other side of the argument. His argument was not correct. Let us get down to the grass roots level and consider the communities in which we live. I can talk of the towns of Taree, Raymond Terrace, Nelson Bay, and so on, in my electorate. Governments will not cure the housing needs of Australia. It will be done by the little person who, from a superannuation point of view, decides to erect a unit, or whatever, as an investment. It will be done by the person working on the street for the council and the small businessman. Those people work hard and at weekends they employ labour so they can be with their families. I refer to those living in a caravan in their yard and wives having to put up with many problems so that they may create an asset that, to them, will be a form of superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They need incentive.

—They need incentive as the honourable member for Cowper said. Not only is this superannuation for the people concerned; it also provides housing for the needy of Australia. This individual does not charge excessive rental. He will help overcome the problem with housing because he will go out and work over weekends and live in poor conditions in a caravan or a tent on a block of land. This person has owned a home and sold it. He may buy another home, or erect accommodation in his home town and rent it to people looking for accommodation.
