SPEECH.PARA: Very often in debate in this chamber members of the Opposition, and the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who is sitting at the table, have indicated that in many instances rentals are very high. Mr Scott, the President of the Real Estate Institute in New South Wales, was on television this morning. He indicated the growing numbers of people requiring housing and what should be done to overcome the problem. This man is involved with an organisation directly concerned with housing. He sells houses, encourages people to buy and finds accommodation. He knows about the housing industry. He has been telling the Government for a long time what the answer is to this problem. We can all quote instances of high rentals which the poorer people on low incomes cannot afford to pay. There is no competition in the industry. The answer to the problem is that the Government and the States should provide low cost housing, but we have got to get private enterprise to come in too.

I spoke about the little person who wants to build a block or so of units down the road. He wants to own a home and build another one in order to get something behind him. We have to encourage these types of people. The Government should not place capital gains tax or negative gearing upon them. This is the important factor: The Government should not impose these measures which are killing the incentive and will of the Australian people to work. This is what is happening in our young Australia.

What is Australia doing? Does the Government not realise that Australia is not yet 200 years of age? We will be celebrating our Bicentenary in 1988. It is all right to compare ourselves with the older European countries, but let us have a look at our young country. We have a responsibility to feed the world, to feed and house our own people and to develop the natural resources of Australia. Are we tackling this properly? I am sure we are not. We have lost our incentive. We have lost our will to work in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely right. You have summed it up.

—I am sure the honourable member agrees with me on this. We had better think about it. I assure the House that when we get back into government we will examine, as we are now, the policies that will give incentive back into industry and give incentive to the smaller person working for a wage for the local council or the business down the road. These are the people to whom we have to give incentive.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Groom, to whom we are indebted, came into this chamber today and cited figures for Queensland. It is all right for the Government to try to run down the Premier of Queensland. It is all right to say all these things about him. If that is the only way the Government feels it will beat him, it is a poor attack. As the honourable member for Groom has said, if one examines the facts that emerge from Queensland there is plenty of evidence of what can be done if a government really wants to do things. We have a responsibility in this country to return the incentives that have been lost to the people of Australia.

Let us have a look at interest rates which now stand at 16 per cent or 17 per cent. Who can afford to pay that? Let us compare that with the rest of the world. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) often talks about the problems which affect the people living in Coffs Harbour and Port Macquarie and the growing communities around Australia. Let us look at inflation and unemployment. Why should there be unemployment in this country, when we have a world to feed and a country to develop? Is there not something wrong with the administration? Have we lost, as I said earlier, our foresight of what our endeavours and our directions should be as people? We can look at the low dollar. There is no need for the dollar to be low. We all run around and say: `Isn't it great that the dollar is low because we can sell our products'. That is very nice. We all agree with that. But should we not have a stronger dollar? I am sure that we should. What about our balance of payments and our national debt? We all get up in the Budget debate, which is still before the House, and say: `It is nice that the deficit has come down by $1 billion'. It is still $3.5 billion, and it is a rubbery figure. That is very true.

I will not go into the national debt or the fringe benefits tax, but they are having a tremendously adverse effect on the smaller business man, industry and business generally. Only this morning an article in the Press indicated that only 15 per cent of Australians believe that there should be a fringe benefits tax; 85 per cent of Australians are saying that we should throw this tax out. Members of the Opposition, including the honourable member for Deakin, said last night in this House that we will throw this tax out. That is what the people of Australia require. These are the impositions that we have to attack here.

This nation will never forget this Treasurer. He comes into the House with a fringe benefits tax without considering the realities or the effect it will have on the building of homes, on the farmer in the field and on nurses in hospitals who receive concessional accommodation. Suddenly the hospital says that the rent has to be doubled. What is the answer to this problem? It is going through to the consumer, the worker, the trainee in the hospital and into all fields. It is affecting apprentices and all the young people in this country. They are suffering because of the imposition of the fringe benefits tax. That is only one little issue with this tax. It is a nasty tax. It is a tax that this nation cannot afford. People who are working should not have the worry of sending in these returns.

I have spoken of the capital gains tax. Let us not run away from this problem which particularly affects housing. Only a minute or so ago I spoke about a young person who was about to get married. He said: `I will marry at some time because I want to have a family'. That is the traditional way of life in Australia. He gradually pays off a block of land. The Minister for Housing and Construction, who is sitting at the table, should listen to this because this is a matter which he forgets. This is a matter which he and his Government have really forgotten about. Young Australians today have incentive, but they are changing their thoughts. They are changing in my electorate and they are changing in the Minister's electorate. The Minister comes from an industrial area. These young Australians buy a block of land on terms, pay it off and erect a home. They live there for a while, sell the home and buy another block of land. As I said earlier, they live in a caravan or a tent on the block, but they go ahead and build another home. After the sale of their first home they are up for a capital gains tax on top of the negative gearing. That is the fact of the matter. What incentive is that to these young Australians who are trying to follow in our footsteps?

The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) was married a month ago. How often has he got up in this House and put a case forward for his electors on these important issues? As a young man he will be in this place for a darn long time. He will be here longer than I have been here and I am sure he will take his place on the front bench, because he is sensible. It is important that we should get our feet on the ground. I have reiterated time and again that the approach of this Government is wrong. That is why I am thankful that the honourable member for Groom has come into this House this morning and stated the case for Queensland, which is a free enterprise State.

I could go on and on, but I do not wish to take up the time of the House. The legislation is important. But I have put forward some new thoughts, which have just come to me as I stand here and speak, about our responsibility as elected parliamentarians of this nation. We are failing. But I hope and I know that we of the Opposition parties will not fail in our endeavours to construct and put in place policies which, I am sure, will serve this nation very well over the years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, on behalf of the Acting Treasurer (Mr Hurford), who introduced the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill, I would like to sum up some of the points made by the Opposition in this debate. In the first instance, let me take up the effect of the Bill on public housing. The House will be aware that one of the two intents of the Bill is to make certain percentages of the loan component of the State Government borrowing program-that is, 60 per cent, and 100 per cent in the case of South Australia and West Australia-available to the States at 4 1/2 per cent interest, repayable over 53 years. I am sure the Opposition will agree that that is a highly concessional deal for expenditure on public housing. I will give honourable members some figures on that in a moment and I will pick up some of the points that were made. This $585m worth of expenditure on public housing comes on top of the $693.7m by way of total grant to the States under the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. The total is a very substantial sum of money, almost $1.3 billion of Federal funds which will go to the States for public housing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just compare public housing expenditure in 1986-87 under this Government with what was achieved, say, in the last year of the former Government. First of all, in 1982-83 under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, $406m was made available and nominated funds totalled only $146m. That was a total of $552m for that year. This year under the CSHA the States will get that $694m I just mentioned entirely by way of grant and an extra $582m, a total of $1,275.9m all up. That is a 131 per cent increase on the funding in 1982-83. A great proportion of that increase, of course, comes from the very great rise in nominated funds-this has gone up from $146m to almost $600m in just on four years-which will be paid under this Bill.

I am sorry that I was not here for the full time of this debate-I was at a meeting-but I understand that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) made the point that the housing funds for Tasmania have been cut. I cannot really work out how he came to that conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he said total grants.

—Let us talk about what Tasmania is getting under the housing grants and nominated funds arrangements. Back in 1982-83 it got $29m; this year it is almost $58m. The nominated funds have gone up from $10m to $30m. Tasmania could have got more. I say to the honourable member for Denison that he had better go down and see Gray about this, because Tasmania was the only State in Australia that did not fully take up its entitlements under the nominated funds arrangements in this Bill, which provide for loans at 4 1/2 per cent. Basically, the Gray Government in Tasmania ought to be condemned for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), raised several points which I will quickly take up in the time available to me. The first is the issue of interest rates. I make the point that the former Government presided over the highest short term bill rates-that is, say, 90-day bills-in this country's history when they reached over 20 per cent back in the middle of 1982. The House will be aware-we have made this clear on a number of occasions-that this Government's policy is to take the pressure off interest rates. It is well known why interest rates have been historically high over the last year or so. I will not go into those reasons here. However, the Government has adopted a policy of taking the edge off interest rates by putting more pressure on the fiscal and wages policies. Honourable members opposite would be aware of what happened in the Budget. They know that we have, for the first time in a number of years, a domestic surplus of $0.8 billion and a full Budget deficit of only $3.5 billion. The public sector borrowing requirement has been brought down to 4.4 per cent of gross domestic product which, if honourable members opposite were fair dinkum about this, I think they would admit is a good effort.

Certainly we want to see interest rates come down further. We have set the budgetary conditions in place to achieve that, as I have just enunciated. We expect that over the next few weeks and months an acceptable wages policy will be arrived at and, as mentioned in the Budget, that will involve substantially less than full wage indexation. So the wages and fiscal conditions are in place to see a fall in interest rates. Furthermore, the dollar has been firmer, as honourable members well know, over the last few weeks and interest rates are more stable and are now trending down. I believe that overnight the 90-day bank bill rate went down to around 17 per cent, which is the lowest since mid-August. I hope that after a suitable lag occurs the cash management trust rates will start to trend down as they did earlier this year, before the further depreciation of the dollar occurred in May and then in late July. I think that cash management trust rates will start to come down and that is a fairly encouraging outlook for housing interest rates. I do not want to overstress that point, but all of my economic advice, and the advice of Professor Fred Gruen's Indicative Planning Council, is that we could see a fall in housing interest rates some time towards the end of this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they don't make that judgment; they get that from you.

—That is the advice that I get and with which I concur. So, overall, it is a moderately encouraging outlook for interest rates, because this Government has in place the fiscal policies, and will get in place the wages policies, that are conducive to a fall in interest rates. As I said, the dollar is firmer and interest rates on the short term market are starting to trend down. Again, I do not want to overstate my case, but that is the position, and honourable members opposite know well that that is true.

SPEECH.PARA: I now take up the point that I am told the shadow Minister made with regard to the private rental market. As I have said inside and outside this House, in some cities the private rental market is tight. In some cities that is reflected in the level of rents and vacancy rates. However, let us do a quick comparative analysis. Back in September 1982 we had the following vacancy rates across the board: Sydney, 3.2 per cent; Melbourne 1.4 per cent; Brisbane, 0.8 per cent; Adelaide, 1.3 per cent; Perth, 4.3 per cent; and Canberra, 2.1 per cent. Out of all of those cities only two cities today have a lower vacancy rate. Sydney has gone down to one per cent and Perth, to which city special conditions apply, as we know, is down to 1.5 per cent. Melbourne has gone up. Brisbane has gone from 0.8 per cent to 4.5 per cent and Adelaide has gone from 1.3 per cent to 2.8 per cent. Again, I do not want to overstate the case. I am saying that, yes, in Sydney and Perth particularly the private rental market is pretty tight. However, again, I believe that there is an encouraging outlook in the private rental market, as some of the industry organisation representatives suggested at our Australian Housing Council meeting last Friday. For instance, in July the approvals for units and flats had gone up by 14 per cent, and that was the highest figure since October 1985. As I said, it looks as if the investment could be starting to come through again in the private rental market which, of course, is predominantly concerned with the construction of new units, flats and other dwellings.

Unlike the Opposition, we do not pine for a return to the days of the tax rorts when people could negatively gear their investment to the extent that they could get a tax write-off against not only the income from the property, but against all their other income, whether it results from work as a specialist, a Qantas pilot or whatever. Of course, we want a fair dinkum tax regime. I make the point that negative gearing has been quarantined; it has not been wiped out. It is restricted to the income from the relevant property or properties. That is the way it will stay because we are committed to that position.

It is far better to rely on a depreciation allowance such as we have introduced, which, as I said a moment ago, appears to be working better and which is restricted to new buildings and add-on renovations, than it is to encourage, through tax rorts, people to speculate and drive up the prices of existing buildings simply because they can get a tax concession. We intend to use the depreciation allowance to hike up investment in the private rental market but at the same time to get the added spin-off of investment in new buildings and thus assist the industry.

Mention was made of policy possibilities. It is always open to the Australian Housing Council to put forward ideas. That is what it is for. It comprises some 40 representatives from the industry, including the Master Builders Association, the Housing Industry Association, the Real Estate Institute of Australia, the unions, the Australian Bankers Association and State Ministers. All of the industry organisations are represented on that Council. Of course, they ask: `What are your forward intentions? We would like you to consider these matters'. The day before the meeting I met with members of the Master Builders Association and the Housing Industry Association. They put up policy suggestions about home ownership and about investment in the private rental market. Of course, I do not send them packing. I say: `Yes, well, of course you know that our package is firmly in place; nevertheless I will not send you away. We will look at whatever proposals you put up but I do not give any commitment to introduce them.' The Government is working with the industry. So that is the answer to that point which was made.

In investment in housing-public housing, the private rental market and home ownership-the Government has proved its credentials. In a very tough and stringent Budget it has brought down a very tight deficit and a domestic surplus. We have still been able to fund the bank package which protects the interest rate of 13 1/2 per cent for pre-2 April loans. We have done that at a cost of $145m. We have retained the first home owners scheme. I remind the House that the Opposition's proposal is virtually to abolish that scheme, for which there is expenditure and forward commitment of almost $1 billion and which has already helped 245,000 households into home ownership. We have allocated $210m for the continuation of that scheme in this very tough financial year.

I have already said what our commitment is to public housing. When the States put in their matching funds, total funds will be almost $1.9 billion, which will construct about 22,000 new dwellings. The figures are that there should be about 14,500 new starts for public rental and about 7,500 new homes through subsidised home loans. That is a great effort. It shows the bona fides of our housing package with respect to the first home owners scheme and public housing.

I conclude by examining the state of the industry, which was mentioned by the shadow Minister. The first thing to say is that, particularly as a result of the April package-no one disputes this-savings bank lending has been very strong indeed. My figures, which I get in advance of the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, show that trend to be continuing through August and September. I think the figures for savings bank deposits come out today. I understand that they will be fairly strong for the month of August; we will find out about that later today. But the rate of lending is strong and the growth in deposits is reasonably strong.

But let us look at the state of the industry. For the reason we have been over here on a number of occasions, the annualised rate in the June quarter this year slumped to about 117,000 starts. That is the Indicative Planning Council figure that was released to the Australian Housing Council the other day. The IPC says that we should be back to an annual rate of about 130,000 starts by the June quarter next year. As I have said, that is a moderately encouraging position. Of course, the future does depend to a great degree on interest rates. I have already covered that point and said that the outlook there is also moderately encouraging. I have said that the 13 1/2 per cent interest rate for pre-2 April loans is set in cement; it will not be altered.

I say to the banks-I conclude on this note because it is not a bad note on which to conclude-that, given the moderately encouraging outlook for the industry and for interest rates, it is not the time to lift the 15 1/2 per cent rate. It would be far better to take a watch and hold approach and see what the immediate future holds for interest rates. I am moderately confident that interest rates for the rest of this year will trend down.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Beale's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr West) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the third reading, cognisant of an incorrect ruling by another Deputy Speaker recently on what one is allowed to say on the third reading. I hasten to add that I want to make two comments specifically about two clauses to which I adverted on second reading, but not to recap on the entire second reading debate. As this States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill comes to its third reading, I complain about the shocking discrimination against Tasmania in the program which is authorised by the legislation of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West). I will repeat the numbers. The plain fact of the matter, as I have pointed out, is that in last year's Budget in the civil works program, which is critical in this area of housing and construction, the total amount appropriated for Tasmania for new works was a miserable $2.57m. That is less than one-tenth of the $33m which was made available to Tasmania in the same program in the last year of the Fraser Government. In relation to new works, the amount allocated--

—Order! There is a specific ruling regarding the third reading-no two ways about it. That ruling is that members at this stage may not debate the question in toto but must refer specifically to a clause. Would you identify it?

—My remarks are specifically directed to clause 3 of the Bill, which relates to proposed sections 5a and 5b of the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act and, secondly, to clause 4 of the Bill in relation to loans to States for public housing. I am very conscious of the ruling, Madam Deputy Speaker, and I know exactly what you are driving at, but I want the opportunity to refer to both of those matters. I wish to refer to, firstly, grants to States in 1986-87 in respect of capital expenditure; secondly, advance payments to States for 1987-88 in respect of capital expenditure; and, thirdly, loans to States for public housing. I indicate that my remarks will take only a couple of moments.
—That is quite all right.
—I should have nominated the full funds.

—It is all right for the Minister to mumble and grumble at the table. I am about to make the comment that the deal Tasmania received in 1986-87 under this legislation was on the basis of a miserable $520,000-that is all.
—Miserable.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is quite right. Only $520,000 was provided in Budget Paper No. 12. It missed the Budget; it came out in a roneoed handout and it was a tack-on for `six houses'. Budget Paper No. 12 provided for six houses-$520,000. If we look at the Schedule to this Bill, we will see that Tasmania has been discriminated against by this Minister and this Government.
—Rubbish!

—The honourable member can say `Rubbish'; he should go back to the embassy. It is all right for the honourable member, from his seat in Melbourne, but I am talking about decent people in Tasmania who cannot get housing because of this Government's disgraceful treatment of our State.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, this Minister should resign or should bring in an immediate amendment to this legislation to give Tasmania a fair deal. The Minister hates Tasmania; he has discriminated against our State. I have close contact with our State Premier and Minister for Housing. No government has treated Tasmania worse in housing than this Government, and it stands condemned for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I did not intend to speak on the third reading of this Bill, but I cannot let the remarks of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) go unchallenged. As I said in replying to the debate on the second reading, if one looks at the figures in the last year of the coalition Government under the Commonwealth-State housing agreement in 1982-83, one sees that Tasmania received only $18.8m. In 1986-87 it received $27.7m completely by way of a grant. As an add-on in 1982-83 it received a mere $10m as its proportion of the State Government borrowing program. This year Tasmania will receive $30m; so the comparative figures are $29m in 1982-83 to Tasmania for public housing under the former Government, and this year $58m under this Government-a rise of 100 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat what I said in my reply to the second reading debate that all States nominated to the full extent available-except the State of Tasmania under the Gray Government. Even the National Party Government in Queensland nominated to the full extent of its arrangement. Certainly Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia nominated 100 per cent. If Tasmania had been concerned about housing shortages in that State in the area of public housing, it should have nominated all the Federal funds it was entitled to, but it refused to do so. So it is the Tasmanian Government which is not concerned with housing related issues in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! I call the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). Does the honourable member for Charlton have the leave of the House to speak at this stage?

—I rise on a point of order. I refer to Budget Paper No. 12, and to the figure of $2.57m in the civil works program.

—The Minister has indicated that the allocation to Tasmania under the Commonwealth-State housing agreement is $27.7m. I make two additional points in support of that. First, contrary to the claim made by the honourable member for Denison, Tasmania on a per capita basis has fared very well indeed, as he knows. DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT (RECIPROCITY WITH ITALY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Amendment (Reciprocity with Italy) Bill was first foreshadowed by a coalition Minister for Social Security in 1982. The initiative was announced by the then Minister Senator Chaney who foreshadowed the intention of the Liberal-National parties to proceed with the development of proportional portability as a concept for the payment of pensions to Australians who returned to their country of origin after a period of residence in Australia. For that reason the Liberal and National parties support the concept and the direction in which the Government is moving with this legislation. Therefore, we do not oppose it. Notwithstanding, we have significant reservations about the direction and the mechanics of the action taken by the Government and also about the way in which it is negotiating these agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to spend a few moments outlining, for the benefit of those members who have not read the Bill, the contents of the legislation. Basically the Bill facilitates a reciprocal social security agreement between Australia and Italy. It represents the implementation of negotiations that have been conducted over several months to ensure that we have reciprocity and proportional portability of social security benefits, and in particular age pensions, between Australia and Italy. The Opposition has some concerns about the Labor Government's approach to this issue. We are concerned about its priorities, the mechanics of the scheme and the way the scheme is to be implemented. It is worth reflecting that much of this negotiation and legislation arises from what could be described only as a rush of blood to the head of a former Labor Prime Minister, one Gough Whitlam. In 1974 Prime Minister Whitlam announced, in a gesture of largesse, that all Australian pensions would henceforth be portable and that if one were entitled to a pension in Australia one would be so entitled overseas. It was a magnanimous gesture, but puts considerable strain on the Australian taxpayer and takes no account of the international equities of the payment of social security benefits nor of the different systems of social security operating in Australia and many other Western and developed nations throughout the world.

The principal difference is that Australia runs a non-contributory, needs-based social security system, whereas many other countries throughout the Western world run a needs-based and also contributory social security system, particularly in the case of retirement income policy. It is interesting that this Government, with its so-called highly developed policies on social security, has done nothing to bring Australia into line with the rest of the world. From that we must conclude either that it does not have any policy or any intention of making significant changes to the Australian social security system, or that it is convinced that the Australian system is right and everybody else is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested to hear your policy.

—The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) will hear our policy in due course. The Minister must remember that he is the one who is in government and that he should be explaining his Government's policy. It is similar to the Government's attitude to the fringe benefits tax. He is the Minister for Social Security, he has the Department, he has all the consultants working on reports and he says to the Opposition, `Please tell us your policy because I am devoid of ideas'. The Minister will hear our policy when the election is called, and he should have a better policy than he has at present because the Australian people have had enough of the way he is running our social security system. In fact, the Minister's competence in running that system is called into question every day in nearly every newspaper in Australia. They raise questions of fraud, overpayment and equity in the payment of age pensions. The Minister is about to change the assets test for the sixth time.
—Order! Will the honourable member and the Minister stop carrying on a conversation across the chamber. Will the honourable member address his remarks to the chamber through the Chair?

—I heed your comments, Madam Deputy Speaker, and would also request that you direct the Minister for Health to refrain from conducting a loud and voluble conversation with the Minister for Social Security, which is deliberately designed to distract me.
—Order! I have called the honourable member for Richmond and expect him to speak to the question to hand. It is quite within the capabilities of the Chair to carry out Standing Orders.

—As I was saying, this Bill provides for proportional portability of pensions between Australia and Italy. There are four main principles covered in the legislation and I believe they are all quite logical and deserve bipartisan support in this House. The principles could be summarised by saying that there is a concept of shared responsibility-that is, each country in which the person has been resident will accept responsibility for that person's social security payments and financial maintenance in the future. There is equality of treatment between the two countries and there is totalisation of either residence or contributions or both and that highlights the difference between Australia's system of social security and systems operating overseas. The whole system operates on a pro rata basis and it is this pro rata basis which brings problems to light in relation to this agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Minister for Social Security made certain statements earlier this year and last year about proportional portability of pensions, he was at considerable pains to stress that no one would be worse off. He went to great lengths in his Press releases to say that some Australians would receive extra income, but no Australians would be worse off. That is patently not correct and I believe that it is encumbent upon the Minister and the Government to clarify exactly the implications and consequences of the agreement they have negotiated with Italy and how it will operate within the Australian system.

Let me quote an example. Proportional portability does not apply to a person who has been a resident of Australia or an absent resident of Australia on 8 May 1985 and who begins to receive a pension before 1 January 1996. However, if a man arrived in Australia on 7 May 1985 and turned 65 on 2 January 1996, he would receive only 43 per cent of an Australian pension if he left Australia and went to a country with which Australia had a reciprocal proportional pension agreement. A one or two-day difference in the birth date-that is, the qualifying time for an age pension in Australia-can result in a 57 per cent drop in his entitlement to an Australian age pension, other factors being equal. I refer to many of the statements made by the Minister, particularly the one in his Press release dated 7 November 1985, reference No. 67/85. On page 2 he says:
Many in Australia will get extra payments from overseas, but none will be worse off.

I think I have demonstrated conclusively that many Australians will be worse off and will be worse off in a very arbitrary way because of the incidence of both their birth date and the arbitrary date selected for the implementation of this agreement. Quite frankly, there will always be problems with the introduction of such an agreement, but it is encumbent upon the Minister to acknowledge that there are problems. The Australian ethnic communities are also capable of conducting the same analysis to which I have just referred and that is why among the ethnic communities representative of the Greek, Italian and perhaps some other communities in Australia at present there is concern about the implications of this agreement and its consequences for their citizens in Australia. It does not behove the Minister at all to ignore this problem and pretend that it does not exist. It would be far more honest and forthright for the Minister to acknowledge that the problem exists and that some people will be disadvantaged by the arbitrary operation of these dates. If he were genuine in his approach to these negotiations, given that there is bipartisan support for the concept of proportional portability of pensions, he would recognise that he could have explained how the scheme would operate and there would not have been any significant political backlash.

That is not the only significant problem with the proposals that are being implemented by this Labor Government. There is an inherent assumption in this agreement that Australians who were not born in this country will return to their country of origin. That is not necessarily true. Let me explain the consequences of that assumption for some people who were born outside Australia, who lived and worked for some time in their country of birth, made a contribution to that country's social security scheme, but perhaps did not reach the trigger point, the point at which they are entitled to a payment under that country's scheme. Such people come to Australia and under the scheme proposed by the Minister they earn an entitlement to an Australian social security payment and, for the sake of simplicity, let me assume that it is an age pension. Let us take the hypothetical example of a person born in Greece who works in that country for perhaps 30 years. He comes to Australia and earns an age pension proportional entitlement in Australia and then goes to, say, Italy. What will be the consequences for that person? Perhaps he will not have an entitlement under the Greek system to be paid in Italy; there will only be a proportional entitlement under the Australian system as a result of the proposal to be implemented by the Minister, and when that person goes to Italy he will have no entitlement under the Italian system. I believe that it would be appropriate for the Minister to face up to those consequences. The example that I have cited, between Greece, Italy and Australia, could perhaps be described as extreme, but it is not unusual for people born in Europe to return to Europe, but not to the country of their birth.

One could think of cases of people born in Germany, France, Belgium, or the Netherlands who might come to Australia to work for a period, earn only a part entitlement to an Australian age pension and because of the location of their families or where their children may have settled in Europe, they do not return to the country of their birth so they have no entitlement under that third country's social security system. How does the Minister propose to accommodate such an example under the agreement that he has negotiated here? What will be the consequences if, in the future, he negotiates proportional portability agreements with those third countries, yet the person whom we are discussing has no entitlement in those countries? The Minister must be aware of these possibilities, he must have been advised by his Department of the consequences of this legislation and of these agreements as the number of proportional agreements negotiated by Australia increases significantly. The Minister owes an explanation not only to the Opposition but also to the Australian community. How does he see the scheme operating in the future?

I am also concerned about this Government's priorities in the negotiation of proportional portability agreements and reciprocal agreements for pensions. Earlier this year and late last year we had considerable debate about the payment of social security benefits to New Zealanders living in Australia. I do not want to raise the detail of that particular debate at this time, but I do want to raise the relationship between Australia and New Zealand in terms of social security. As I have said previously, Australia has portability of social security benefits, an initiative of the Whitlam Labor Government; New Zealand does not. New Zealanders who have lived and worked in that country and who have paid tax do not, if they move to Australia, have an entitlement to receive their New Zealand benefits in this country. Of course under the agreement recently renegotiated between Australia and New Zealand, they have an entitlement to receive Australian benefits. It is encumbent upon the Minister to explain why, at the time of renegotiating the agreement with the New Zealand Government to accommodate certain administrative problems and potential for fraud, abuse and manipulation which initially he said did not exist, the question of proportional portability of pensions was not raised and was not made part of that agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was raised.

—The Minister says that it was raised, but I still do not know why we do not have a higher priority for negotiating a similar agreement with a very close trans-Tasman neighbour like New Zealand. The Minister should explain that publicly and in some detail. Of course, the same comment can be applied to the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom has one of the most impertinent attitudes that could be imagined to the payment of pensions to its former citizens who are now resident in Australia. Former residents of the United Kingdom with an entitlement to United Kingdom pensions are paid those pensions at the rate and at the level of their entitlement on the date of their departure from the United Kingdom. Many of these people come to Australia and over the period of their residence in Australia the rate of inflation in the United Kingdom and our much higher rate of inflation mean that the effectiveness of pension payments made from the United Kingdom, notwithstanding our ever declining dollar, is inadequate. The United Kingdom Government has for many years refused point blank to renegotiate the agreement and refused to adjust pensions paid to former citizens of the United Kingdom who are now resident in Australia in order to account for inflation in both the United Kingdom and Australia. The Australian Government is forced therefore to top up those United Kingdom pensions to adjust for changes in the exchange rate and inflation rate. I am told-I do not have any accurate figures for this-that there are up to 800,000 former residents of the United Kingdom with potential pension entitlements in Australia.
—Stop putting out misinformation.

—I would be interested if the Department of Social Security or the Minister could, at some time, give me some indication as to the accuracy of that figure. I would like to know the exact number of former United Kingdom residents living in Australia who receive pensions which are topped up by the Australian social security system. It strikes me that there must be an absolute priority for negotiating a reciprocal portable agreement between Australia and the United Kingdom. While this Government is so preoccupied with negotiating with the United Kingdom over the cleaning up of former atomic test sites in South Australia, it could direct the same attention and zeal into renegotiating this agreement.
—I have publicly stated that we are renegotiating the United Kingdom agreement.

—Perhaps it could direct the same public pressure to those negotiations that would be warranted by the significance of the relationship between the United Kingdom and Australia. This Government is running around in circles in terms of social security. The Minister is lying back at the table, interjecting at will and suggesting that certain things are not the case. The reality is that there is so much wrong with the Australian social security system that he does not know where to start. Yesterday he tabled a 38-page discussion paper on maintenance payments, which conflicts with previous Press statements. We have seen in Budget estimates in relation to the payment of Australian pensions overseas that he proposes to withdraw the two resident Australians from the London office, which is responsible for the administration of Australian pension or social security payments to the United Kingdom, Europe and Africa. It is hoped that the Department of Foreign Affairs will step into the breach and fulfil the administrative arrangements. We pay about $87m worth of social security benefits to Europe, the United Kingdom and Africa. We have two Australian officials over there at present, but the Government proposes to bring them home. I think that is ample evidence of the priority that the Government attaches to maintaining this system.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a very complex system of social security, which is based on entitlements and obligations of some people to comply with the requirements for eligibility of that system. In terms of the priorities attached to negotiating agreements, we see no evidence of the Government's adopting a rational approach which reflects financial priorities and population linkages. We see no evidence of the Government's determination to ensure that the system is internally consistent, by ensuring that the requirements are applied equally and with equal force to Australians who are resident in Australia and Australians with an entitlement who are resident outside Australia. We see a continuation of the double standards and a continuation of the need to fine tune the system to cope with the fundamental flaws that arise. We see a reluctance on the part of the Government to address the fundamental problems in the system and to undertake significant reform.

However, we see significant lampooning and significant rhetoric from the Minister, but we are still waiting to see a full-blown social security policy. I am still waiting to see the same determination on the part of this Minister as was evidenced by a former Labor Minister, the Hon. Bill Hayden when he was Minister for Social Security, who went to the Department with an agenda, a set of objectives and a capacity to change the system. The present Minister seems to be ambling along, dividing his time between fighting on behalf of the left wing faction of the Labor Party and trying to cope with the immensely complex and difficult problems of social security in Australia. The Government's attempt to address the problem of retirement income policy has been an absolute failure which will be paralleled with its attempt to come to grips with the taxation of fringe benefits in Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I remind you that there is a considerable parallel between it and the actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to rescue his Government from the mire of the assets test, announcing on the run that he would have a review of the assets test, which went on and on and on. Until last week we had the fifth version, and I am told that in a Bill to be introduced in this place later we will see further changes to the assets test and its implementation, which will take us to the sixth version. I ask this House and the Government whether we will see six, seven or eight versions of the fringe benefits tax. I believe it is incumbent upon this Government to address the question of social security equity seriously, not to restrict itself to handing out statements in the form of Press releases which contain only the most superficial comment and which contain no significant discussion or debate upon the consequences of these changes for the Australian community and, in particular, the Australian ethnic community.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax-Overseas Trade-World Peace Initiatives-Australian Industry: Restrictive Work Practices-Queensland Government-Courier Mail Advertisement-Australian Submarines Program-Capital Gains Tax-National Party of Australia: Advertisement-Multiculturalism

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has fulfilled nearly two years of its current term, its second in office, and is now exhibiting signs of governing under very great pressure. The conjecture running in some of the media of this country is that it may cut its losses and go to an election, perhaps later this year. That is, indeed, a matter of conjecture and only the handling by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of the current bungling of the fringe benefits tax will tell us, by the time the end of the year is upon us, what his intentions are. But it is interesting to reflect, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there will probably be less than 20 sitting weeks of Parliament available to honourable members before the Government goes to the next election in the natural fulfilment of its three-year term. It is interesting to see the Prime Minister under so much pressure as he bungles, day after day in this House and in the media, the handling of the fringe benefits tax. He has learnt little from his bungling of earlier proposals such as the assets test and lurches from one crisis to another under Opposition questioning as to whether or not the tax will apply to certain groups within the community. So we await with great interest the developments of the Government's response to the public rejection of the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon I want to refer briefly to one of Australia's greatest problems. It is one which is announced each month by the publication of Australia's overseas trade balances. It is such a problem that the Government has no solution for it and, by ignoring the full impact on the Australian community of the dramatic reversal in overseas trade, the Government seems to be saying to the Australian community that it does not know what to do about it. In August the reversal amounted to $1.235 billion. For the running year from August to August the deficiency in our overseas trade balance totalled $13.92 billion. By this time next year it is expected that there will be such a degree of accumulated imbalance in our trade that each Australian will owe, overseas, $7,000. What a burden to hand on to the future generation! It is in the light of this tremendous, accruing deterioration of our balance of trade that one looks with interest at the meagre attention that the Government is giving to that problem. I notice in today's Australian Financial Review a report-the subject is referred to in other papers also-on a new announcement by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins). It is headed `New Drive aims at $3.5bn' and relates to the Minister's attempt to increase Australia's industrial exports. Apparently the Minister intends to achieve this by an expenditure of $2m. That is a laughable investment, I believe, in relation to the severity of the challenge and the need to revitalise our industrial exports. The Government obviously intends to do little indeed in this regard. We read of an expenditure of $2m to procure an improvement of $3,500m in export income. We read of round-the-world air trip prizes for small business people who do well in producing income.

I am not decrying the measures that the Government has announced. At least it is giving some attention to this vast problem, but it is entirely insufficient to rely on giving prizes to peak exporters in small industries, in the course of a $2m promotion which seeks to energise Australian export managers, and to rely on import replacement programs based on providing new logos for Australian made goods. That is fiddling at the edges of this enormous problem for Australia. We are, of course, left in the dramatically reliant situation of depending for export earnings upon the traditional bases of primary industry and the resource industries. Wool, meat, wheat, coal, iron ore and metals are the only factors included in a little synopsis of Australia's exports-which is included in a review of the Australian economy put out by the Commonwealth Bank-of the 13 per cent or some such proportion of our exports which derive from an industrial base. At this time, when the great resource and primary industries are under enormous pressure, because of the adverse terms of trade, in regard to the earnings that they can bring into this country we have an opportunity as a community and as a government to do something real about promoting industrial exports from Australia.

The Government sees the taxation system of this country too much as a matter of collecting income for the Government rather than an instrument of policy. In the Fraser years the Government decided that Australian industry needed an infusion of new investment in plant and equipment. I think all honourable members will remember the effect of the Fraser Government's policy of offering an investment taxation allowance which started off at the dramatically high figure of 40 per cent. It had the equally dramatic effect of putting billions of dollars worth of new plant and equipment into Australian productive enterprises. That was a direct response to a direct incentive. We know also that a great deal of the success of the Australian film industry is based on the very real incentives that have been provided through the taxation system. I put it to the Government that that is the only real way to energise potential industrial exporters-rather than seek, by the giving of prizes to find a simple answer. The Government can give prizes too if it likes. The answer is not to spend a paltry $2m on promoting export managers' activities, but rather give real incentive to exporters through the taxation system. I put it to the House that about 13 per cent of Australia's manufactures are exported. The best figures available to me at the moment-they are a little out of date-reveal that in 1983 manufacturing companies made gross profits of just under $8 billion. After allowing for interest and depreciation totalling $4,200m and taxation of $1,758m, they were left with a profit of $1,978m. If one adjusts the figures roughly, as one must, from 1983 to the present because of the lack of information available, one arrives at the fact that, with 13 per cent of industrial activity related to exports, Australian secondary industry is paying approximately $350m a year in taxation on income earned from such exports.

The Government is in the process of making rather dramatic changes in the taxation system of this country and I put it that there should be a trade-off between the relief that it is giving to individual taxpayers and the provision of incentives for the export of industrial products. It could in fact reduce the taxable profits earned by Australian manufacturers on exports to 20c in the dollar merely by the expenditure of several hundred million dollars in taxation relief. That would indeed provide a real incentive for industries in this country. I am not asking the Government to forgo revenue but saying that the Government should trade off its search for popularity in the community-by way of reducing personal income tax-against making certain that there are other incentives than the low value of the dollar. It should make certain that Australian exporters are aware that if they get out there and sell our manufactured goods overseas they will get a real reward in their annual profit and bank balance. That is the way in which people respond-not to exhortation but to policy changes that put more profits in the bank at the end of the year. It would enable companies to compete with the lower costs in other countries. I ask the Government to reconsider the paltry sums that it is expending on meeting our export problem and make a real contribution, in the course of its taxation changes, to coming down heavily in favour of relieving the tax burden on exporters of industrial products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —In two days President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev will meet in Iceland. Their meeting comes after nine months of uncertainty about whether a second summit meeting will be possible and several weeks of wrangling over Nicholas Daniloff, the American journalist arrested in Moscow and Gennadi Zhakarov, the Russian diplomat arrested in New York. After much negotiation, agreement was reached to exchange these two and Yuri Orlov, a Russian human rights campaigner, thus making way for this weekend's meeting. Those concerned with super-power relations are relieved. While the Soviet Union and United States of America leaders are talking the possibility of achieving agreement on important arms control and disarmament measures is enhanced and the danger of conflict is reduced. Towards the end of a year in which aggression, violence and nuclear accidents have dominated the news, the Reykjavik meeting is a sign of hope. A second recent sign of hope was the agreement reached on September 22 at the Stockholm based conference on confidence and security building measurements and disarmament in Europe. That agreement was the first to cover conventional military forces throughout Europe. All countries in Europe except Albania have agreed to provide to each other an annual calendar of their planned military manoeuvres. The significance of this agreement is that it makes it easier to detect any threatened military activity. The agreement will reduce insecurity and build confidence between the countries of Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: However, my purpose in speaking today is to draw attention to a third and less well-known sign of hope, the work of Parliamentarians Global Action. There have been two significant results from the work of that organisation this year-progress on the establishment of a global seismic network for verification of a nuclear test ban treaty and agreement for on-site inspection of nuclear test sites in the Soviet Union and the United States by non-government scientists. Parliamentarians Global Action was formerly known as Parliamentarians for World Order and was launched in 1980. It has a membership of about 600 members of national parliaments in about 35 countries representing the full spectrum of political parties. The members of Parliamentarians Global Action recognise that the only way to provide security for our constituents and countries, and ensure a future for humanity, is through world-wide demilitarisation, economic development and strengthened world institutions. Working together across frontiers we seek to act as catalysts to promote constructive change in the international community. I attended the organisation's annual forum at the United Nations Organisation meeting in New York in October of last year and am the Australian member of the PGA Council.

One of the major activities of PGA has been the organisation of the five continent peace initiative. This initiative began a couple of years ago and includes the leaders of six major non-aligned countries-Argentina, India, Mexico, Tanzania, Sweden and Greece. These six leaders have met several times and have been in frequent contact with the two super-power leaders, calling for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty as a crucial step towards ending the arms race. A major stumbling block in the test ban debate has been the issue of verification. At the urging of PGA the six leaders entered the verification debate. PGA commissioned a report on the feasibility of verification of a test moratorium, including the technical details necessary for implementing such a plan, from several eminent United States scientists. With this study as background, the six leaders made a series of verification proposals in personal correspondence with Reagan and Gorbachev. In a message delivered just before the super-power summit in Geneva in November of last year, the six proposed a nuclear testing moratorium with verification measures and offered their countries as locations for seismological verification stations. Within weeks, in a major shift from its traditional policies, the Soviet Union accepted the proposals of a group of six. There was other correspondence between the Six and Gorbachev, in March and April of this year, which contributed to encouraging the Soviet Union to extend its test moratorium. The most recent action by the six leaders was a meeting in Mexico in August. In the communique issued after the Mexico meeting the six nations offered the funds, the personnel and the equipment to back up their concrete verification proposal. The annual cost of the program, which the six countries will provide, is estimated to be about US$10m. The Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) was amongst a number of leaders who welcomed the Mexico declaration on disarmament.

The timing of the Mexico meeting of the six leaders turned out to be opportune, for on the day after they made their proposals public the United States House of Representatives passed, by 234 votes to 155, an amendment to the Defense Authorisation Bill which provided for a cut-off in funding of nuclear testing for one year beginning 1 January 1987. The condition for this cut-off is that the Soviets do not resume testing during that time. The proposal to cut off funding was initiated by several members of Parliamentarians Global Action including Tom Downey, who is one of the presidents. The fortunate timing and linkage of the six-nation summit and United States House of Representatives vote showed that co-ordinated efforts can have a positive bearing on the disarmament climate. The other initiative in which PGA has been involved this year is the agreement by the Soviet Union to allow on-site verification by non-government scientists. The Global Action delegation which went to Moscow in April also met with members of the Soviet National Academy of Sciences, thereby setting the stage for the United States National Resources Defense Council's project, under which a team of United States seismologists will set up seismometers at the Soviet test site of Semipalatinsk in July and at the United States test site in New Mexico. This is really an extraordinary breakthrough because, after many years of opposition to on-site inspection, the Soviet Union has now agreed to it. It is regrettable that so far this has been limited to verification by non-Government scientists but that may well lead later to intergovernmental agreement to on-site verification. The Soviet Union has maintained a test moratorium since August 1985, yet the Reagan Administration remains obdurately opposed to a testing moratorium. This is despite the fact that both the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate have now voted in favour of a testing moratorium. The United States administration claims not only that verification remains a problem but also that it must continue to test existing weapons to make sure that they are working. Perhaps both are actual reasons for the administration's opposition but it seems likely also that testing requirements for the strategic defence initiative, Star Wars-a proposal under which includes a nuclear explosion-driven X-ray laser in space-represent one of the important reasons for the refusal to join the Soviet Union in a testing moratorium. The Soviet Union has said that it wants to put a test moratorium on the agenda of the Reagan-Gorbachev summit. In fact, Gorbachev has said that he wants to include this in the discussions in Iceland on Saturday and Sunday.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the principal reason for this speech is to draw attention to the value of activity outside the formal channels of Government and to show that non-government organisations can play a significant role in changing the climate and contributing practically to arms control and disarmament agreements. It is encouraging to have these glimmers of hope because without them many would despair about the desperately serious threat to the survival of human kind which the arms race involves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year coal export shipments to Japan were held up in New South Wales ports. Twenty ships were at anchor, idle! Exports suffered, mines were closed, mining jobs were lost, and all because of a strike over an all too familiar Australian restrictive work practice-overmanning. This was not a shipping strike, nor was it a mining strike. The economic chaos was caused by the Australian Federated Union of Locomotive Enginemen. This was a strike over a manning issue in the railways. It was a strike in which the unions' claim was repudiated by the arbitral authorities and even condemned by Mr Wran, the then Premier of New South Wales. It was a strike which served to illustrate that a union can wreak havoc and not be liable for the losses incurred. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made a contribution to the development of restrictive work practices in Australia. During his period as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions he condoned and encouraged these counter-productive work practices and attitudes. Now, as Prime Minister, he resorts yet again to another summit to resolve the problem. This issue will be resolved on the factory floor, not by so-called summitry between big government, big unions and big business. At least the Prime Minister has become aware that there is a problem and that Australia's future is at risk because we are no longer competitive or efficient in world terms.

SPEECH.PARA: On September 15, 1986, the Economic Planning Advisory Council produced a paper outlining the difficulties facing Australian industry as a result of the effect on productivity of restrictive work practices, which it defined as:
Particular ways of working which are introduced and maintained for reasons other than safety, effectiveness and efficiency.

As such, they have a dubious rationale, particularly in today's economic environment, and collectively contribute to an inflexibly organised and underutilised work force with reduced individual satisfaction from, and motivation to, work. This feeds back into a lower productivity syndrome. The paper identifies areas where these restrictive practices have grown up during times of prosperity since World War II and are no longer to be tolerated in these tougher economic times. Accommodating management attitudes allowed these practices to develop. I refer to overmanning, demarcation by tradesmen and unions, a reluctance of the work force to adopt new technology and the retention of old methods. The condoned practices of compulsory overtime have become the norm, and the excessive tea breaks, late starting times and early knock-off times have become institutionalised work practices which militate against efficiency and good morale.

In the mining industry, and the coal industry in particular, there has been a gradual and casual approach to the changeover time taken between shifts. This has resulted in six hours of work being achieved during an eight-hour shift. What is more, the coal industry has accepted the inefficient practice of having productive work from Monday until Friday only. What remarkable under utilisation of resources in such a capital intensive industry. EPAC suggests that industry should move from a craft-based union structure to industry-based unions where a co-operative effort will ensure profitability and job opportunities. Management, in its turn, needs to move away from the `we and they' syndrome, where there is a separation of the roles between the work force and managers. Industry protection from the chill winds of international competition fosters and encourages such restrictive work attitudes and the capital and export nature of some of our major mining projects encourages these outdated work practices in the interest of production and short term profits.

In recent months, the work practices of the Pilbara region have brought Australia's export industries and working conditions into sharp focus. The sacking of 1,200 workers at Robe River identified a number of problems that had been glossed over by both management and unions in the past. I appreciate the problems of isolation, difficult working conditions and repetitive work activity with little tangible result for hours worked, but the local rules of work developed to outrageous proportions. For instance, front end loaders worth between $1m and $2m were utilised for about six hours during an eight-hour shift, reducing the productivity of that piece of equipment by 25 per cent. Union stand over tactics and management weakness had allowed the practice to develop to this alarming degree because export orders had been profitable and management's main objective had been to fill the ships and not worry too much about productivity in the mine itself.

The widely-publicised dispute between the Electrical Trades Union and the South East Queensland Electricity Board clearly demonstrated restrictive trade practices in their worst form. On that occasion, the Electrical Trades Union had restrictions on the use of contractors and insisted on prescribing the number and classification of employees and enforcing the strict demarcation of work. After a long and protracted dispute involving the Queensland Government, the issues were resolved with common sense prevailing and productivity returning to normal levels. At Port Hedland last year the strategic use of stop work meetings at a critical time ensured that the export of iron ore was delayed for five days because the necessary rising tide had passed. Therefore, the ore carrier remained yet another day. This cost a Japanese importer $100,000 and soured his relationship with Australia. In the woolbroking business, technology has overwhelmed outdated union practices and attitudes. In Geelong, which has historically been a major wool handling centre for Victoria, about 700 storemen and packers were handling the receival of western Victoria's wool clip. Now about 40 persons do the same job. All bales are now handled with fork-lifts and hardly a bale is touched by human hands. During the mid-1970s the storemen and packers, led by Simon Crean, as Assistant Secretary, managed to have inserted in the award the proviso that bales may weigh no more than 204 kilograms and no less than 110 kilograms. The advent of power presses would ensure that much heavier bales could be pressed-in the interests of efficiency and cost saving. However Simon Crean's outdated, obsolete and ridiculous provision that wool bales may weigh no more than 204 kilograms remains in practice because of an arbitration ruling in 1976 to bring about so-called industrial peace. How will Australia ever become competitive in export terms given the persistence with this outdated practice in a modern, single floor wool handling complex using modern mechanical equipment? Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon who, in recent times, has been most supportive of the coalition's industrial relations policy of achieving a more flexible wages system, has added his support to the removal of restrictive practices within industry and has said:
Improving the ability of our industries to compete against intensifying competition, both at home and abroad, requires reform in the area of restrictive trade practices.

I would like to endorse the statement made by Mr Fred Helmer, the Australian managing director of the management consultancy firm, McKinsey and Co, that for an employee to be productive a job must have meaning, an element of creativity and performed in an atmosphere of trust. Without trust industrial relations break down, enthusiasm is hard to muster and people will not innovate. The key objective of the Federal Opposition's industrial relations policy is prosperity through productivity, more jobs, industrial harmony, work place flexibility and reduced union power. Unions which foster restrictive work practices sabotage Australia's overseas trade and employment opportunities and undermine the living standards of employees and their families. They will ultimately be seen as troglodytes and a barrier to economic progress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks ago the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Nev Warburton, raised the issue of a National Party official, an ex-Senate candidate, Michael Behan, being given a loan of $145,000 at the direction of a National Party cabinet Minister despite a recommendation by the Agricultural Bank that the loan application not be approved. It has now been discovered that $85,000 of the $145,000 was, in fact, Commonwealth money lent to Queensland under the National Disaster Relief Scheme. It had been lent at 4 per cent. Because of the efforts by the Premier of Queensland to cover up the issue, it has taken quite a period for the facts to emerge. When finally he was confronted by the media he referred to the loan as a `lousy $145,000'. I would suggest to National Party members here, and to the Government of Queensland and its Premier, that there would be tens of thousands of primary producers who would certainly not think of a loan of $145,000 as representing a lousy amount. As Nev Warburton said so correctly, many a farmer has virtually got down on his knees to the Agricultural Bank and the Rural Reconstruction Board for much less than a `lousy $145,000', as Mr Bjelke-Petersen calls it, and has been refused. It is proof of the special types of preference that apparently is given to the National Party citizens, and of the ministerial interference that does take place. I wonder on how many other occasions similar politically motivated deeds have been done for National Party supporters and members, but never aired. The fact is, unless some public servant in Queensland gets a fit of conscience that he cannot cop any longer, no one seems to know what is going on.

SPEECH.PARA: After all, it took months of Opposition digging and pressure from the media for the truth to come out about the $40,000 that was misappropriated from the Queensland Day Committee. That committee's activities came under the Premier himself but he tried to evade his ministerial responsibilities. Now we all know that another person is to face court in December on charges of misappropriating hundreds of thousands of dollars of public funds through that person's link with the Queensland Film Corporation and the Tourism and Arts Departments. Again, it was only after months and months of hounding that the National Party Government of Queensland admitted the truth behind the allegations of misappropriation. Every attempt was made to cover them up and conduct a disinformation campaign within the media. The latest episode concerns another public servant-linked with the Sports Department-and the fictitious granting of the sum of $9,000 to a sporting club. Again, the issue came to light only because of a leak to the Queensland Opposition. I am told that the figure of $9,000 could blow out into tens of thousands of dollars. The fact is that Queensland needs some sort of Public Accounts Committee but the chance of that occurring under the present Queensland Government is nil because there has been a motion on the Notice Paper concerning it for five years.

Corruption in the National Party of Queensland is not a new characteristic, as some might think. Back in July 1977 a company by the name of Houston Oil and Minerals was given an authority to prospect for coal at a place called Oakey Creek. It was given that authority without public tender. In July 1980 the National Party-dominated Cabinet approved a consortium's application to develop the Winchester South coal field, even though the vast majority of 31 other applications that were received were never considered. In 1982 a company called Maralinga, which was controlled by a well-known National Party political personality, was allowed to do a sale and switch deal on a milk entitlement, which resulted in massive personal profit for his company even though the transfer was contrary to the policy of the Milk Entitlement Committee. In September 1982, a Four Corners report told the story of a prominent businessman who, after donating $100,000 to the Senior Citizens Hospice in the Premier's electorate, received a knighthood. In the same program the expelled National Party member, Lindsay Hartwig, exposed an approach made to him to donate $10,000 to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation if he wanted to get into Cabinet. Again on the same program the State Secretary of the Liberal Party at that time, Stephen Litchfield, said that from complaints that he had received from business people it was the belief in Queensland that if you wanted to do business in that State you had to donate to the National Party and get close to it. Where in any other part of Australia would the head of a quango, a peanut marketing board, be able to pay himself a salary that is more than the Premier gets, take 12 overseas trips, fully paid, not be able to account for tens of thousands of dollars within operations of the marketing board, and get away with it? Where else than in Queensland could we find a politician able to have a decision to build a powerhouse in one area of the State-in this instance, Millmerran-changed to his own electorate, Tarong, where he had nearby mining leases? In doing so that cost the taxpayers $259m and totally overturned the State Electricity Commission's recommendation.

Where else than in Queensland would you find taxpayers' money totally wasted by a government for political purposes? Twenty million dollars that were given by the Federal Government for roads in North Queensland has never been accounted for. It was used, we think, on the Brisbane electrification system. Four million dollars was given for a water scheme in the Gulf of Carpentaria. It is believed that it was used for a dam in an area near where the Premier's son has a property. Tens of millions of dollars have been wasted. Tens of millions of dollars have been misappropriated. Where else than in Queensland would we find a government using taxpayers' money to pay for a five-minute prime time television propaganda program every Sunday evening on every commercial television station, just before the 6 o'clock news? Where else than in Queensland would you find a government that has spent tens of millions of dollars on government aeroplanes but gives no information as to who uses them, where they go and for what purpose? The Government of Queensland has to be made accountable. It is not only the Behan affair. That fades into insignificance against one of the issues raised in July of this year: In 1982 the Queensland Government resumed land for the Burdekin Dam. The compensation to be paid was very carefully checked out by the valuers of the Water Resources Commission. It has now been revealed that a person, who just happens to be a relative of an ex-State member, Vicky Kippin, and is an ex-National Party member-a fellow by the name of Cox-although evidence was given to a land court hearing in July by the valuer of the Water Resources Commission that the land was worth $1,228,413, on his own admission to the court personally wrote to and saw the Premier, and received as compensation not $1.228m but $2,448,000-of taxpayers' money. The latest episode is that concerning Mr Bond and the Premier. I want to read from a confidential letter that I have and that I believe the Parliament ought to know about:
Attention: Mr D. R. Aspinall.
Thank you for letter to Biggs and Biggs dated 22.11.85, which I have now seen.
Please note that solicitors for Mr Bjelke-Petersen have phoned this morning claiming Premier insists matter is settled for $400,000 plus costs.

Insurers have had no discussions with Mr Bond and believe that recent developments have irretrievably prejudiced their position. This matter has gone from being dormant and one both sides could have expected QTQ to win to a position where the Premier expects $400,000 plus costs and any normal commercial resolution appears impossible.
We are instructed that insurers have no wish to remain involved following actions which have breached policy requirements and hereby deny liability. We suggest the following occur:

1. QTQ immediately instructs its own solicitors to act in this matter. Biggs and Biggs may be prepared to remain involved but this would have to be on the express understanding that future instructions and liability for fees rests with QTQ and not insurers.
