2. You give urgent consideration to the ``settlement'' with the plaintiff. If the terms which Mr Bond and the plaintiff discussed were expected to create goodwill, then indications from the plaintiff's solicitors are that this could be jeopardised by further delay.

We note that the discussions which have occurred provide for an unprecedented amount to be paid to the plaintiff. We would strongly urge that such terms be treated as strictly confidential as the sum involved could only raise the expectations of other plaintiffs and potential plaintiffs.
Bruce Burke.

We have here surely the proof that the Queensland National Party Government is the best government money can buy and all that counts is whether you can afford to buy it. Here we have it stated in correspondence, which I table in this House, where Mr Bond expected to buy or create goodwill. People know that when you buy a business a component of that purchase is goodwill and here is clear evidence that Mr Bond here was buying his way into Queensland. He was buying the Premier of Queensland. He was buying goodwill. If ever there was a need for a full and thorough investigation into some sort of deal in the State of Queensland, it has to be the Bond Corporation rort with the Premier of Queensland. Certainly the Queensland National Party is the best government that money can buy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is easily seen why the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) was the permanent Leader of the Opposition in Queensland. I rise in this grievance debate, both as a long time sports lover and a proud Queenslander, and wish to expose the dishonesty of the Australian Labor Party's advertisement in today's Courier-Mail, as compared with actual Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. Before developing that point, I say that I am certainly not alone in this place in professing a love of sport. I share that spirit with no less a person than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself. I think that all fair-thinking people would agree that the Prime Minister was elected to his leadership position because of a perception in the community of an ability on his part to get this nation working together for the greater good of all. The community saw in him a person who might lead us out of the deep malaise we found ourselves in because of the long term effects of a severe drought and a slow-down in the economy. But what has occurred in recent times? The Prime Minister was always there when the America's Cup was won, when a car race was held at Bathurst or Adelaide, or when other sporting events occurred. But he was also in Melbourne and Sydney two weekends ago and was booed. The Prime Minister of Australia was booed. I want to know why he was booed. Was it his Government's decision to impose a fringe benefits tax, a capital gains tax, an assets test? Was it the decision to mine uranium, reintroduce tertiary fees, or merge Special Broadcasting Service with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation? Was it the Public Service voicing its opinion about his actions in streamlining the Service? I would also like to ask the Prime Minister which group he thinks led the chorus of boos. Was it the New Right? Was it the Australian Council of Trade Unions, was it the Socialist Left. Could it have been the pensioners, the ethnic community, Bob Ansett? I suppose that there were a few small businessmen, farmers and middle-class Australians in the crowd also.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I must profess some surprise at hearing this reaction from the people who thought so highly of the Prime Minister, I predict that there will be even more surprises for him on or after 1 November, the date of the Queensland State election. The Prime Minister's demise as the folk hero of our nation could well be seen as taking place in the period from that last week in September to 1 November. His Party's demise as a force, if it can be called that, in Queensland will be marked as occurring on 1 November 1986.
I draw the attention of the Parliament to the Labor Party's advertisement in today's Courier-Mail, which went to print yesterday. Referring to Queensland, it said:
What is that record?
A record of the highest unemployment in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—The honourable member does not know what he is talking about. He is a dickhead.
— Order! The honourable member for Groom will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw it, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin, released at 11.30 this morning, shows that Queensland has not got the highest unemployment. That distinction belongs to South Australia so the Labor Party is issuing dishonest advertisements. We are going to expose its dishonesty and stupidity. I want to talk about some of the great things that the Queensland Government has done and will quote from the most current statistics, those issued at 11.30 today. First, let us look at that very important section of Australia, its youth. Youth unemployment in Queensland, at 18.8 per cent, is the lowest in Australia. What is the position in some of the socialist States? For New South Wales the figure is 21.5 per cent; for Victoria it is 19.5 per cent; and for South Australia it is 26.5 per cent. We do not want to see this dishonest form of advertising occurring. Queensland has the highest rate of youth employment in Australia. We have one of the highest participation rates, our rate closely following that of Victoria. No longer do we have the highest rate of unemployment in the country. That distinction belongs to the socialist State of South Australia. I throw these lies back into the teeth of the Labor Party of Queensland. The Courier-Mail should not accept this dishonest type of advertisement. Labor will not win the Queensland election by being dishonest. That is why it will not even have a cricket team in that State's Parliament after 1 November. In Queensland, unfortunately, 6,500 New Zealanders collect unemployment benefits. We have 9,900 unemployed who have come to Queensland from other States. If we subtract those figures from these most recent statistics we find that the real unemployment figure for Queensland is about 8 per cent. That brings the Queensland rate down to one of the lowest of the States. Only Victoria and the Northern Territory have lower rates.
—It refers to Queensland residents.

—The honourable member cannot even add up. He belongs to one of these gangs that put in dishonest advertisements. If we look at the statistics again we find that the Hawke Government is always parroting what it has been able to achieve in job growth. Let us give to the radio listeners of Australia the real statistics. Since the second Hawke Government came to office in December 1984, 31 per cent of all jobs created in Australia have been created in Queensland-80,900, compared with 51,000 in New South Wales and 51,200 in Victoria. I wish to compliment the Premier of Queensland on his recent policy speech. He is worried about jobs. He is honest. He is not worried about piffling away with dishonest advertisements such as the one to which I have referred.
—Saying that he is honest is a bit much.

—The lie is thrown in the teeth of the Minister by the Government's own statistics, released at 11.30 this morning. The Premier of Queensland is worried about employment. He knows what the Commonwealth statistics reveal. They do not come from one of his Departments: He has announced that he will make available $340m for capital works programs. That is designed to create jobs for unemployed people and allow employed people to continue in employment. The special program involving the expenditure of $600m for capital works is due to expire in December of this year. Let us relate this whole matter to ordinary working people. We of the National Party are interested in the working people. We just do not pay them lip-service. We want them to have jobs and the injection of $340m will provide an additional 23,000 man years of employment. That will further reduce the unemployment figures that the Bureau referred to in its release this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about some of the great things that have happened in Queensland and will continue to happen after the Labor Party has been shattered and destroyed on 1 November-a shattering and destruction which will be aided by dishonest advertising. I do not know, Madam Deputy Speaker, how you can belong to a party which yesterday placed in a newspaper an advertisement which was dishonest, as revealed by figures released by your own Government.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member for Groom is out of order in posing such a question to the Chair.

—I apologise, Madam Deputy Speaker. Let us talk about the economy of Queensland. It has the second highest annual population growth of all the States. Why do people want to come to Queensland? They want to come to Queensland because it has good government. Our population has increased by 1.62 per cent. It has the highest annual retail sales growth in the nation and a growth rate that is higher than the national average. Very importantly, it has an inflation rate that is lower than the national average. It has the highest employment growth of all the States of Australia. I have given the number of jobs that, since the second Hawke Government came to office, have been created in the State of Queensland as a result of positive action on the part of Queenslanders. Equally importantly, Queensland was the only State which, for the month of August, showed an increase in number of persons employed. Employment growth was 0.1 per cent, representing 1,300 jobs. Queensland was the only State in the Commonwealth to be rewarded with a positive employment growth rate. All of the other States lost jobs. Australia needs export income. Queensland is the leading export State in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by referring to tourism. My view on tourism is shared by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) who came to Queensland and said: `This State has the greatest growth of tourism'. He got up in this House and admitted that that was what he had said. It was the truth. The Queensland tourism industry continues to outperform all other States and enjoys an average growth rate of 8.5 per cent. This Federal Labor Minister came to Queensland and said: `Queensland is a great State for tourism'. He obviously implied that it was well governed, that people could come there secure in the knowledge that the rules were going to be made and were not going to be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has elapsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gorman Mr R.N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention to cover a couple of subjects in this grievance debate, should time allow, Madam Deputy Speaker. The first concerns the six replacement submarines that are to be constructed in Australia by Australians for the defence and protection of Australia. They will, of course, be manned by Australians. The remaining two contractors, who are now assessing the final plans, specifications and location for the construction of the submarines, would, I am sure, have no simple task in selecting a site. As we all know, each State has been most co-operative in its attitude to both of the companies and in offering greenfield sites and so on. It can be stated very clearly that New South Wales-the State of which I am one of the representatives in this House-
—And a good one!

—I thank the honourable member. My State has more to offer in all aspects associated with the construction of the submarines, such as a balanced, experienced, qualified work force with a proven track record in industrial relations. That is essential to the final outcome, the overall construction of the submarines. To emphasise the point, the figures for 1986-naturally the most recent available-show that the number of paid man hours lost through industrial issues represented less than 0.76 per cent. If one deducts those concerned with general industrial or national issues, over which the companies or their employees have little or no control, the percentage of lost paid man hours is reduced to around 0.19 per cent. That indicates the union movement's attitude to establishing a harmonious industrial relationship with employers. The bulk of the construction of the new submarines must go to New South Wales as we have the best sites available in Australia. To mention just a couple, we have Cockatoo Dock in Sydney Harbour and the facilities at the Newcastle Dockyards. Both offer the full facilities of sites that would be required for the construction of the submarines. Both sites have all the essential requirements and an abundant qualified labour force. Also, they are close to major suppliers of steel and specialised steel treatment. I refer to the facilities of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd at Newcastle and Port Kembla and, of course, the Bungi steel treatments works located adjacent to the Port Kembla steel works. I could go on and on about the associated industrial backup that exists in New South Wales. Many of the companies that will supply plant or equipment for the submarines are, luckily enough, established in my own electorate. One of the companies, Radcobellows, is a small company which produces flexible metal bellows and a full range of flexible tubing, a great deal of which will be required in the construction of the submarines. The company employs some 50 local people and has been established in the district for some three years.

SPEECH.PARA: The construction of the submarines will be a very good opportunity, one that Australian industry has been waiting for. It must be said that a construction program of this magnitude, at today's prices, involves the expenditure of around $2.4 billion. It will give the Australian engineering and manufacturing industry the impetus for which it has been waiting for for many years. One of the major sections of the submarine is referred to as the platform, and the construction of the submarine platforms will represent the first step of the ladder on which Australia's engineering and manufacturing industry will start climbing towards recognition as that of an industrial nation. The project will also set the stage for Australian industry to become a permanent partner in all future defence contracts. It must be stated at this point that the decision to build the six submarines in Australia represented a combined effort by the Minister for Defence, (Mr Beazley), the Caucus Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, the Defence Department and officers of the Navy such as Rear-Admiral Oscar Hughes and, of course, Captain Graham White. The full support of the Parliament has always been behind the project. I take this opportunity of quoting from a recent copy of the Pacific Defence Reporter:

Today, as we are aiming to turn the process around and involve the manufacturers in the engineering of the specifications enabling them to compete for contracts on the basis of information they fully comprehend, which hasn't been the case before. Further, the submarine project offers long-term contracts and long-term employment, in some cases possibly up to 30 years.

Already the Defence Department has created a new and good feeling among Australian contractors. Also, the overseas companies have displayed a real enthusiasm for involving Australian industry and hundreds of Australian companies are responding with equal enthusiasm.

If we can achieve (the Government goal) a 60 per cent Australian industry involvement in such a specialised and complicated project as submarine construction, we should easily attain 90 per cent participation down the road in related contracts, such as ship and tank construction, say.
The submarine project could well be the catalyst to bring about a significant in-country capability which we do not have now.
Such a capability is of supreme importance to Australia's security as in 15 years or so it could be a vital part of our defence should we be cut off from world supplies.
Let's not be asking ourselves then, `Why didn't we do this 15 years ago?' We're all fired up now. Let's not stuff it up.

The new construction submarine project has a problem not only from the point of view of industrial relations, which is most important, but also the point of view of a skilled work force. For expediency and effectiveness, skill formation will need to be developed on an existing infrastructure of skills, which principally only exist now in New South Wales. In order to build on what we have great emphasis will need to be placed on training. I refer to not only on the job training, but also apprenticeship and post-trade training. Management training must not be overlooked. This will require an investment in new or updated courses at principal training centres such as technical and further education colleges. This is a long term investment that should start now. No State government will commit money to training in TAFE colleges without knowing where the submarines will be built. While we procrastinate time is being lost which could be devoted to skilled development. The Government should not delay answering the question as to where it will build, and when making that decision should not confuse it with the old spectre of industrial relations. The success of the project, and long-term technology transfer for the good of the nation, will find its hub in training and skill information. My good friend John Tolley, who is a member of one of my branches, would be very scotty with me if I did not thank him for the help, assistance, and information that he has given me over the years, a great deal of which I have used from time to time at committee meetings.

The other item, Madam Deputy Speaker, that I must mention is the recent emergence of the New Right which should be named the Australian Fascist Party. All members of the Opposition benches must be told to stand up and be counted. Are they all to be a part of this new fascist party? If so, which one of them will grow the moustache so that we will at least know which one looks like the little hun that brought such inhumane action against mankind. Mark my words--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I rise on a point of order. There are inferences contained in this address which are quite beyond the pale, and I ask the honourable member to withdraw the inferences which he is casting about members on this side of the House.
—I would uphold that point of order and ask the honourable member to refrain from making such offensive imputations.

—If there is any offensive inference in what I have said I will withdraw it, Madam Deputy Speaker, but what was objected to was not stated. I said that honourable members opposite should indicate which of them would represent the little hun that brought such inhumane actions against mankind. Mark my words, Australian workers will not tolerate fascist treatment, so honourable members opposite should take heed. I thank the House for the time it has allotted to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, the grievance I bring to the House today is not in fact the flavour of the month, such as the fringe benefits tax; it is one about which I have had as yet very few complaints, unlike some of the Labor Party's other policies and so, in a sense, it is more of a potential grievance, but it is a grievance that will affect many of the people listening today, and as sure as night follows day, we will all be hearing a lot more about it. I refer, of course, to Labor's capital gains tax. That is the tax that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in 1983 said we would never have.

SPEECH.PARA: It has not had a lot of publicity because if you owned something before September 1985, it is exempt from the capital gains tax. The Government has put out the story that the family home, whenever purchased, is also exempt. The Taxation Office is already under siege because of the fringe benefits tax. There is no doubt that its staff are pulling their hair out on that one but have naturally been happy to keep the lid on it; and of course they have got an eye on this imputation tax, with which the Government has been struggling and which is to be foisted on us, apparently, very shortly. In the little booklet obtainable from the post offices the Taxation Office says: `In broad terms, the following capital gains are exempt from the tax: Profits you receive if you sell your home'.

That is the broadest definition of broad terms I have ever heard. I must say that I would have preferred, and I think it would have been more accurate, that the Tax Office had put out a pamphlet which said to Australian home owners: `When you are buying your next home beware of Labor's capital gains tax'. The other ploy to keep the lid on the capital gains tax is to tell everybody that it will bring in only $25m; that is the official figure. Honourable members would have to say that it does not sound much and in this year's Budget the obvious inference to be drawn is that it will bring in so little that the experts cannot even calculate such a negligible figure. If those people who are listening are lulled into a sense of false security, let me give them a warning about the application of Labor's new capital gains tax, because the reality is that many home owners will find themselves subject to it.

I am not talking about just a few isolated cases. I am talking about literally hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australian homeowners having to pay capital gains tax on the family home. Obviously, if the tax is going to be as bad as I am putting to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, the tax to be collected by the Government will have to be a lot more than $25m, which is the official estimate. I have another figure, and I must say it is from the best and most authoritative source currently in the land; and that is a problem which comes from the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating), the honourable member for Blaxland. What he says publicly is one thing-that is the $25m-but what he says privately to his colleagues is another.

In July 1986, before the ALP's National Conference in Hobart, he wrote to his colleagues boasting about Labor's 25 anti-business tax measures which would bring in $3 billion. In that list there was a figure for the capital gains tax. It was not $25m, it was six times that amount; it was $300m. That will please only those politicians of envy in the Labor Party and particularly the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who last year was pressing for a capital gains tax that would bring in $1.5 billion.

I have given the warning. Let me now give just some of the at least 15 examples where the family home will be subject to capital gains tax. Take, for example, an elderly person who goes into hospital for a hip replacement and, because of that operation, is required to be in hospital for an extended stay. It is true that as to the capital gains tax, if you leave your permanent place of residence for period-in other words, a `temporary absence', to use the language of the Act-you will have an exemption. But-and here comes the rub and red tape-you will get that exemption for the period of absence if, in the words of the law, and I quote:

The taxpayer notifies the Commissioner in writing not later than the date of lodgement of the taxpayer's return of income for the year of income in which the dwelling again became the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer, that the taxpayer elects that this sub-section is to apply in relation to the dwelling.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is arrant nonsense and you know it.

—That is in the Act and I would invite the honourable member to read it, because some of his constituents will be faced with Labor's capital gains tax. I would bet that in a population of 16 million, hardly anybody will know that fact, let alone understand it. The Prime Minister has not got a clue, you would have to agree, on the fringe benefits tax, and you can be sure he has not--
—Order! I call the honourable member to order and point out that he is not to cast personal reflections upon the Prime Minister.

—The Prime Minister has appeared, Madam Deputy Speaker, in the last few days to have had personal difficulties with the interpretation of the taxation Acts and the point I make is that I believe the same difficulties will fall upon the Prime Minister in regard to the interpretation of the capital gains tax. It is terrible that elderly people are required to understand taxes which this Government itself does not understand. How many elderly pensioners lodge tax returns, anyway? Why should the elderly in our community who have fought for their country, risked their lives and paid taxes all their lives, have to fill in forms just to protect themselves from Labor's capital gains tax? The fact is that thousands of pensioners are going to be caught up in the red tape and the entanglement of Labor's capital gains tax. That is only one example. Let me give another.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take the case of a young couple who are buying their first home and, as many young couples do, first buy a vacant block with a plan to construct a house on it; part of the Australian dream. Under the taxation legislation, if you buy a vacant block after 19 September 1985, build a house on it and that becomes your family home, you will not be up for Labor's capital gains tax. You will say that is fine and that is what you have been told; that is what you expected. But there are two catches, Madam Deputy Speaker. Firstly, if it takes you longer than four years to get into the house from the date that you bought the block, for the period in excess of four years you will be up for capital gains tax. I think a lot of people will be paying a Labor capital gains tax just on that catch alone.

If that does not sound too bad to you-and I certainly would have to say that I do not understand why four years is such a magical figure-the second catch is considerably worse; because to claim the exemption the house has to become as soon as practicable-whatever that means, and perhaps you cannot take a holiday before you move in, but leaving that aside-after the dwelling was erected and continues to be the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer for those purposes for not less than 12 months. In other words, when you have built your family home and you move into it, you will get the exemption; but on the basis that you live in that house for 12 months.

What if you work for a bank? What if you work in the Defence Force for your country and the employer says to you, `You have got to move to Perth', or `You have got to move interstate' and for that reason, which is beyond your control, you have got to leave your house that you have just built within 12 months? The ramification of that under Labor's capital gains tax is that that young couple will pay a tax on the family home.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish and you know it.

—There is no rubbish about it. The honourable member ought to read it because people in his electorate will not be voting for him when they find out that his Government's tax has introduced a liability for capital gains tax on the family home. Quite frankly, Madam Deputy Speaker, this Government gives with one hand and talks about supporting young people moving into family homes, but on the other hand it has its hands in the pockets of ordinary Australian taxpayers and home owners and is ripping into them with capital gains tax. In my electorate there are many other examples. I will give just one: If you buy a property in excess of two hectares-in other words, if you buy a 10-acre block-the excess over two hectares will be subject to capital gains tax. Is that a fair thing in a country which cherishes home ownership? I can tell honourable members it is not in my electorate, where people like to get out into the country and have a 10-acre block and I do not see why they should pay the penalty of a capital gains tax.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise as a grievance what I consider to be a most important problem facing Australia. But before I do I want to touch on some of the things that have been alluded to by members of the Opposition. The hyperbole that comes from that side continues to amaze me. The honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) talked about the growth in Queensland. He then said; `The growth in Queensland since the advent of the Hawke Government has been very substantial'. Of course it has. The Hawke Government planned it that way, because things were depressed in Queensland and we put a special emphasis in there. He then spoke of tourism in Queensland. It is true that Queensland, particularly along the coast, is very spectacular; it is a beautiful State.

SPEECH.PARA: This is hardly thanks to Joh. The country was always beautiful; it is obviously close to a very large tourist pool and it is bound to be the State with the greatest tourist attraction. It also has very good weather, hardly something which Joh can take credit for. Then the honourable member talked about dishonest advertising. For years and years we have seen the rorts pulled by the Liberal and National parties at election time. Everyone will remember the fistful of dollars they promised in advertising campaigns. I was talking to a sports journalist this morning about an obscure code of football apparently played in some parts of Australia-rugby. He was saying that Wally Lewis, the captain of the Kangaroos currently touring the world to represent Australia, was recently used by the National Party in an advertisement, without his consent, without his consultation.

The journalist told me that Wally Lewis is outraged at this dishonesty and deception and he has sought to have the advertisement withdrawn; he has totally repudiated it. The journalist to whom I spoke was very hot under the collar about this and he assured me that Wally Lewis is absolutely outraged. What could be more deceitful? What could be more dishonest or disreputable than simply to take a person's name while he is out of this country, serving his country, trying to raise the status of this country, and to use him in this very tawdry fashion? These people come in here and talk about dishonest advertising.

Madam Deputy Speaker, other things were alluded to, including a reference to capital gains tax by the very forgettable honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). Capital gains tax in Australia is a very equitable tax. It is a tax payable only on the real profit. Any capital gain has excluded from it inflationary gains, so it is a tax applied only to the real profit. It is interesting to note that since the advent of the capital gains tax, the stock market in this country has boomed. Obviously the people out there are investing now. We have had to get people away from this syndrome of the land dealers and wheeler-dealers, the people with their shonky land deals and blocks of flats. We have to get people out there investing in Australian industry and investing in Australian intellectual drive.

The capital gains tax serves a very useful purpose, but it should not be seen in isolation. It was this Government that gave to industry, after 40 years of pleading from industry, imputation. This means that the dividends from shares will now not be taxed in the hands of the shareholder. Industry and commerce had been asking for it for 40 years, but it was never acceded to by the Liberal Government. It was given by this Government.

Further, this Government allowed companies to write off losses incurred in one company against the profits of another wholly-owned company, something else that industry has been seeking for many years. This Government gave those incentives to industry. This has enabled mining and exploration to go ahead in leaps and bounds. It was the initiative of this Government and these packages must not be seen in isolation. It is quite dishonest for these people to come into the House and make unjustified claims. Claims made by the forgettable honourable member for Flinders about the impact of the capital gains tax are so much hyperbole and nonsense and he knows it. The shameful thing is that he knows that he is not telling the truth.

I want to return to the real problem facing Australia and it is not the very poor performance and the fearmongering of the Liberal Party, particularly of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). The real problem facing this nation is the growing dichotomy between city and country. There was a time when Australia was a united country. The history of Australia is that everyone has always lived in the cities, but there was a time when people in the country had a very good association with people in the city and everyone in the city knew someone from the bush. That has gone, very largely as a result of 40 years of the policies of the Liberal Party, particularly because of the Menzies myth; and it has gone also because of the other myth, institutionalised by both political parties, the myth of multiculturalism.

Madam Deputy Speaker, this is not a multicultural country; this is the most Anglo-Celtic country in the world. While we have-I applaud it-a measure of the cosmopolitan about our cities, the fact remains that this is overwhelmingly an Anglo-Celtic country. The Anglo-Celtic culture is a most generous and encompassing culture. I get rather concerned when I think about the impending takeover of the Special Broadcasting Service by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. One of the reasons for this, is that both political parties-and, of course, it was institutionalised by honourable members opposite-believe in the myth of an ethnic vote. This is the most degrading thing I have come across.

There are people in the Parliament, in the system, who believe that one has to get on-side only a few chosen ethnics and all the rest would follow like sheep. This is very degrading to ethnics and I certainly reject it. I can tell honourable members that it is rejected by the large number of ethnics that I have in my electorate. One of the things that we have to face in this country is the effects of immigration. We have an immigration policy today that this Government inherited.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with Standing Order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

—I refer the Prime Minister to his emphatic comment on the Carleton-Walsh Report last night that no concessions would be made on school fees in the review of the fringe benefits tax. Does this mean that free or discounted school fees for the child of a member of the clergy who teaches and lives at a church school will be subject to fringe benefits tax and that the religious institution will be forced to pay that tax? Is this an intended or unintended consequence of the fringe benefits tax?
—Dear, oh, dear!
—Enjoy yourself and answer the question.

—I am enjoying this very much. The discomfiture of Opposition members is something beautiful to behold. I have nothing to add to the answers that I have given already. I have indicated that there will be a review of the sort that I have talked about. If anyone wishes to bring forward anything through the consultative process in which we will engage, he will be able to do so.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of recent reforms to the United States tax system? Does the Prime Minister consider that the US reforms could provide a model for future changes in the taxation system is Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Canberra for her question. By way of preface I shall make some observations on the American tax reforms--

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: The honourable member for Canberra asked `Does the Prime Minister consider'-I quote her exact words. That is clearly asking for an opinion from the Prime Minister in relation to a matter which is not directly within his jurisdiction.
—I think that the honourable member for Canberra is asking for the matter to be transposed as part of the responsibility of the Prime Minister's portfolio.

—I preface my observations about the American tax reform proposals by saying that the sweeping reform of the Australian taxation system which has been brought in by my Government will produce, as is increasingly recognised, a fairer and more efficient tax system. It is one that will mean that for the first time the friends of the Opposition, the wealthy tax dodgers, will have to pay their full and fair share of tax, which they have been able to avoid under the processes and practices allowed by our predecessors. The top marginal tax rate will be reduced from the 60c bequeathed to the Australian people by Treasurer Howard to 49c. There was all the talk in the world about using the tax system to create incentives. Opposition members were full of rhetoric but decidedly short on achievement. The tax reform will be achieved in two cuts, one in December and one in July next year. The cuts will give the average worker relief of about $12 a week. We have taken the initiative to introduce a sweeping and effective tax reform and there is no need for this Australian Government to look to the American reform as a model for Australia. It is interesting to observe that the Leader of the Opposition, a paragon of virtue when it comes to tax reform, said on 29 September:

ANSWER.PARA: I'm very attracted to what Reagan has done. What Reagan is doing is being examined very closely as part of developing our own tax policy.

The Opposition's tax policy is like Halley's Comet-it is necessary to wait a hell of a long time before seeing it. The Leader of the Opposition is very attracted to the American tax reform, which has been designed by the American Administration for circumstances which it regards as appropriate to that country. I shall not comment on whether what it has done is or is not appropriate in the circumstances of that nation. It is interesting that the Leader of the Opposition says that he finds the American model attractive for Australia, and I suggest that we consider a few of the features of the reported American tax system that the Leader of the Opposition says he finds so appealing.

One of the features of the American tax reform is a rise in tax payments by American companies of the order of 25 per cent. There is to be a 25 per cent increase in the tax burden on American companies. This will be brought about, basically, by a massive crackdown on business perks and the elimination of many other business deductions. So the Leader of the Opposition finds attractive a 25 per cent increase in the tax burden on companies that is to be brought about by wiping out so many of their perks.

In addition to the Federal income tax impost in the United States, there is a system of social security contributions as well as State and local income taxes. Let us consider capital gains tax, which the Leader of the Opposition finds very attractive. The United States tax reform includes a capital gains tax on nominal gains at the relevant marginal tax rate. In other words, the system that the Leader of the Opposition puts on a pedestal has within it a 25 per cent increase in the tax that is paid by companies and a retrospective capital gains tax on the full nominal gain, compared with the fair and efficient capital gains tax that we have. As on every tax issue, the Leader of the Opposition will not come clean on what his position is. That is true of capital gains tax. On 29 August 1984 he said:
I think I was asked at the last National Press Club luncheon the same question by Max Walsh and I said then that there are arguments within a total restructuring of the system for what you have said.

In other words, the honourable member was saying in 1984 that there are arguments for a capital gains tax. When he became Leader of the Opposition, however, he retracted and said: `No, no capital gains tax'. The honourable gentleman has now done another twist and turn and he supports the American system, which has a severe and retrospective capital gains tax element.

The Opposition simply does not know what it is saying. On the one hand, it is saying that there should be no capital gains tax. On the other, it is saying that it will have such a system. The only honest statement on tax which has come from the Opposition in recent times is the statement made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, when he said frankly that school fees, cheap loans and Mercedes-Benz company cars are obviously perks which should be taxed. That is the only honest statement on tax that has come from the Opposition, and the Deputy Leader of the National Party, for his pains in being honest-something that is now a crime in the Opposition-has been gagged by the opportunistic Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Acting Treasurer aware that many small businesses in the tourism industry are forced to become incorporated in order to obtain operating finance? Is he aware also that the shareholders and directors of such small companies often comprise a husband and wife who actually live on the tourist premises-for example, a motel? Is the Minister further aware that the Australian Taxation Office has advised that these people-for example, those who live in a motel-will have to pay fringe benefits tax on their own home and meals? Is this an intended or unintended consequence of the fringe benefits tax?

—I am aware that much of what the honourable member has put in his question is a fact. I am also aware that the Government, in bringing down this eminiently fair fringe benefits tax, is not only following principle in the design of the tax but also it manifestly going to be following fairness in the way that tax is administered. That is why, as the Prime Minister has announced and as I have alluded to on previous occasions, we are reviewing the imposition, in the light of all the information that has come to light in the past couple of months, at least since 1 July last. The facts as they have been outlined to the House by the honourable member will be put before the review committee, and if there are unintended consequences, they will be addressed.

—I address my question to the Special Minister of State. I preface it by saying that I hope that he will not take it lightheartedly and simply answer `So what?'. Can the Minister advise honourable members whether the use of a person's photograph in an election advertisement, without that person's permission, would be permitted under the Commonwealth Electoral Act, for which the Minister is responsible?
—It's his birthday.

—The Prime Minister has drawn to my attention the fact that I did not do that which was essential when I rose to my feet at first and wish the Minister, on behalf of all honourable members, a very happy birthday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some good news for the Opposition. I shall do only a further six terms as Opposition business manager-as Government business manager.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable members ask the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations why I got it mixed up, they will be able to explain. They should take no pride in what they did to me last night.
—We will have you as a penmate, Mick.

—I shall listen to that Coonabarabran radio station all the time. The interviews that the honourable member does up there are pretty good. One interview a week will do for a while. In answer to the honourable member for Bowman, the advice that I have received is that no provision in the Commonwealth Electoral Act would inhibit such advertising. However, it would seem that there are civil remedies available to people whose name or photograph is used either against their wishes or without their permission. I understand-this may be of some interest to the Queensland Premier-that there could be appropriate instances for defamation. If Wally Lewis wants a bit of good defamation, there might be 400,000 bucks up there on which he can get his hands.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand, from the interview given by Mrs Lewis this morning, that Mr and Mrs Lewis have made clear the views they hold about the use by the National Party of the captain of the Australian rugby league team in the National Party advertisements. In answer to questions put to her in an interview this morning, Mrs Lewis said:
Wally is away overseas. He can't defend himself, so they shouldn't have used it. Our views on the whole matter-we just don't want it used.
She was asked:
Are you angry about this?
She replied:
Yes, we really are.
The journalist continued:
Wally has been known to say favourable things about the Labor Party previously, hasn't he?
Mrs Lewis replied:
Yes, that's probably due to me. I'm a very Labor woman, but that's beside the point. We just don't want him involved in any political fights at the moment. They can use someone else.
Mr Lewis's father-in-law used more colourful language. He said that he would rather pull the heads off his racing pigeons than do anything favourable for the National Party.

As I pointed out yesterday, as to events in Queensland, such as the purchase of a property by the Queensland Premier whereby, all of a sudden, there was a new school, a new police station, a new bitumen road, a new dam and a new bridge-so what? Four hundred thousand dollars-so what? I can tell honourable members something else that the National Party has on the Labor Party. If one goes to one of Joh's dinners one has to pay 25,000 bucks. There is a bit of goodwill in that. As the Leader of the Liberal Party and the Leader of the Labor Party have said, after the elections there will be a decent electoral system brought into Queensland. I believe that Queensland should bring in some of the laws that we have instituted-such as a register of political donations, so that we can see what is going on in Queensland. There is no doubt that the result of that $400,000 defamation case between the Bond Corporation and Joh Bjelke-Petersen throws light on the way in which business is done in Queensland. If it is done in this case, it must be done in many other cases. People who are paying $25,000 to go to those dinners in Queensland must also be buying a bit of goodwill for their businesses in Queensland. It is about time that this was exposed. It is great that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has reopened its hearings. We shall hear a lot more about what has been going on in Queensland, the way things have been done, and the way companies have been helped. There is absolutely no doubt in the mind of anyone connected with the law that that $400,000 is absolutely phoney in terms of what was said on the television station and what the Queensland Premier could have expected to get out of that case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go and say it outside.

—I will say it outside when I am defeated for Port Adelaide, and that will be a long time. We will hear a lot more about this. It is pleasing that the Federal Parliament will be sitting right up until the date of the Queensland elections, because we should have a little discussion on this every day.
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister.
—So what?

—With a bit of luck we might get an answer. I refer the Prime Minister to his comments last night on the Willesee program that `there's the few who rorted the system'. If that statement is correct, why did the Prime Minister introduce legislation that taxes religions, charities, the disabled, sporting clubs, the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the National Trust, governments, local councils, struggling farmers, small businesses and many other individuals and groups that clearly were not rorting the system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the best way I can answer the honourable member is to indicate, again, the breadth of support that there is for the tax, and outline the necessary implication.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Hollow laughter is no substitute for a principled policy. That is all Opposition members can do. In an answer I gave yesterday, I referred to the broad body of support contained in the submission that was presented to me by Premier Burke. I remind the House of the organisations-the Primary Industry Association of WA (Inc), the Australian Mines and Metals Association (Inc), the Chamber of Mines of WA (Inc), the Confederation of Western Australian Industry (Inc), the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (Inc), and the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of WA (Inc). They all said that the taxation of fringe benefits was a necessary part of any rational personal income taxation system. That is why the Australian Financial Review, in its editorial of 12 August, said:

ANSWER.PARA: The fringe benefit tax is a method of reducing tax evasion, as part of a broad tax reform aimed at producing more equity and fewer rorts, and improving incentive for effort by getting the top marginal income tax rate down below 50 per cent.
It observed:
The Liberal Party, in promising to remove this and other taxes, is falling into such hypocrisy.

The position of members of the Opposition is one of total hypocrisy. Their leader says the tax is wrong. It will be removed not only in part but lock, stock and barrel. The tax is wrong in principle. Members opposite can luxuriate for the time being in that position. They will pay a very heavy penalty for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in his capacity as Acting Treasurer. In deciding to apply a fringe benefits tax, what are some of the considerations the Government took into account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to the honourable member for giving me this opportunity. There were three options before the Government: One was what I will call the haemorrhaging option. That option has now been adopted most recently by the Leader of the Opposition and, it would seem, by the Leader of the National Party of Australia. In fact, they have had so many positions that it reminds me of the Karma Sutra. But the most recent position they have had is the haemorrhaging position where tax to the extent of $700m is being haemorrhaged to revenue. The Government decided that that could not continue because it would be an unprincipled position.

ANSWER.PARA: There were two further options before the Government. The second could be called the Opposition's secret fringe benefits tax option and then there is the one which the Government has adopted. The secret fringe benefits tax option has been betrayed by certain front bench members when they talked about section 26 (e). The secret system is one where the employers would have to report on the benefits in kind that are given to employees; they would have to disclose at the end of the financial year the value of the benefits given; they would have to report each pay day on the amount of benefit for each member of their staff; and they would have to then put up with the fact that many of their staff members could not afford the tax when it was converted from kind into cash. In short, the secret option gives employers much more paperwork than under the alternative, but gives the employees the obligation to pay this tax. There would be much more work for employers and much more work for the administration, resulting in hundreds, indeed thousands, more tax officers.
The third option, which was the one adopted by the Government, namely, the fringe benefit tax route, is clearly, unassailably, the most principled and the best administrative way to go.
Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —The hollow laughs opposite betray the fact that there is a difficult settling in period. There is always a difficult settling in period for any new tax. I remind the House of the similar hollow laughs we had three years ago when we were bedding down the prescribed payments system.
—In the building industry.

—In the building industry, yes. Who hears of it today? It is recognised as a fair system. We are addressing the teething problems in this bedding down period. We have already made reference in Question Time to the review that is taking place. That review will be completed by 28 October, but I draw the House's attention to the fact that as things presently stand employers attracting the fringe benefits tax liability must lodge their first instalment declaration and tax payment with the Taxation Office by 28 October. The Commissioner of Taxation has already advised tax agents that no penalties will attach to payments received from tax agents before 28 November where half of the tax agents returns are provided by 28 October.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members will understand that most people who are obliged to pay fringe benefits tax are employers and businesses and they will have tax agents. That is a very important qualification to note. There is already an extension of one month provided in a large number of cases which go through tax agents. In addition, in view of the Government's review of the fringe benefits tax, I inform the House that the Commissioner of Taxation has decided to grant a blanket extension for all fringe benefits taxpayers of two weeks, including an additional two weeks for tax agents, with a further extension in the case of demonstrated difficulty. The Commission of Taxation will shortly issue a Press release confirming the details of this extension. As I have said, the fringe benefits tax is a principled one and a good one in design. In imposing it administratively we will make sure that equity and fairness will prevail both in the design and in the imposition of the tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the review of the application and administration of the fringe benefits tax. I ask the honourable gentleman: Who will take charge of this review? What organisations will be asked to make submissions? How does one get to be a participant in the review? Will the report on the review be made public? When will an announcement be made? Will and changes be retrospective or operate from the date of change? Finally, will the review include changes in the area relating to motor vehicles as urged this morning by the South Australian Premier, Mr Bannon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer will have the primary responsibilities-

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —This mob will laugh at anything. The Treasurer will have the responsibilities for the undertaking of this review, as it will be the Treasurer who presents the submission to the Cabinet. The details of the consultative process are being finalised. I have had discussions with the Treasurer by telephone and the process will be finalised in discussions between the Treasurer and me on his return on Monday of next week.
—Can the Minister for Health inform the House as to the street level reach of the national campaign against drug abuse in New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question, particularly as it gives me an opportunity to comment on the latest inanities of the coalition drugs task force which claims that the street reach of the drug campaign in New South Wales is inadequate. I must say in the not easy task of trying to co-ordinate the national strategy against drug abuse in this country that the activities of the coalition drug task force has added an element of light relief. Its first survey was ridiculed on the back pages of the newspapers. I am certain that this second survey will be treated in the same way. The coalition drug task force is now claiming that of 71 organisations surveyed in New South Wales only six had benefited financially from the Government's drug campaign in 1985-86. Of those 71 organisations named, I am informed by the Government of New South Wales, which is responsible for the direct imbursement, not six, but 55 of those 71 gained additional moneys in 1985-86. Indeed, for those 55 organisations, the joint extra funding was $2,740,000.

ANSWER.PARA: Let met give some examples of what is contained in the survey. For Hunter Life Education, the survey says there is nothing new; the fact is that there is $75,000 which is new. For We Help Ourselves, the survey says nothing new; the fact is that there is $104,000 which is new. For Westmount Co-op, Katoomba, the survey said nothing new; the fact is that there is $87,000 which is new. For the Wayack Committee, the survey says nothing new; the fact is that there is $28,000 which is new. For the Buttery Bangalow, the survey says nothing new, but there is $39,000 which is new. For DC24 Drug Centre, Ringwood, according to the survey there is nothing new; but the fact is that there is $51,000 which is new. For Group Recovery Organisation of the World Australia, the survey says nothing new; but there is $33,000 in fact. For the Dubbo Drug and Alcohol Committee, there is nothing new according to the survey; in fact there is $22,000 which is new. The list goes on and on and the facts simply refute the claims made in the survey. Additionally, another 33 community and government agencies not mentioned in the coalition's survey, and not surveyed, got an extra $510,000 new money under the cost shared program.

I am ready to concede that although most of these inaccuracies are the result of the shabby survey techniques of this coalition drug task force, it may be that in some case that, as the State Government is responsible for the direct payment of those moneys, these amounts may not always have been recognised as new moneys. We are writing to ensure that the State Government has these moneys properly identified, but there is no doubt that it is the shabbiness of the survey that explains most of those inaccuracies. To the Leader of the Opposition, whom I believe in these matters is a responsible person, I say: This Government will welcome constructive comment on the work of this campaign. But this destructive, unprincipled, inaccurate type of comment does the Opposition no good-let that be made clear-nor, of course, does it do any good for the campaign throughout this country. In fact, it is an insult to the thousands of people working throughout this country at the street level to make this campaign a success. The most useful thing that the Leader of the Opposition could do to contribute to the success of the drug campaign in this country is to wind up his useless coalition task force.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I remind him that it took a full eight months following the Treasurer's statement in September last year for the Government to produce the 139-page Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, with its 176-page explanatory memorandum, and that over the last five months the Commissioner of Taxation has issued 115 pages of rules on the tax. How, then, is it going to be possible to conduct a complete review of the tax, decide the necessary changes, prepare legislation and draw up the machinery for implementation in time for the Prime Minister's promised announcement to occur in less than three weeks time?

—As distinct from the Opposition, this Government is fair dinkum about the matter of tax reform. We have not been waiting for my announcement for this work to be done. As I have indicated, the Treasurer had already said in August that some amendments would be introduced. There has been an on-going monitoring of the situation as I have said so many times now that I would have thought that it would have at least penetrated the thickness of the minds of the Opposition. The work has been going on for a considerable time and we believe, with the application of the resources of government and the co-operation of those whom we will be consulting, that the timetable I have indicated will be able to be met.

—I ask whether the Minister for Health is aware of media and medical reports concerning the carcinogenic properties of smokeless tobacco and the fact that this very dangerous product is being increasingly imported into Australia and promoted among young kids. What action does the Government propose to take in respect of this public health issue?

—I take the opportunity to point out that the honourable member for Hughes is one of the most active defenders of consumers' interests in this House and has certainly been persistent in expressing his concerns about this issue. I think it can be said that there is now a general concern in the community about the effects of both smokeless tobacco and oral snuff. The medical evidence identifying the relationship between the incidence of oral cancer and oral snuff and smokeless tobacco is now overwhelming. In June 1986, a National Health and Medical Research Council committee recommended that smokeless tobacco be added to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. Unfortunately, at that time it did not deal with snuff and I have asked that it give immediate consideration to snuff as well. A reworked proposal for banning the import of both smokeless tobacco and snuff will be put before the NHMRC at its next meeting. In addition, the concerns of the States have also been reflected, in that at the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council meeting last week there was support across the board for the banning of smokeless tobacco products nationally and for the prohibition of imports. This recommendation will be on the agenda of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy when it meets at the beginning of November. I have already informed Senator Button that I will act on the NHMRC recommendation as soon as it reaches me in its final form and will request that smokeless tobacco products be banned under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. I also understand that the promotion of oral snuff is occurring in Australia on a low scale. It is packed in a very innocuous fashion and I will be recommending national action both to my State colleagues and to my Federal ministerial colleagues on that matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment wrote to the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy on 16 September concerning the future status of Kakadu stage 2, saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Should the Commonwealth decide to pursue World Heritage listing of the former Stage 2 area `the Northern Territory Government' will be consulted in accordance with the CONCOM agreement prior to any approach being made to the World Heritage secretariat in Paris.

In view of this very clear commitment, why did the Minister issue, on the same day, a joint Press statement with the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, which stated that immediate steps should be taken to nominate stage 2 of the park for inclusion on the World Heritage list? Will the Minister confirm that no further consultations took place with the Northern Territory Government before the submission was sent to Paris, I understand, on the following day, 17 September? If so, why did he deliberately lie to the Northern Territory Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will withdraw that remark.
—Madam Speaker, I have his letter here, and what he said in the letter and what he has done are opposites.
—The honourable member will withdraw.
—I will withdraw and replace that word with the words `grossly mislead'.
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw that also.
—With due respect, Madam Speaker, `mislead' is an acceptable parliamentary term.
—The word `mislead' is acceptable; the word `grossly' we will leave out.

—To fully understand the implications of the honourable member's question, one needs to go back to the original nomination of Kakadu for World Heritage listing, when it was made clear to the World Heritage Committee that this was just the first part of the process and that it was intended by the previous Government that Kakadu stage 2 would eventually become part of the park and would be an addition to the World Heritage listing, as will, eventually, Kakadu stage 3. It is quite different from other newer, fresher nominations which may occur, such as the one we are now considering, that is, Uluru National Park, which I discussed with Mr Hatton in my recent visit to the Northern Territory and which, incidentally, he strongly supported. However, in this particular case it was intended to be merely an addition to the existing park.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to comments made by the Premier of Victoria alleging bias to New South Wales in appointments to Australia Council boards and the distribution of grants to writers resident in New South Wales? Are Mr Cain's remarks in relation to the Minister's portfolio accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for asking this question 24 hours too early. I must say that some creative work in the arts has been done by the Premier; who can, if he wishes, have the right of reply. According to the Premier, one would have to be stupid or cupid to believe that Sydney writers do not enjoy an unfair advantage over Melbourne writers. I am quoting from a Fairfax Press editorial, if the Prime Minister does not mind.
—That is all right.
—The Premier is concerned that four of the seven members of the Literature Board come from New South Wales. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: It irks me all the more because last year that Board awarded 50 grants to New South Wales writers and 18 to Victoria.
The excellent editorial states:
There are statistics, and there are Mr Cain's statistics. Some of the ``NSW'' grants, for instance, are for writers who used to live in Melbourne.

What is happening is that very talented writers from Melbourne now gravitate to Sydney. They are now leaving St Petersburg and coming to Tinsel Town. I give some examples: David Williamson, who has a holiday home in my electorate, and Barry Oakley. Of course, more recently, the very talented Phillip Adams has come to Sydney. There is not a great deal that we can do about this. Unfortunately, artists tend to congregate in the areas of artistic activity. Like it or not, that is now occurring in Sydney. We cannot provide grants on a per capita basis; the money has to go where the talent is. To take that logic a step further, what would happen if all artistic grants were allocated on a per capita basis? We would have to provide every single town in Australia with a grant based on its population. The situation now is that people gravitate to certain areas. The grants are based on artistic merit, not on where those artists are located. I am sorry that the Premier cannot have the opportunity to reply, but I am sure that I will hear from him later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Attorney-General confirm that a Queen's Counsel, Mr Chester Porter, was sought by the Director of Public Prosecutions to give an independent legal opinion on whether a Mr Taillon should have been charged with the illegal importation of narcotics? Does the Attorney-General recall that Mr Taillon was allowed to go free, having been caught in Australia with some $300,000 worth of narcotics in his possession, when a loophole was discovered in our laws? Does the Attorney-General remember that nearly a year ago he promised an urgent review of this glaring anomaly-and since then nothing has happened? Finally, will the Attorney-General clear up this matter by giving the House details of what is contained in the legal opinion and informing us when legislation to close this loophole will be brought into the House?

—The information given by the honourable member is not correct in the sense that the question of Mr Taillon not being prosecuted was a decision made by the Director of Public Prosecutions because he took the view that the issue of possession and importation did not apply in that case. It was alleged that there was some drug in the baggage allegedly belonging to Mr Taillon but not in his possession. Because of the public interest following the Director's decision, I obtained an opinion from Mr Chester Porter. I had already indicated in answer to a question in the House that I would have the matter investigated from the point of view of the potency of the law in respect of both importation and possession. I am pleased to say that in that opinion Mr Chester Porter said that the prosecution could have gone ahead on the basis that it related to importation but that perhaps there was some doubt on the issue of possession. That was the sort of variation in evidence. Because the importation aspect is not a matter within my portfolio but one for the Australian Customs Service, that opinion and advice has been forwarded to my ministerial colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. I understand that arrangements are now in place to amend the Act to ensure that, whether a case relates to importation and/or possession, prosecutions can be launched.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The Minister may proceed.

—On 19 August, in answering a question, I said that Mr Justice Murphy has made it clear to me that he had had discussions with his fellow judges and there was never any suggestion that he should not sit with them. I also said that that statement was of some surprise to me in view of other information given to me at that time. In this morning's Canberra Times, there is an article by Mr Jack Waterford headed `Attorneys-General calling senior judges liars'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the second time in months an Attorney-General has publicly called the most senior judge in his jurisdiction a liar.

That obviously suggests that I had said that of the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia. No such statement was ever made by me, nor could it ever be imputed to me. The article further states:
The Gibbs-Bowen affair has already been well chronicled . . .

As far as I am aware, it has not been chronicled anywhere. The only matters that the Press has been able to report have been some Press statements issued by either Mr Justice Murphy or the Chief Justice, I want to make it clear that at no stage was there any suggestion that I called the Chief Justice a liar. Such a statement is false and malicious and could cause damage to the Court, to the Chief Justice and to me. We all hold the High Court in the highest esteem. The matters that may have transpired between the judges are something that they alone know about; they are not matters for comment by me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The night before last in the adjournment debate I addressed the House on the issue of a grant of $72,500 from the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies for the preparation of a political biography on the life of Mr Charles Perkins, Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The Age of 9 October and also the Sydney Morning Herald of the same date subsequently carried accounts of my remarks. I refer specifically to comments in the Age, one of which read:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal of the institute, Mr Warwick Dix, said no one on the council had opposed the grant at the meeting, although a couple of members had said that other research applications should have higher priority.

The implication of that is that I did not oppose the grant. PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.
Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
