PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that The House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Post Office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Beale,Mr Bilney,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Cobb,Mr Drummond,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker,Mr Milton,Mr Nehl,Mr Ruddock and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Ms McHugh,Mr Milton,Mr Scott and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware that it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum.''
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker,Mr Reith and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
Reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer,Mr Hawker and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7 per cent in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5 per cent of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5 per cent of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941);
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That families have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of their net disposable income through:
Failure to index family allowances-resulting in a 50 per cent loss in their real value since 1976
Abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18-even those still at school
Failure to increase the spouse rebate since 1982
Discriminatory taxation system-which penalizes single income families.
Recognising the cost benefit to taxpayers when the intact family unit itself delivers essential care to the extended family.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take immediate action to:
Restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them to cover future price rises
Introduce optional income-splitting for taxation purposes
Retain the spouse rebate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Justice, Equity and Redistribution of Wealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia, hereby petition the Prime Minister as Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Government in Australia and humbly showeth that:

The voting public of Australia did in March 1983 and again in December 1984 vote as a majority for the election of a Labor Government who did claim to stand for social justice, equity and redistribution.
That the said voters sincerely believed that a contract was entered into in voting for a Labor Government with democratic socialist principles.

That there is an erosion of support for the pensioners, the unemployed, the aged, the sick and the working class of Australia, while the lot of the privileged class, the banks, the oil companies, and the money-changers continues to improve.

Your petitioners call on the Australian Labor Government to implement those policies and follow those principles of social justice, equity and redistribution which the majority of Australians voted for in 1983 and in 1984, and to adopt an immediate programme that will transfer the current economic burden to those better able to carry it.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax

1. That the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 is having a detrimental effect on the car industry generally in South Australia, and more particularly, on employment in that industry.

2. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 contains many anomalies, inconsistencies and mistakes in drafting and its administrative implementation is an unwarranted burden on Australian businesses and the Australian taxpayer.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject the Federal government cuts to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs and the axing of Multicultural Education Program and we request the restoration of funding to these programs.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth: That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent change in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act, refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act (as amended in 1985), and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations:
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in the renumeration packages:
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business:
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament House. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Maranoa electorate respectfully showeth that:
The current Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Pension: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
By drastically cutting E.S.L. funding, you have disadvantaged thousands of Australian children.

Not only will students with limited English face gross educational inequality, but the entire Australian community will feel the wider effect-through the resultant inability of some of its citizens to contribute effectively to Australian society.

On behalf of the children who will be directly affected, and the Australian community generally, we call on you to restore full funding for the general support element of the Commonwealth E.S.L. program.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth:
We most strongly oppose the use of the `Special Broadcasting Service' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

We are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on Radio 3EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
We respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.

Your petitioners therefore, strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

(1) A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
(2) The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until 6 August this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners wish that all medicines prescribed by a registered Medical Practitioner be made available free of charge by the Government to all pensioners for the following reasons:
1. The enormous cost of some drugs, including pain relieving ones, not at present on the `free list'.
2. That certain drugs essential for permanently disabled, such as epileptics are at present being charged for and therefore present a great financial burden to the pensioner.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will consider our wishes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: 1986-87 Budget
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we wish to protest at the cutbacks announced in the Federal Budget of August 1986. Large numbers of people live in poverty and many more are now moving in that direction. Gains in education, multi-culturalism, welfare and in many other areas that have been important to the Australian people are being eroded and in some cases totally destroyed. Members of the ethnic community have been hit twice as hard by the August budget. They experience the hardship of general economic policies as well as the severe cutbacks that affect services essential to developing equal opportunity and the promotion of multi-culturalism.

We therefore call upon the Federal Government to reconsider the economic direction which it is pursuing and develop economic policies that cater for the needs of all Australians. Specifically, such policies must include the following which are vital to the ethnic and general Australian community at large:
The Federal Government to undertake full responsibility to maintain and expand the ESL programme;
Retain the Human Rights Commission;
Retain the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs;
Reinstate funding to the education centres programme;
Maintain the autonomy of SBS Television and Ethnic Radio;
Maintain the branches of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Albury, Wollongong, Newcastle in NSW, as well as the other branches in Victoria and Queensland;
To not introduce Tertiary Education fees;
To maintain the Bill of Rights legislation.
Your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toowoomba Education Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the Toowoomba Education Centre, electors of the Division of Darling Downs shows that Federal Recurrent Funds to the Centre have been reduced and your petitioners therefore pray that the funding be retained at its present level.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows:

We wish to register our concern at the intention of the Commonwealth Health Department's proposal to drop essential medication from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Antihistamines, Pain Killers, Cough Mixtures and Angina treatments are essential medication in numerous chronic medical conditions. Deletion of these medications will cause long term suffering and disadvantage a large proportion of the community least able to afford the increased cost of these medicines after their deletion from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Those on old age Pensions, Repatriation Benefits, Concessional Benefits and others on low incomes will be particularly disadvantaged.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the Government does not proceed with its proposal.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the Capital Gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and wealth creation, has contributed to Australia's economic crisis and contains many anomalies.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately repeal the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Act 1986.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Pony Clubs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we the undersigned are totally opposed to the Government's policy to tax pony club income.
Your petitioners urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to allow tax exempt status for pony clubs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian Government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 Budget.

PETITION.TITLE: Jervis Bay
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives as assembled.

We, the undersigned concerned residents, visitors and holiday makers, reject the proposed military and industrial developments in Jervis Bay and support the conclusion of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation 1975 which found that Jervis Bay should be preserved for recreation and scientific reference purposes with sound management planning to safeguard the environment and retain the natural landscape and atmosphere. We also call for the area to be put on the Register of the National Estate, and an appropriate National Park and Marine Reserve System to be declared.

PETITION.TITLE: Namibian and South African Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Parliament of Australia. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The abhorrent, racist system of Apartheid prevents non-white children and youth in South Africa and Namibia from equal participation in education (official statistics given in the South African Parliament for 1980-81 showed the annual expenditure on education to be 1,000 rand per capita for whites as against less than 200 rand per capita for blacks);

Education inside South Africa and Namibia is so imbued with the ideology of apartheid that non-white students have rebelled against the `Bantu' education system, leading to many students being imprisoned, beaten and harassed by police;

Many children and youth have fled apartheid South Africa and Namibia to refugee camps run by the African National Congress of South Africa (ANC) and the South West African People's Organisation (SWAPO) of Namibia. In these refugee camps international aid provides primary and secondary education, but tertiary education in such circumstances is impractical;
The Australian Parliament has a bipartisan policy of opposition to Apartheid;
The provision of scholarships for tertiary study in Australia for students from these refugee camps is one of the most positive steps Australia can take towards a non-racist future for South Africa;
Community contributions to the Jim Gale Memorial African Scholarship Fund have reached over $13,000 in eight months, demonstrating the strong concern among Australians about this issue.
Your petitioners therefore pray and urge the Parliament of Australia to:
Provide one hundred scholarships annually for South African students to be selected from ANC refugee camps, to enable them to undertake tertiary studies in Australia;
Provide one hundred scholarships annually for Namibian students to be selected from SWAPO refugee camps, to enable them to undertake tertiary studies in Australia;
Join with the Jim Gale Memorial African Scholarship Fund to provide at least one scholarship each year in memory of Jim Gale;
Waive any visa charges which might otherwise attach to these students as overseas students.
Your humble petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Special Broadcasting Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

We the undersigned residents of Australia deplore the decision by the Federal Government to amalgamate the SBS with the ABC. At present there is no guarantee that the principles of multicultural broadcasting will be maintained at any level of the ABC administration. An independent and strong SBS should be retained. We humbly pray that you oppose the amalgamation of the SBS and ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is an urgent need to up-grade and extend the facilities at the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Provide the necessary capital funding for the Northern Rivers CAE to ensure North Coast students have access to a tertiary institution capable of providing them with the skills they will need to meet the challenges of the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business, anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
that the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
that the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television Services in Rural Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
(1) That in the past, because of their remoteness, citizens in rural areas have not been able to receive SBS (Multicultural) television through conventional means.
(2) That recently those citizens have been able to receive the SBS television service from the AUSSAT satellite by means of receive-only earth stations.
(3) Now express concern that by Government decision this service is to be terminated.
Your petitioners therefore urge that SBS television continue to be made available to citizens in rural areas of Australia by means of the AUSSAT 1 satellite and receive-only earth stations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and the Honourable members of the House of Representatives in the assembled parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.
We the humble petitioners at Gippsland Institute Student Union, in the Federal electorate of McMillan respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of an Administration Charge of $250 for higher education students in Appropriation Bill 1986-1987 (Volume-1, Page-98) is a regressive step for the Education system;
That the introduction of an Administration Charge will force students to withdraw from studies and thereby destroy the opportunity for them to complete their education;
That the Administration charge is a form of Tuition Fees and as such destroys the principle of free education for all;
We the humble petitioners hereby request you to amend the appropriation Bill 1986-1987, so that the system of free education for all students will continue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Sales to France
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell uranium to France, against ALP policy.
The French are still nuclear testing in the South Pacific, despite world wide protests. We therefore call on you to reverse the decision to sell uranium to France.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully sheweth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Child Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully request that the Federal Government take responsibility for existing and future funding of child care services and that such funding allocation be at such level to ensure the maintenance of quality child care. We further respectfully request that proper planning of services occur and that the Federal Government enter into formalised agreements with State and Local Governments to achieve this result.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bills were returned from the Senate without amendment:
Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1986
Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1986
Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1986

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION: EFFECT ON FARM AND SMALL BUSINESS SECTORS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage and high cost of the Government's tax regime on country Australia, especially the farm and small business sectors.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —No sector of the Australian community has been harder hit by the Government's mind-boggling tax policy than those who live in country areas of Australia-the farmers and small business people. It is also having an indirect effect on those people living in country towns and those who are seeking jobs. The Hawke Labor Government's tax policies are in shambles. Nothing highlights this disastrous situation more than the events of the past few weeks, particularly, the last few days, when the Government has had to admit, under Opposition pressure, that the fringe benefits tax is full of anomalies, inequities and uncertainties. Here we are three weeks away from `D' Day-the day that all employers are supposed to make their returns to the Taxation Commissioner under the fringe benefits tax legislation. Next week we will witness the spectacle of another mini-tax summit with representatives from employers, accountancy firms, and others who will be called together to try to help the Government to sort out its unbelievable mess.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in answer to questions this week, revealed his total lack of understanding-or that is what he has tried to convey to this Parliament-of the damage that the fringe benefits tax will do not only to the Australian farm sector and the small business sector, but also to charitable organisations, churches, bodies such as the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, sporting organisations, and those disabled and aged people employing in-house domiciliary assistance. In spite of the fact that the Government announced the fringe benefits tax on 19 September last year and introduced the legislation in May this year, it still has not been able to get its act together. How the hell does it expect the taxpayers of Australia-the employers and employees-to get their act together by 28 October. They have no chance. The Prime Minister, at a meeting with farmers in Canowindra earlier this year, gave an assurance to farmers that he would get the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to take whatever action was necessary to overcome the anomalies so far as farm workers' accommodation was concerned. On two occasions in the Parliament I asked the Prime Minister to honour the undertaking he gave to Canowindra farmers before the legislation was passed in the Senate. No action was taken.

Numerous representations were made to the Government bringing to its attention the anomalies and the inequities associated with this tax, but the Government has refused to listen. Those representations have come not only from our side of the House, but also from the Government's own side. They have come from farm organisations, industry organisations and other groups over the past few months. It is no good the Prime Minister or any other Minister saying in this place that they did not know that these problems were inherent in their legislation. How can the Government justify a situation whereby a small business proprietor or a farmer has been barraged with 139 pages of legislation, 167 pages of explanatory memorandum, two booklets of 69 pages, 14 rulings of 159 pages, pamphlets, Press releases and a video tape. No wonder Tom Burns, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, has called this legislation bureaucratic bull-you-know-what. He has used much stronger terms. Of course it is bureaucratic bulldust. Look at all these papers! They are all over the place. It is no wonder that people are chucking the things in the wastepaper basket. They are fed up to the teeth. There is not a farmer in the countryside who is employing labour who is not fed up to the teeth with this wretched rubbish which is coming across his ruddy desk. It is a mind-boggling, iniquitous, confusing tax. The Government has violated the fundamental requirements of any tax system-simplicity and equity.

How does the Government expect the employers of this country to comply with the requirements to make returns by 28 October when it has resorted to a mini-tax summit in a desperate attempt to come to grips with its own bureaucratic bungling? The Government should abolish this tax immediately. It should do so before that stubborn, headstrong, pigheaded Treasurer returns. If the Government is not prepared to abolish the tax, in fairness to the employers, employees, taxpayers generally, the Australian Taxation Office and indeed to itself as a government, it should defer the implementation date until 1 July next year or at least until 1 January. It is no good continuing with the administration of this tax at this time. It is nonsense to say that the Government is ready, the Taxation Office is ready and the Australian community is ready to comply with this incredible bureaucratic mess.

The events of the last few days have highlighted the worst example of government bungling to which the Australian people and taxpayers have been exposed. The tax policy is the consequence of a back room deal done by the Prime Minister with the Australian Council of Trade Unions in the closing hours of the now infamous National Taxation Summit held last year. The deal was done behind the Treasurer's back. As a consequence, the Australian people have had imposed upon them one of the worst, most complex, most confusing and most iniquitous tax systems yet introduced in this country. No tax in my memory has caused more anger or confusion. No wonder people throughout Australia claim that they will refuse to co-operate, refuse to fill in forms and refuse to pay the tax. Nothing highlights the concern more than the decision taken by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association in Sydney this week when it unanimously adopted a no-pay advice which is now being distributed to its 22,000 strong membership. That advice is: `Do not pay the tax'. That is civil disobedience, but these people have apparently been forced to take this action-forced by the bureaucratic bungling and the lack of answers from the Taxation Office that comply with answers given in regional offices. They are fed up to the teeth. The Government has saddled ordinary Australians with reams of time-consuming paper work, often to no purpose, making life more difficult in what are difficult economic circumstances for business today. The keeping of a log book for vehicles, the keeping of records on farms of stores and goods provided to employees is making decent, hardworking Australians little bureaucrats. I can think of no more Bolshevik action by any government in a Western democracy than the way in which our Government is trying to administer this tax.
Last night the Prime Minister on national television attempted to justify his fringe benefits tax about-face. I was amazed to hear him say:
Mr Keating indicated in fact a few weeks ago he would be bringing in some legislative changes. He has already indicated that.
This is in stark contrast to the Treasurer's reply to a question I asked of him on 24 September. He said:
Let me make it clear about fringe benefits taxation. The Government is not going to alter the fringe benefits tax.

The Government knows it has to alter the fringe benefits tax. It is a mind-boggling, bureaucratic bungle. The fringe benefits tax is unacceptable, unworkable and clearly people are not going to put up with it. Not only have the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes had a depressing effect on rural areas, on farmers and their property values and on small businesses, but they also represent a real threat to their enterprises.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are costing jobs, too.
—Exactly. The capital gains tax has been introduced in spite of the promise that the Prime Minister made in these words:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it, and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion . . . There will be no new capital gains tax.

Here is this promise on this sheet of paper for all honourable members to see. The Prime Minister gave that undertaking to the Australian people in his election policy speech at the Sydney Opera House in February 1983. That promise was made with as much vigour as the undertaking given by the Government in the 1983 election campaign that Labor would not impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wine. That promise was given by none other than the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and he underlined the words `will not'. Yet the wine industry copped a 10 per cent sales tax the next year which has now been doubled to 20 per cent this year putting the final nail in the coffin of hundreds of winegrowers in this country.
In November 1984 we were also promised by none other than the Prime Minister:
For the term of our next government the Medicare levy will not be increased.

That is another undertaking and promise broken. The litany of broken promises is associated with the most savage taxing government in Australian peacetime history. These taxes have been imposed in spite of an accelerating cost-price crisis for farmers-a crisis which is now affecting our major regional service centres, where unemployment is running at extreme levels. Last week the Bureau of Agricultural Economics informed us that in the last financial year the terms of trade for farmers dropped by 8.1 per cent-five times more than in the previous year-and net farmer incomes are expected to be about $3,400 this financial year. Yet they will be subject to this fringe benefits tax.

The Government is bleeding country Australians with its assets test, the capital gains tax, the monstrous fringe benefits tax, the lump sum superannuation tax, and the heavy substantiation requirements as from 1 July this year. Under extreme pressure the stud stock valuation for tax purposes, which was one of the hidden traps in the rural statement which was submitted to this Parliament by the Minister for Primary Industry on 15 April, has finally been put down, as indeed was the quarantining of farm losses-an ill-conceived tax imposition with which the Government also found it could not live. At least it had the sense to drop it. It should also have the sense to drop this idiotic fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax at a time of severe recession in so many rural industries and amongst so many families.

Undoubtedly, the most devastating attack of all has already been launched on country Australians-indeed all Australians-with the quadrupling of the fuel excise. When the coalition Government left office in 1983 fuel excise revenue returned about $1.3 billion. This year it will reach $5.5 billion-

TALK.START.PARA: —That cannot be right.

—It is right. It is an increase of $4.2 billion, or 336 per cent. What an outrageous increase in fuel tax, denying the Australian people-every motorist, employed or otherwise-of the benefit of a fall in world oil prices. The long awaited tax cuts which are now deferred until December have virtually been financed already by taxing all the motorists in Australia, most of whom are taxpayers. Taxpayers and consumers are being taxed through the petrol pumps in a most rapacious manner. Once again, none are hit harder than those who live in country Australia, with their requirement to travel long distances between centres and their requirement to use relatively large quantities of petrol.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has ripped off country Australians, with its tax policies eroding already small incomes-in some cases, negative incomes-and aggravating the severe rural unemployment problem. The Minister for Primary Industry let the cat out of the bag yesterday in respect of how the Prime Minister is conducting the affairs of this nation. He said that Cabinet had not even been consulted by the Prime Minister before he announced his review of the administration of the tax. Once again the Prime Minister is taking sloppy decisions on the run, because of the pressure of the Opposition and those outside Parliament. The Government knew about the anomalies. Let us not deceive the people: The Government has known for some time that these anomalies were there, but it was going to try to tough it out. It is not good enough for the Government to say that farmers should be grateful for having the fringe benefits tax levied on them rather than their employees to save them book work. It is an absolutely outrageous way to treat the taxpayers and other people in the country areas.

I call upon the Government as a matter of urgency to stop bashing country Australians-the farmers, the small business people and others. I call upon the Government to drop its ludicrous, confusing and unfair fringe benefits tax, which was labelled by the Deputy Leader of the Queensland Branch of the Australian Labor Party as bureaucratic bull you-know-what. If it cannot face its own failings and admit that it has made a mistake, it could at least defer the introduction until 1 January next year. Following the next election the Liberal and National parties in government will abolish the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the assets test lock, stock and barrel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), finished his speech by saying that the Opposition in government would wipe out the fringe benefits tax. I am quite amazed that it put him forward as a speaker today because last week in a radio interview at Gunnedah he said that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, had made it clear that he would not let fringe benefits become another tax avoidance device. To his credit, the Deputy Leader of the National Party went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words he is not going to allow company executives to have half their salaries paid by kind without tax such as providing a house, interest-free loans, Mercedes Benz cars and free education for their children.

So Mr Hunt, the Deputy Leader of the National Party, came clean. We all know that the Liberal Party of Australia is working on some form of fringe benefits tax. We all know that the Liberal Party in opposition is concerned about fringe benefits, as well it should be. We do not have to go far back into history to see that. When the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer, in 1980, he tried to do something about miners' housing. The government of the day was very concerned about the whole area of fringe benefits. If one looks at the White Paper on taxation reform in this country, one will see the statistics in the various tables showing the leakage. Under the heading `Factual Evidence: Fringe Benefits', it is stated that the increase in the number of employees receiving fringe benefits between August 1983 and August 1984 was 25.5 per cent.

If the Opposition is to be responsible it will be very concerned about fringe benefits. It has given us evidence of that. The Deputy Leader of the National Party has been honest enough to say it. Of course, it is not something that we have concocted in government. Taxation of fringe benefits is already provided for in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Again I will read from the White Paper on taxation reform:

Some fringe benefits, such as cash payments and benefits convertible into cash, are income according to ordinary concepts and therefore assessable under section 25 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The income tax law provides for the taxing of other fringe benefits under a general comprehensive provision (section 26 (e)) that requires the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, benefits or bonuses (whether received in cash or in kind) related to employment to be included in assessable income. Despite the comprehensive coverage of section 26 (e), the taxation of benefits which do not take the form of outright cash payments . . . poses practical difficulties. For non-cash benefits, there is a difficult question in each case, for taxpayer and tax administrator alike, of determining the value to the taxpayer of the benefit provided.

So, it is already there in two parts of the taxation Act. That is why the previous Government focused on it and it is why this Government focused on it. But there was an acceleration. The proportion of total tax taken in this country was going down very severely for the corporate sector; more and more of the incidence of taxation was falling on wage and salary earners; and increasingly wage and salary earners were taking benefits apart from strictly determined taxable income. The consequential loss to revenue was assessed, when this report was written, at some $700m. The Opposition is being very coy about what it would do; it has given evidence that it would do something about it, so I assume that it is looking at section 26 (e).

If any government is to address this whole question of leakage, there are really only three options. It can try to tighten up section 26(e). Just assume that that is what the Opposition intends to do. The whole problem with that is that it would impose an additional burden on employers, far beyond what the Government is now proposing. They would have to allocate the fringe benefits across the range of individual employees and remit the pay as you earn deductions every week, not every quarter. In other words to make section 26(e) work, employers would have a lot more paper work than what the Government proposes. If the Opposition is not going to apply fringe benefits tax by tidying up section 26(e) and if it is going to stick with what the Leader of the Opposition now says about fringe benefits tax, as he moves from one position to another-namely, that it is wrong in principle-it will be going back to the rorts. If the Opposition forms a government there will be a bigger and bigger tax leakage. Does the National Party seriously suggest that wage and salary earners should have more and more of their income determined by benefits outside normal wages? What will it do about that? Will it introduce a broadly based consumption tax? Is that what it is being coy about?

It is all right to be critical but we have a real problem. The provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act are not working and there are three options. We can do what the Government is trying to do with fairness and equity, we can allow the rorts to continue or we can try to tighten up on section 26(e). The latter course would produce far more paperwork than we would have with the proposal that is before us. This is a situation that has to be addressed seriously and not merely in terms of political opportunism. No one likes to pay taxes but, on the other hand, no one likes to see one group in the community going scot free. I remember the Australian newspaper running a campaign in 1976-77 under the slogan `Join the tax revolt' and some members of the business sector did that. That was done by the dishonest people. There was enormous tax evasion and avoidance under the previous Government, which did nothing about it until the death knock.

Let us consider some of the new taxes that the previous Government introduced. Not all of them were greeted with unbridled enthusiasm. It introduced the bank accounts debit tax, the 2 per cent revenue duty, the 2 1/2 per cent Medibank levy, the 1978-79 income surcharge and sales taxes on pet foods, soft drink bottles, television tubes, safety belts and a whole range of other items. I could go through a range of increases in sales tax. It introduced excise on off-road distillate, a 33.3 per cent increase in sales tax rates, an increase in the excise on tobacco, petrol and beer, and the massive $3 billion tax take on the crude oil levy, so let it not be thought that this Government is unique in having applied income taxes. This Government is trying to bring about taxation reform and is doing so. The Opposition is concerned because we shall have a tax cut of a total value of $4 1/2 billion by July next year, with the first instalment on 1 December of this year. There will be the additional $500m with respect to tax imputation and group off-sets. There is much misrepresentation about these matters, and I heard a gentleman saying on the radio the other day that the effective tax on company profits is of the order of 79 per cent. He failed to point out that with imputation the tax rate on all company profits will be down to 49 per cent. This is real reform. Everyone will benefit from our taxation reform.

Does the Opposition have a policy on tax cuts worth $1.5 billion at the first stage on 1 December, with the cuts worth $4.5 billion when fully implemented from 1 July 1987? The cuts will reduce the Opposition's top marginal tax rate from 60c in the dollar to 49c and reduce all marginal income tax rates. Does it have any policy on tax cuts worth $12 a week to typical workers? The answer is: `No, of course it does not'. The Opposition will wipe out Medicare and allow the rorts to continue unless it decides to tighten up on section 26 (e), which will cause more paperwork, or unless it inflicts on wage and salary earners a broad-based consumption tax and allow all its big business mates and the rich to get off scot free and rort the system. It has only a few choices and instead of indulging in political opportunism it should face the facts.

Let us consider some of the facts. This will be a rather novel experience after what we have heard today. All taxpayers face the same income tax rates except for two major exceptions. These are the zone allowances that are available to taxpayers in particularly remote areas and the tax averaging that is available to farmers. Is that discrimination against country Australia? No, it is not. It is a reflection of the Government's view that the disadvantages facing country Australians should be fully addressed in policies. This is our strategy. The only differential treatment that we apply to country residents are measures to offset the disadvantages of remoteness and locality. But what does the National party want to do? We have that man in Queensland with that corrupt minority National Party Government and elements of the National Party in this House that want a flat tax. That is nice and simple. It is possible to go around and con people by saying: `We shall bring in a flat tax'. At least the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) had the guts to say what absolute nonsense that was.

What would a flat tax do for farmers? It implies an increased tax burden on country taxpayers in general and farmers in particular. Under the flat tax proposal of the National Party, farmers receiving the average farm income, as estimated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, would pay about $1,675 more in tax per year than at present. Let us consider the Government's tax reform package. The rorts that the package redresses are greater in the cities than in country areas and the package will be to the net advantage of country residents. The Deputy Leader of the National Party has focused mainly on fringe benefits, and who has school fees paid by employers? What is the value of subsidised housing in the city compared with in the country? Where are company cars used as part of salary packages in the bush? Who receives low interest loans, hostess allowances, free holidays and all the other fringe benefits that the Opposition so conspicuously failed to tax when in Government? The answer is city executives. How many farmers provide employees with these sort of benefits? Fringe benefits tax is about employees, and the Opposition wants city executives to be paid private school fees by the employer at the expense of the many country people who have to struggle hard to pay boarding school fees.

The Opposition keeps harping about the effect of fringe benefits tax on farmers, but to be subject to FBT it is necessary to provide fringe benefits to an employee. We know that 85 per cent of farmers do not have any full-time employees. What is the value of the fringe benefits that are provided? What is the value of farm accommodation miles away from cities, particularly when the Government's 40 per cent remote area concession is taken into account? That is the extent of fringe benefits in the bush. Farmers, like all country residents, will be benefiting from tax cuts that the fringe benefits tax will be funding. Those people paying the 60 per cent marginal rate in the bush will be paying 49 per cent. In addition, there will be the other reductions in tax. What does the Opposition want to do with fringe benefits? No one knows. It does not want rorts but it does not want to stop the rorts. We listened to the words of the Leader of the National Party this morning. He said:
The reality is that the field of tax evasion is not in the field of fringe benefits.

That is absolute nonsense. It has been demonstrated that it is costing honest taxpaying people some $700m a year. However, the Deputy Leader of the National Party says that there are rackets in the fringe benefits tax area. There is a division between the Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party. The Deputy Leader has identified school fees and motor vehicles and he is right, but there are many more besides those. The fact is that fiscal necessity-the necessity to fund the Opposition's wild promises-will force the Opposition to tax fringe benefits. I think that it will resurrect and enforce section 26 (e) if it ever gets into government. This means that all employers will face the same paperwork burden that now applies in calculating fringe benefits, and the additional burden of attributing the benefits to individual employees and remitting the pay as you earn tax. That is the only alternative. Let it be clearly understood that business objections to the Government's fringe benefits tax will be less than those raised against the Opposition's proposals.

What else is there in the tax reform package that is supposed to discriminate against country Australians? Is it the extension of immediate deductibility of soil conservation expenditure to the broader concept of land degradation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a personal sense, one cannot help feeling sorry for the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) because he is continually called upon by his Government to defend the Government and to apologise for its disastrous rural economic policies right around Australia. Today has been no exception. I am bound to say that he was far from convincing. When considering the high cost of the Hawke Government's tax regime on country Australia, especially the farm and small business sectors, it is very important to keep in mind that the Government's top priority long term objective is to make Australia a socialist state. There is no doubt that the Government has embarked upon a carefully thought out systematic program designed first to cripple and then to drive Australian families out of farming and business operations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is pursuing a policy of big government, big unions and big business. Government control of business is the socialists' aim. A first step towards achieving this objective is to eliminate family enterprises because they cannot be easily commanded by powerful trade unions and Labor governments, certainly not as effectively as can large corporations. To accelerate the growth of the Public Service, which now has approximately 15,000 more employees than when this Government came to office, the Hawke Government is taxing the pants off farmers and operators of small business. This Government is the biggest spending, biggest taxing government in Australia's peacetime history.

This afternoon, the Minister for Primary Industry referred to the tax cuts promised by this Government. We do not know whether the tax cuts will come or not. If they do come, after the tax cuts promised for 1 July next year, the average Australian taxpayer will be paying $36 a week more in tax than he was paying in March 1983 when this Government came to office. I remind honourable members and the Australian public that it was the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who, as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in 1971, said:

I believe that ultimately the welfare of the people of Australia will be best served when the means of production, distribution and exchange are removed from private ownership and are owned by the people.
A leopard might be able to change its habitat, but it will never change its spots.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The Prime Minister. He also told the Fabian Society's centenary dinner in Melbourne on 18 May 1984:

SPEECH.PARA: Most reformers think that all they have got to do in a political democracy is to obtain a majority. This is a profound mistake. What has to be changed is not only the vote that is cast, but also the mental climate in which Parliament and the Government both live and work.
To ensure that his self-confessed link with the Fabian socialists could not be misinterpreted, the Prime Minister added:
. . . that I find to be an accurate description of the approach I and my colleagues have tried to bring to the affairs of this nation in our first term in office.

In that speech, which every Australian should read, the Prime Minister acknowledged the debt of his own Government to the Fabians and referred to several Fabians, including Jim Cairns and also, to use his own words, `not the least our own Fabius Maximus-Gough Whitlam himself'. The Prime Minister concluded this very revealing speech by quoting the Fabian Society's motto, which in part reads:
For the right moment you must wait, as Fabius did, most patiently, but when the time comes you must strike hard, as Fabius did, or your waiting will be in vain and fruitless.

The Hawke Government has certainly struck. This time it has struck at the heart of the Australian farming and small business sectors. It has done so in a brutal and dishonest way. At a time when Australia's rural community is suffering badly from the depressed state of international commodity markets, the Government's deliberate high interest rate policy is severely compounding those problems. The Government was elected on a promise to bring interest rates down. However, let us consider what has happened since the last election. The prime lending rate in Australia was 14 per cent at the time of the last election. Today, it is around 19 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five percentage points more.

—It is five percentage points more. That has not been caused by accident. High interest rates are the direct result of this Government's intervention to prop up the Australian dollar, which collapsed as a result of poor economic management. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has admitted publicly many times that, by its own decision, the Government has forced up interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer is recorded in Hansard of 20 March as saying:

There has been a $3.8 billion deterioration on a terms of trade basis on an annual rate over the course of the year with which the exchange rate has had to cope. It could not possibly have coped if we had had demand running to strongly. We have turned the wick up on interest rates to moderate that demand.

Some Treasurer, and some wick. When the Treasurer turned the wick up on the interest rates, he caused an explosion-we have not heard whether it was an intended or unintended explosion-the like of which has not previously been experienced in Australian peacetime history. We are no longer competitive with our major trading partners. Our interest rates, which rose a staggering 27.9 per cent in 1985-86, are putting people out of business and work all over Australia. Our prime interest rate of 19 per cent contrasts sharply with that of Canada at 9.8 per cent; France, 9.5 per cent; West Germany, 7 per cent; the United States of America, 7.5 per cent; and Japan, 4.1 per cent.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) has alluded to the fringe benefits tax. That is another example of the Prime Minister's Fabian socialist exercise in gradualism, only this time he has bitten off more than he can chew. He made no mention of this new farm and this business tax before the last election. Instead he thought that he would sneak it in after the election and get away with it by taxing the employer. Again, his judgment was bad. The Australian community is rebelling because the Government's legislation is wrong in principle; it is punitive; it is bureaucratic; and, in short, it is clearly on the nose.

To highlight its hate of farmers and people engaged in small businesses who operate as sole traders or in partnership, the Government has discriminated against owners of small businesses and farmers who do not operate under a trust or company structure and the ordinary citizen who uses a car for the purpose of earning his or her income by imposing a formula considerably harsher than that applying under the fringe benefits tax legislation.

A corporation liable for fringe benefits tax for motor vehicle usage can opt to use a statutory formula instead of a log book. If the vehicle travels more than 40,000 kilometres in a full year, under the formula, the corporation would pay tax on 6 per cent of the value of the vehicle, which would represent between 80 per cent and 90 per cent of the cost of running the vehicle. On the other hand, owners of small businesses and farmers who do not operate under a trust or company structure and the ordinary citizen who uses a car for the purpose of earning his or her income under the substantiation formula can claim only one-third of the operating cost or pay tax on 12 per cent of the cost of the vehicle.

During Question Time yesterday and today, the Prime Minister selectively quoted from a submission sent to him by Western Australian Premier Burke. He did that to try to establish that the submission, which was the work of a number of Western Australian organisations, supported the Government's fringe benefits tax. As is often the case, the Prime Minister failed to read the most telling passage of the document, which was, in fact, the summary. It reads:

In summary, the existing FBT arrangements do not maximise net total equity/efficiency/simplicity benefits. As well they fail four of the nine principles of tax reform announced by the Prime Minister in 1985.

The Government's fuel tax policy, which is causing great concern to the Australian public, is also of tremendous importance and concern to primary producers and operators of small business. Before the 1983 election the Labor Party promised to reduce fuel prices and was very critical of the policies being pursued by the Fraser Government. Excise on fuel in Australia has doubled during the past 12 months, to 20c a litre, during a period when world crude oil prices have fallen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed that members of the Opposition can contrive such a matter of public importance as the one introduced by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and seriously believe that the Australian public could accept that there is any credibility left in the Opposition. The honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), in his 10 minutes, addressed the issue of taxation for perhaps two minutes during his speech. He rambled on about socialism and all the other evils that he tries to find under the bed. The honourable member for Gwydir misled the Parliament in many ways on various issues, which I will address later.

SPEECH.PARA: What is fundamental about members of the Opposition is that they do not understand the principles of a fringe benefits tax. Five basic principles apply to a fringe benefits tax: Firstly, it must be a benefit; secondly, it must be provided by an employer; thirdly, it must be provided to an employee; fourthly, it must be over and above wages and salaries; and, fifthly, it must not be deductible in the hands of an employee. The honourable member for Gwydir was a senior Minister in the Fraser-Howard Government. That Government's only contribution to the taxation debate in this country was to elavate tax avoidance and evasion to an art form. This was to the direct disadvantage of honest farmers and small businessmen who could not avail themselves of the shonky tax scams that flourished under the coalition. In fact, the tax avoidance industry was the only growth industry in Australia during the seven dark years of Liberal-National coalition rule.

All Australians will remember the election campaign of 1977, when the coalition's advertising featured a fistful of dollars. But after the election of the coalition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), now Leader of the Opposition, snatched back the tax cuts. What was his excuse? When the current Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out that the honourable member for Bennelong had reneged on the coalition's promise to provide tax cuts, the Opposition Leader's response was: `I didn't make the promise'. What a convenient line this was for the Leader of the Opposition to adopt. The honourable member for Bennelong sought absolution. Thankfully, the Australian public has a long memory and still distrusts this Opposition Leader.

What was the record of members of the Opposition when they were in government? I would just like to list some of the new taxes they created so that the Australian public can judge the coalition on its record and not its rhetoric. They introduced the bank accounts debit tax; the 2 per cent revenue duty; the 2.5 per cent Medibank levy; the 1978-79 income tax surcharge; excise on off-road distillate; a 33 per cent increase in sales tax rates; increases in excises on tobacco, petrol and beer; new sales taxes on pet food, soft drink bottles, television tubes, safety belts, oils and greases, insecticides, curtains, manchester, construction equipment, and so on and so on. Finally, they introduced the massive $3 billion tax take from the crude oil levy. In other words, the Opposition spent seven years taxing everything that moved and, in some instances, things that did not move. This Government's record, by comparison, is outstanding. When this Government promises a tax cut, it delivers. On 1 November 1984, the tax scales were cut to make the tax system more fair and progressive. Taxpayers with incomes in the range $12,501 to $28,000 received a tax cut of $7.60 per week. This tax cut was not grabbed back, but is now an integral part of the tax reform that continues on 1 December this year, and will conclude with a final instalment on 1 July 1987. For a person on $28,000 this will mean an additional $15.30 per week tax cut. For people on average weekly earnings, savings will be in the vicinity of $10 to $12 per week. For high income earners, the savings will be much more substantial, as the Government moves to wipe out John Howard's 60c in the dollar tax rate so that no one in Australia will pay more than 49c in the dollar to the Government in personal income tax. For someone on $20,000, savings will be $5.64; for someone on $30,000, the savings will be $16.90; for someone on $40,000, savings will be $35.56; and for someone on $50,000, there will be a massive tax saving of $57.56 per week.

The honourable member for Gwydir claims, laughingly, that these tax cuts will do damage to the farm and small business sector. This claim is absolute nonsense. Various members of the Opposition, including the Leader of the Opposition and National Party members, have been touting around the country the proposition that Australia should introduce tax reforms similar to those introduced in the United States of America. This is a deception on the part of the Opposition, but it will not fool the people. Once more the Opposition is peddling half truths. The bottom line is that the overall incidence of taxation in the United States is remarkably similar to that in Australia, at around 30 per cent of gross domestic product.

It is no good muttering about low marginal tax rates in the United States when the facts of the matter are, first, that the top marginal tax rate is actually 33 per cent, not 28 per cent as claimed by the Opposition, because of the phasing-out of the tax thresholds and personal exemptions. Secondly, the rate does not include compulsory social security levies, which for the average United States taxpayer are 6.7 per cent of income; thirdly, the rate does not include State and local government income taxes, which range from zero to 16 per cent in the various States of the United States. Taking all these points into account, individuals on average United States earnings will face an effective marginal tax rate of between 39.7 per cent and 55 per cent depending on which State of the United States they reside in. By comparison, even the highest income earner in Australia will face a marginal tax rate of only 49 per cent. What is more fascinating is that the American tax reform will be financed by a 25 per cent increase in business taxation. In view of the matter of public importance introduced by the honourable member for Gwydir, is this a proposal that the coalition now endorses?

The honourable member for Gwydir, as Deputy Leader of the National Party, has obviously introduced this matter of public importance as part of the National Party's overall taxation strategy. We need to ask ourselves how the National Party would perform in government. We can look at the clear example in my State of Queensland, where the National Party currently governs in its own right. I am sure that all members are aware that this will change on 1 November. The electors of Queensland will then have the opportunity to cast their verdict on the scandal-ridden National Party Government, which is led by an increasingly irrelevant and aging premier.
