Contrary to the popular myth, Queensland, under the National Party Government, is not a low tax State. Any objective analysis of State taxes and fees in Queensland, including such things as rail freight surcharges of $394m, make Queensland, per head of population, the third highest taxing State in Australia. It is also the State with the worst economic record, and the lowest level of services to its people.

As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has previously pointed out, the Queensland National Party has invented a whole new tax-the tax of the hollow log. The hollow log tax particularly hurts the primary producer and the small businessman. The Queensland Government has siphoned off $33.5m from rural assistance funds and run up hollow logs totalling $75m in money that should have been going to assist Queensland farmers and small businessmen. What else does the National Party want? The honourable member for Gwydir, like the Queensland Premier, favours the flat tax system. Under this flat tax proposal, farmers receiving the average farm income, estimated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, would pay $1,765 per year more in tax than they are currently paying. What are the other taxes which members of the National Party feel are unfair? They say they are opposed to the capital gains tax, but the capital gains tax does not apply to properties acquired prior to 20 September last year. Because the turnover of farm properties is less than that of other assets, farmers are the biggest beneficiaries of that exemption. In reality, farm land values do not increase in real terms over time, so little, if any, capital gains tax would ever be paid by the farmers.

Members of the Opposition like to talk about fuel taxes. Of course, they conveniently neglect to inform farmers that the excise does not apply to diesel used on-farm by farmers. This is a most generous tax concession to the rural sector as the farming community is the only group in this country receiving the full exemption. The National Party, as usual, tries to mislead farmers by suggesting that the exemption has changed in some way. There has been no such change. It is common knowledge amongst political observers that the Opposition, when it finally releases its taxation policy, will include some kind of consumption tax. It will be interesting to see whether the National Party is honest with the farming community in advising it of the massive extra burden that farmers and small businesses in country areas will have to bear from such new taxes.

It will be interesting, when the Opposition finally does release its policy, to see what it will do in the area of fringe benefits. It is obvious that many farmers are conscious of the need to tax fringe benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO NEW ZEALAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the official report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to New Zealand, 1986, and seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report which has just been tabled is the report of the fourth Australian parliamentary delegation to visit New Zealand since the adoption in 1978 of what has become known as the Nareen agreement. In 1978 Prime Minister Fraser and New Zealand Foreign Minister Talboys agreed that to further Australia-New Zealand relations there should be regular exchanges of parliamentary delegations. Three delegations from the New Zealand Parliament have also visited Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation visited New Zealand between 9 June and 19 June this year. I consider that this visit was possibly the most informative and worthwhile of any in which I have participated. The delegation's inspections and discussions were wide ranging. The report recognises that because of time constraints it was not always possible to fully pursue matters of interest. We also acknowledge that some of the matters discussed and the views obtained may not fully reflect attitudes within New Zealand. We feel, however, we gained enough information on a number of issues to draw conclusions and to suggest particular courses of action for various Australian Ministers. From our discussions with primary producer organisations it is clear that Australia and New Zealand have a common interest in overturning the dumping policies of the European Community and the United States. It is also clear that there are many areas where joint marketing approaches could be adopted by the two countries to their benefit.

Before our departure we were aware that claims had been made repeatedly in the Press and elsewhere that large numbers of New Zealanders were taking advantage of the lack of immigration controls to abuse Australia's unemployment benefit system. We had the opportunity to discuss this matter with the New Zealand Minister for Social Welfare. The Australian Government has recently taken action in the Budget to overcome this abuse. The delegation, however, requests the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) not only to address the question of abuse but also to provide detailed information to ensure that the Australian Parliament and the community are aware that the vast majority of New Zealand residents in Australia do not take improper advantage of the Australian welfare system.

New Zealand officials advised the delegation that there is no proposal to develop a facility such as the Australian Institute of Sport. These officials suggested that better access to the Australian Institute of Sport should be given to New Zealanders. The delegation believes that this approach could work to the mutual advantage of both Australia and New Zealand. While Australia would be providing the facilities for New Zealand athletes, New Zealand could respond by making coaches available to the Institute.

As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, I was pleased that we were able to conduct extensive discussions and inspections relating to Maori affairs. The problems faced by the Maori people are very similar to those faced by the Australian Aboriginal. The New Zealand Government has undertaken extensive programs to address the economic and social imbalance which exists and to ensure that the rich Maori culture which we observed is preserved and fostered. The Government is pursuing policies to ensure that New Zealand develops as a harmonious multicultural society.

Our discussions with the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence indicate that New Zealand values its relations with Australia. Whatever problems exist with ANZUS it is clear that the Government wishes its relationship with Australia to be maintained and strengthened. It is clear that New Zealand places a considerable importance on these parliamentary exchanges. We, too, believe that these exchanges are valuable and lead to a strengthening of the already close relations between our two countries. We believe the exchanges should continue as they allow parliamentarians from all parties in both New Zealand and Australia to gain first hand knowledge of the other country and to obtain a clearer understanding of current issues.

Our visit was successful because of the assistance given and the hospitality of those involved in the delegation's program. I would particularly thank the New Zealand Prime Minister, his Ministers and officers for making time available to speak to the members. We also thank the Speaker of the New Zealand House of Representatives and members and staff of the House for making us feel so welcome when we visited. Our escort officers from the New Zealand departments of Internal Affairs and Foreign Affairs also deserve special mention. His Excellency Mr Graham Ansell, New Zealand High Commissioner to Australia, and his staff provided valuable assistance prior to the delegation's departure. The delegation also greatly appreciates the friendliness of the New Zealanders who welcomed us so warmly to their businesses, farms and homes. I particularly thank His Excellency the Hon. Les Johnson, Australian High Commissioner to New Zealand, and his staff. I make the comment that Australia is well served by our mission in New Zealand and it is obvious that the High Commissioner is held in very high regard by New Zealand Ministers, Parliamentarians and officials. Finally I pay tribute to the deputy leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) whose fine singing voice helped strengthen the entente cordiale. Unfortunately, he could not be here this afternoon and apologises for his absence. I would also like to thank both the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) for their co-operation and helpful advice on the trip. They were all good ambassadors for Australia. The delegation's role was made so much easier by the diligence and perseverance of the Secretary to the delegation, Mr John Cummins, and I know that all members of the delegation share that view. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The closer economic relations agreement is very important to New Zealand and probably not quite as important to Australia, but I hope that over the years we have an acceptance of the aims and spirit of CER in this country, just as the New Zealanders do. It is appropriate to remind Australians that, prior to the implementation of CER on 1 January 1983, 80 per cent of trade across the Tasman was tariff free and 90 per cent was free of quantitative import restrictions and quotas. The agreement will be reviewed in 1988. The agreement is working. There is a genuine wish by New Zealanders and Australians to have ongoing discussions about matters that are causing concern at the moment and likely to cause concern in the future. There is a willingness to have discussions on an industry by industry basis. When that review comes around in 1988, provided that spirit of genuine goodwill and co-operation is still present, we will have a wider base for primary industry and manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, our countries have a close relation- ship. Anzac Day is a very important day in the history of New Zealand and of Australia. It is interesting to note that New Zealand has many internal problems similar to ours. For instance, it is cheaper to ship wheat from Melbourne to Singapore than it is to take it across the strait to Tasmania. In our discussions, we were similarly told that it is cheaper to ship goods from the North Island of New Zealand to Sydney or Melbourne and thence to the South Island than it is to ship them directly to the South Island. So there are a great deal of similar problems.

Of course, there is a spirit of friendly rivalry. The leader of our delegation will recall how, when we visited the factory where the New Zealand challenge boat for the America's Cup was built, the New Zealanders indicated that they hoped that they would beat the Australians. I am not an expert on sailing but, on account of our close association with New Zealand, if in the dim distant future some country should happen to beat us, I would prefer that it be New Zealand. It is interesting to note too that we beat them in rugby. That occurred after our trip over there. We were amazed even at watching reserve grade or under-age games, which we did at Queenstown on a fairly inclement day. The traditional power of the forward play of the All Blacks was absorbed even by the youngest players. These were very interesting things to learn about.

I join with the leader of the delegation in extending thanks to our guides from New Zealand, Mr Blair, Mr Greenland and Mr Ward. They introduced us to many people. The overriding view that I came away with was of a genuine interest in partnership with Australians in exploring trade opportunities in the South Pacific and Pacific basin area. As an Australian parliamentarian, probably the highlight of the trip was to note the very high respect-I repeat very high respect-in which our High Commissioner, the Honourable Les Johnson, is held by the New Zealanders. Irrespective of any personal views that people may have, I believe, having seen the position of esteem in which he is held in New Zealand-he is very widely known and has the ability to open doors and arrange deputations-that there is a role in diplomatic circles for people who may be termed politicians, professional or retired. Les Johnson is a credit to the Australian diplomatic service. As an Australian and as a fellow parliamentarian of his era, although we were from different parties, I was very proud to note the esteem in which he is held. To my mind, for professionals in the diplomatic service, Les Johnson has set almost impossible high standards for them to follow.

On that note, I conclude by giving warm congratulations to the leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard). His very friendly, warm and generous approach welded together the four parliamentarians from different parties. He was always only too willing to allow discussions to continue when one or other member of the party was interested in pursuing a particular point of view. At all times he ensured that all of us were treated as equals. To Allen, I express my deep appreciation for a job very well done indeed. He was very generous in his praise of the deputy leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who, of course, in his inimitable way, was mostly the life of the party.
