DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT (RECIPROCITY WITH ITALY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time left to me in this debate today, I would like to summarise the Opposition's views on the Social Security Amendment (Reciprocity with Italy) Bill 1986 and to express our concern at some of the directions that the Government has gone off in in negotiating this agreement with Italy. Firstly, I reiterate that the agreement, the Bill and previous amendments to the Social Security Act arose as a result of an initiative announced by a former coalition Minister for Social Security, the Hon. Fred Chaney, in 1982. The initiative is designed to ensure that Australia has a working proportional portability relationship with countries to ensure that Australians who have their origins in those countries have some sort of retirement income and social welfare entitlement in those countries, should they choose to return to their country of origin after a period of residence in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is that, although the Government has pursued the initiative of the coalition and adhered in principle to the philosophy of that initiative and to the underlying principles announced by Senator Chaney when he elaborated that proposal back in 1982, the detailed negotiations on those issues seem to have gone wrong. To put it quite simply, they have gone off at a tangent. They have failed to pay attention to the details. Unfortunately, the Government has been less than frank with the Australian people and with many members of the ethnic communities in Australia who have a vital and real interest in this legislation because they are likely to be affected directly by it.

In speaking to this initiative in the House and in other places the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has implied that there will be no losers; that all Australians will gain and no one will be worse off. He has even convinced the members of the Australian Labor Party that that will be the case. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), in speaking to this legislation, said that there will be no losers; that everybody will be a winner. I will take a moment to explain how inaccurate is that perception that Government members are seeking to create. Under the provisions of this agreement, an unknown number of Italian Australian pensioners could lose part or all of their entitlement to an Australian pension. For example, if a man arrived in Australia on 7 May 1985 and turns 65 years of age on 2 January 1996, he would receive only 43 per cent of an Australian pension payment if he left Australia to return to a country with which Australia has a reciprocal agreement, which in this case is Italy. If, however, that person turns 65 on 31 December 1995, that is a day before the trigger for the introduction of this agreement, two days ahead of the hypothetical birthday, he would receive 100 per cent of the Australian age pension, subject of course to the assets test. That means that because of the arbitrary incidence of a two-day time lag-that is, the difference in his birth date of two days 48 hours-he stands to drop 57 per cent of his entitlement to an Australian pension. To my mind, and to the minds of all Opposition members, it seems that some Australians will lose. Obviously there are circumstances where Australians who originate from overseas and who intend to return to a country where we have a proportional pension agreement will stand to lose entitlement compared with other Australians who choose to stay in this country. The Government should explain that to the ethnic communities and be fully frank about the consequences.

There is also the consequence of this agreement applying to Australians who originate from, say, Greece and who work in Australia for a time, and then go to Italy or to another country with which we will eventually have a reciprocal agreement on pensions and social security. Their entitlement may be reduced, or they may have no entitlement other than a proportional Australian entitlement because they have not been a resident of that third country and earned an entitlement by either residence or contribution over a period. As the number of agreements is extended to countries throughout the world, this problem will trap more and more Australians whose country of birth is not Australia. It is a growing concern among ethnic communities throughout Australia.

The other matter that arises as a consequence of these reciprocal agreements is how the Australian social security system requirements will be enforced overseas. We have been talking predominantly about the age pension. That pension under the Hawke Labor Government is subject to both the income and assets tests. I ask the Minister to explain in detail how he intends to enforce on pensioners who are claiming that pension overseas both tests with the same degree of diligence and rigor as are enforced on Australian pensioners. I remind the House that it is the Government's intention to remove the two Australian based officers from the London office of the Department of Social Security and repatriate them to Australia. That office has responsibility for administering some $87m of social security payments overseas. We have two at present plus a local staff. We are withdrawing the two Australians. How are they to be expected to enforce the assets test, the income test and all the other requirements of the Social Security Act in respect of benefits paid overseas when in Australia it takes some 1,500 officers to enforce the assets test alone, and many thousands of officers within the Department to administer and enforce the requirements of the Australian social security system? Obviously we shall see the development of a double standard in enforcement of entitlements and obligations under the Social Security Act.

Before this debate was resumed, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) commented on his recent delegation to New Zealand. He also commented on the concern on both sides of the Tasman as to abuse of the Australian social security system by New Zealand nationals. He was at pains to stress, and I agree with him, that not all New Zealand nationals resident in Australia at a point of time manipulate our system, but he acknowledged, and brought to this House the acknowledgment of the New Zealand Government, that there were problems with the system. I contrast that acknowledgment with the initial statements made by the Minister for Social Security that there was no problem with the agreement with New Zealand.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.
—Order! The Minister will withdraw.
—That is a very misleading statement.
—The Minister will withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—At a later time today I shall seek to apprise the House of statements made by the Minister in Press releases. I am concerned that, while this Government is pursuing the negotiation of reciprocal social security agreements with foreign governments, it is not attaching sufficient priority to negotiating reciprocal agreements with countries with which Australia has close and growing economic ties, close population links and close population-migratory trends. There is a need to negotiate an effective reciprocal agreement with New Zealand that covers both the portability and the eligibility for social welfare in both countries. As I mentioned previously in this debate, priority should also be given to negotiating a similar agreement with the United Kingdom because of Australia's historical links and the numbers of people from the United Kingdom who are now settling in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There is broad bipartisan support for the general thrust of this agreement. We are concerned, however, at the direction the Government is taking and with the fact that the Government had been less than frank as to the consequences of its proposals for some members of the Australian community. It is incumbent upon the Minister in his concluding remarks to explain what action he intends to take fully to acquaint those members of the Australian community with the potential implications of this agreement for their entitlements should they remain in Australia, return to their country of origin, or go to a third country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is discussing the Social Security Amendment (Reciprocity with Italy) Bill 1986, and it is interesting that we have just heard the usual number of sweeping statements from the Opposition spokesman on social security, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). One wonders what sort of position the country would be in if the honourable member were ever to administer the social security legislation. Obviously the honourable member either has not read the Bill or has not understood the thrust of a number of other areas of the present social security legislation. One can always construct examples and models of Italians who come to live in Australia for 15 years and then decide to go to live in Iceland. It is then said that such a person may not be eligible under this reciprocity arrangement. Those kinds of examples are nonsense, as I shall demonstrate later in my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The remark that showed the ignorance of the honourable member for Richmond of the Social Security Act was displayed a few moments ago when he took the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) to task in respect of some person who may have left the country a day or two short of meeting the eligibility criteria and who was thus found to be ineligible. If the honour- able member understood the present Social Security Act, he would know that that was a fact now. If a person leaves Australia-a male before his sixty-fifth birthday or a woman before her sixtieth birthday-he or she would not be eligible to take any pension overseas. A person is only eligible once he or she has reached that birthday here in Australia. The honourable member said that there was a loophole in the legislation, but I remind him that it already exists. This Bill attempts to overcome precisely those problems. In the past one experienced the ludicrous state of affairs that some people spent most of their working lives in Australia, left the country before their sixtieth or sixty-fifth birthday and were not eligible for social security benefits here or in their country of origin. One of the main reasons for these reciprocity agreements is to overcome a problem which the honourable member for Richmond, in his ignorance, did not realise exists in Australia at present.

Reciprocal social security agreements are based on principles which are in line with a number of international practices. As the Minister outlined in his second reading speech, those principles are: Shared responsibility, where each party to the agreement will contribute to a person's total social security coverage; equality of treatment, which provides that the residents and citizens of both countries will be given equal access to each other's social security laws; totalisation, which ensures that periods of residence and/or contributions in both countries will be added together to give people the minimum period of residence or contributions required to qualify for a pension from either or both countries. That was a matter which the honourable member for Richmond seemed to think was not contained in this legislation.The other principle was the pro rata basis, which ensures that the total amount of pensions to be paid by each country to people residing in the other will be based either on the length of a person's residence or contributions. Those four points would ensure that any agreement into which Australia entered would benefit Australia, people who are sometimes residents of Australia and any other country with which we are dealing.

I draw the attention of the House to the point about the pro rata basis, because in the past that has been a major stumbling block to carrying out proposals for a reciprocal agreement. Most nations which have social security arrangements-and in the main these tend to be developed countries, especially European nations-have social security and pension systems based on contributions, not on a period of residence in that country. As everyone knows, in Australia we have a universal age pension based on a minimum period of residence of 10 years, which is payable when a male reaches 65 or a female reaches 60. We also have other types of pensions in various categories. Australia is unique in the world in that we have a non-contributory type of social security system. Most other developed countries have systems that are based on contributions and it is easy to marry them up. Many people in Australia think that the tax system somehow entitles them automatically to a pension, but our system is not based on any automatic entitlement. That has caused some misapprehensions on the part of immigrants who have come from systems where they have contributed through either a percentage of their wages or a surcharge on their taxes and thus are entitled to a pension, no matter what their economic circumstances might be.

This particular agreement is the outcome of long and careful negotiations instituted by the Minister for Social Security. He held extensive consultations and was involved in some 50 meetings with migrant community groups throughout Australia before the Government's position was settled. Despite the difficulties and what sometimes seemed like insurmountable opposition from certain areas of the ethnic community, the Minister persisted. I must pay tribute to him because when his proposals were explained and then the misinformation that was being put around, in some cases by people who were perhaps just a bit fearful that they might lose rights that they already had, was corrected, the agreement had widespread acceptance. It is quite wrong for the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Richmond, to try to suggest that there will be losers in this type of program. There will not be. This type of misinformation, which the Opposition put around during the negotiation period, caused a great deal of uncertainty in many sectors of the ethnic community in Australia.

The Minister was also advised in the negotiations by a group of five people, including Italian Australians, on the consultative process and the policy issues involved. When the initial discussions were being held between the Minister and various ethnic groups, I was privileged to be a member of a committee from the Parliamentary Labor Party which participated in the consultation process. As a result of that process, the Social Security (Proportional Portability of Pensions) Amendment Act 1986 was passed, which enabled the principle of pro rata basis to be adopted in Australia. Although proportional portability provided a basis for cost sharing agreements, it is part of Australia's domestic law and therefore it does not give the Minister carte blanche to enter into agreements. That is very sensible because as part of the arrangement in the consultation process undertakings were given to people that no agreements would be entered into unless they were done by legislation and until there was widespread discussion. This Government is about ensuring that those people who have an interest-financial or any other sort-in this type of legislation will be taken account of and discussions will be held with them prior to the Government entering into any agreements with other countries.

The Bill before us refers specifically to the reciprocal agreement signed with Italy on 23 April this year. This will be the forerunner of a number of other agreements which will be negotiated and for which the Australian-Italian agreement will provide the basic principles and blueprint for action. I must stress again that other agreements may have to be modified. This agreement will provide the framework for the process, but the provisions are not set in concrete. Some 18 other countries have already indicated an interest in negotiating cost sharing agreements with Australia. I would have thought that the Opposition spokesman would have known that when he gave the example of the Greek who went to live in Italy after retiring, having lived in Australia for a number of years. The Greek Government may want to enter into an agreement with Australia, and I have no doubt that the Italian and Greek governments are probably considering arrangements with each other. Once that world wide web of agreements is reached, it will be for the benefit of everybody who is a resident of Australia.

The final form of any future agreement will depend to some extent on the particular country's social security scheme and how our scheme can be aligned with it in order to obtain suitable reciprocity. Most importantly, I wish to stress-and I think this should be stressed over and over again-that no agreement will be negotiated unless there is support from the relevant ethnic community in Australia. The Government's view is that these things will benefit those people who are residents and citizens here and they will always be taken into account when the decisions are being made.

One of the encouraging things about reciprocal agreements, be they on social security or the recently announced reciprocal health care agreements, is that we are moving closer to the day when people will be able to move freely from one country to another over their lifetimes without jeopardising their entitlement to protection against the contingencies of life. Reciprocal agreements also provide a suitable mechanism to ensure that each country to which a migrant has contributed shares responsibility for social security coverage.

The reciprocal agreement between Australia and Italy specifically addresses the social security rights of those who have resided in Australia and cannot claim Australian pension entitlements because they now reside in Italy; those who ceased contributing to the Italian social security scheme when they migrated to Australia and who now cannot claim Italian pension entitlement; and those from Italy who are now in Australia but do not have access to Australian pensions because they have not resided here long enough. That qualification period is usually 10 years. In the long run, when we have arrangements with other countries, a number of people in my electorate, which has a very high immigrant content, will be a lot happier. I often have cases where a person has come to Australia under the Government's arrangements for allowing parents of citizens to migrate here pretty well without any qualifications. Many of those people find that after they arrive their children's circumstances change and the children, who may have young families of their own, are not able to look after their parents as well as they might have when they first assisted them to migrate. Because those people have not lived in Australia for 10 years, they are not entitled to an Australian pension. If they are in dire circumstances, they may be able to obtain a special benefit from the Department of Social Security, but it has always struck me as absurd that the country in which they spent their lives and contributed to the economic progress-usually a developed country-could not provide them with a pension here in Australia.

Until this agreement was signed the only country that provided any social security assistance to its nationals who migrated to Australia was Britain. This applies also to a lesser extent to New Zealand. Britons who lived in Australia were able to receive a pension here. But Italians, Greeks and others who had contributed to their own country's social security scheme found, when they came to Australia, that they were not able to receive a pension from their country of origin. Indeed, some Australians who had lived here for many years-in some instances 30 or 40 years-but went to a third country or returned to their country of origin before their sixty-fifth birthday if they were male or their sixtieth birthday if they were female were not entitled to claim an Australian pension to take with them. That occurred even though they had contributed to the economic growth of Australia over many years. This gave rise to a ridiculous situation in which a number of people had to return here for their birthday and make sure they were here the day before and the day after so that they could claim a pension and take it overseas with them.

The amount of pension which will be paid by Australia will be based on actual residency during working life. Under the Italian scheme, Italy will calculate its pension on actual contributions. More people in Australia will be entitled to money from Italy than people living in Italy will be entitled to money from Australia. That is the important thing, because many people have suggested that this legislation would result in a massive outflow of cash from Australia. It is quite the reverse. In fact, some 17,000 people resident in Australia of Italian origin will be entitled to an Italian pension and only 3,000 people who were Italian residents living in Australia and who went back to Italy will be entitled to a pension from Australia. The balance of this is very much in Australia's favour. This agreement can be seen to be very good for Australia and for people who live in Australia.

Despite the myths to the contrary, some of which were perpetuated in this House today by the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Richmond, the vast majority of people who migrate to Australia remain in Australia. They do not retire to their country of birth and live the lives of kings on an Australian pension, as some people would like us to believe. The reason that most of those people come to Australia is that they intend to stay here for good. When this agreement is finalised, 17,000 people in Australia will be entitled to an Italian pension and only 3,000 people in Italy will be entitled to an Australian pension. Those figures alone suggest that people who come to Australia from other shores tend to stay here.

There are close to 300,000 Italian born people in Australia. Estimates are that in the first year of operation of the agreement Australia will outlay about $4.6m on payments, while it will cost the Italian Government about $38.3m. During the first three financial years of operation of the agreement, between 1987 and 1990, it is estimated that there will be a net inflow to Australia of $109.6m. In the same period the cost of the agreement is estimated at $16.5m to the Australian Government. Even that $16.5m will be offset by an estimated tax revenue of $16.7m, which will give Australia a net saving of $200,000. This measure will be not only of benefit to the Australian people but also of advantage in a small way to the Australian exchequer.

The implementation date for the agreement with Italy is targeted for next year. Since 1952 Italy has been pressing Australia for a reciprocity agreement. Italy has a network of agreements designed to protect the social security rights of emigrant workers. The absence of a comprehensive agreement with Australia represented a significant gap in that network. The Italian-Australian community has been campaigning for an agreement for some years and has made strong representations to the Italian Government to implement the treaty without delay.

Australia introduced portability of pensions in 1973 and the introduction of proportional portability from 1 July this year further rationalised the portability concept. The agreement with Italy will cover people who move between Australia and Italy, enabling them to qualify for a number of pension benefits, including the Australian age, invalid, widows', wives' and double orphans' pensions. The Italian benefits include old age, seniority, anticipated pensions and a number of invalidity and unemployment allowances.

The proportion of a pension payable by Australia to a pensioner living in Italy will be calculated according to how long he or she spent in Australia during the working age years. If those years are fewer than 25, the pension he or she will receive from Australia will be calculated on the basis of a proportion of an income or assets tested pension represented by the number of years spent in Australia over 25 years. Someone who lives in Australia and claims an Australian pension under the agreement will, through the combination of the Italian and Australian pensions, get a total payment which will equal the amount that any other Australian pensioner will get. No person will be disadvantaged by the agreement. Claimants for pensions will be able to apply for Australian benefits while living in Italy and they will continue to apply for Italian benefits while resident in Australia.

A number of issues were the subject of negotiation. It was difficult to obtain reciprocity on a benefit to benefit basis due to the basic differences between the Australian and Italian systems, so the governments of Australia and Italy took a global approach. The Italians protested at Australia's initial proposal of a 40-year working life period and had a fundamental difficulty with Australia's different bases for the rates of calculation inside and outside Australia. The Italian-Australian community pressed strongly for a reduction in the Australian working life proposal and, after consultations, 25 years was finally agreed upon. Reaching agreement on appropriate income testing of Australian agreement pensions, given the absence of general income testing by the Italians, was a long process. Solutions reached included special income testing arrangements in exchange for the inclusion of other Italian benefits in the agreement.

The Minister for Social Security is to be congratulated on this legislation. I have only one suggestion to make. I noted in today's Australian that the Japanese Ministry for International Trade and Industry, better known for its promotion of Japanese goods and services in overseas markets, has proposed a scheme known as the Silver Columbus scheme to export pensioners. The proposal is to set up retirement villages of about 1,000 people in overseas countries. Given that proposal, I suggest that the Minister should urgently consider reaching an agreement with Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) on his comments, few of which I disagreed with. For the first time I heard some figures presented by a member on the Government side; the cost benefits to Australia have not been forthcoming from the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). I have seen no indication of cost benefits in this agreement or in projections for other agreements which are imminent, so those figures are very much appreciated by the House, but there has been some dereliction on the part of the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: My view that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has always been a grandstander has been reinforced. It does not matter whether it is attendance at a sporting event or categorical statements on income tax, capital gains tax, superannuation tax or whatever; that is his character. I refer the House to statements made by the Prime Minister while he was in Italy for the signing of this agreement with the Italian Social Security Department. The Prime Minister was reported in the Canberra Times of 25 April 1986 to have said:
This agreement brings us closer together and enables people who have moved their country of residence to receive better rewards for a lifetime of work.

Superficially that sounds fine, but let us analyse what is happening, because there are some difficult areas in this legislation which have not been noted by the Government nor expressed to community groups. The community groups are very concerned because they are starting to find, as with the fringe benefits tax, other areas about which they have not been told things that they should have been told. If we search the fine print of speeches and Press releases, we find tucked away in half a dozen words an inference-nothing more than that. It is not appropriate for the Minister or the Government to seek to build an expectation or a perception which is larger than life and larger than reality. That has happened. All the Prime Minister's statements need to be put under a microscope, because the more flamboyant and categoric the statement, the more likely it is to be misleading. In this instance the statement sounds fine, but let us analyse it because the conclusion one must draw is that the Prime Minister is a grandstander. It is necessary for us to examine precisely how the proportional portability legislation will work.

I have before me a table from the Department of Social Security which I wish to examine as to who is eligible for a portable pension and who is not. A person who was a pensioner prior to 1 July 1986 will not be affected by this legislation in any way. People who are not currently pensioners but were residents or absent residents on 8 May 1985, or people who were invalided or widowed, de jure in Australia will not be affected by this legislation. It is simple and compassionate. If a person loses his spouse or is invalided in Australia, he loses nothing and the legislation does not affect him. However, if the person is a resident or an absent resident on 8 May 1985, he is not affected by the legislation if he becomes a pensioner after 1 July 1986 and leaves Australia before 1 January 1996 or if he becomes a pensioner after 1 July 1986 and leaves Australia after 1 January 1996 for a non-agreement country.

That is a very easily read statement, but it is difficult to explain unless one can see the chart. It really means that a person who goes back to a non-agreement country after 1996 takes his full pension with him, but if he goes back to an agreement country he gets a proportional pension. I think we need to look at how many people may be affected. The way in which one can make that assessment is to look at the number of people who have come in within the 14 years prior to the commencement date, which is a total of 24 years and which is the legal working life under this legislation. If we look at the numbers of people who have come in within that period, we find that from 1971 to 1985 there were 25,900 Italians, 24,900 Greeks, 11,400-odd people from Malta and 24,964 from West Germany. The number of immigrants to Australia during that period from all the countries with which the Government has indicated it will negotiate agreements totals 187,900. Those are the figures that I have been given, and I think they would be fairly close to reality. We have a bulk of people who have arrived here after 1971 and who will be affected by the legislation, which begins, in effect, in 1985.

If those people stay for the 10-year period, which is the gap that the Minister has put into the legislation, and then return to their countries of origin, they are eligible for only part pensions, if they have been in Australia for less than 25 years and if they go to a country with which we have an agreement. I tried to do a calculation on the returns, and I found that on average over the last five or six years about 14 per cent of people who come to Australia return to their countries of origin. Some of them go back very soon after arriving in Australia-they find that they do not like it here-and they return for a number of reasons. The Minister has not said, nor can I gather, the likely number of people. Fourteen per cent of the 187,000 who may be affected is roughly 26,000 people. The wide open statement which was made by the Prime Minister and which was supported by the Minister, that no one will be worse off and that everybody will be fine, is not true. People who will have given between 10 and 25 years of their working lives to Australia, compared with their Australian colleagues, will be placed in a worse position. Those are people who will retire after 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why worse?
—Because they will have only a part pension.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Lowe-They will get a pension from Italy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will get a pension from Italy-they will have the buildup process from Italy-but a person who goes back to a non-agreement country, on the 10-years residency process, will be entitled to a full pension. People are concerned that it is likely that they will get less than the expected pension. They have given fair working lives to Australia; they were here prior to the introduction of this legislation; and they had a reasonable expectation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not objecting to the process that the Government has used; I am objecting to the lack of comment and openness in some of the statements that have been made by the Government. Complete frankness about people in these circumstances will draw a ready and supportive response because the people in these circumstances are good Aussies; they understand basically why the Government is doing it; and they are supportive of the Australian way of life and Australian ideals. I feel that the Government could have been a little more frank. It has taken me weeks and weeks to work out what the Government is doing, sometimes through lack of communication, sometimes because departmental officers have been busy and partly because of misleading rumours that run rife in ethnic communities where people are not properly informed. Those things ought to be, but have not been, safeguarded against. The Minister, in his Press release of 7 November 1985, said:
Many in Australia will get extra payments from overseas pensions systems. None will be worse off . . .
I challenge that because I believe that those returning in the circumstances that I have outlined will receive less than a full Australian pension. The Minister also said:
These new arrangements-worked out after extensive consultations with all major communities in every State-will bring major benefits to many people both in Australia and overseas.

They will bring benefits to some, but not to all, in the future, as the carte-blanche statement seems to indicate. I would go so far as to say that in this instance there are substantial unintended consequences, to quote the words of the Prime Minister in the last few days. I think the Minister and the Department ought to come forward and state readily and openly that there will be circumstances that affect people. If one reads the Minister's second reading speech, one will see tucked away in part of one sentence:
After that date,--
that is, 1 January 1996--
only those who go to a country with whom Australia has a reciprocal agreement will be affected.
That is the only mention that the Minister makes of that circumstance in his speech. On the next page of his speech are bald statements such as:

Honourable members will be aware that the Social Security Act provides that certain pensioners in Australia can continue to receive their pensions if they go overseas. The new provisions do not alter these basic provisions.

That is misleading for an expectant recipient of a pension under normal circumstances. People expect to be treated as they have been treated traditionally in Australia, with fairness and openness. To find some little hook later in the event is of concern to anybody who has made a major contribution to bring his family up in Australia, and has paid taxes and has worked hard for the benefit of, and in helping to build, this nation.

I refer to the House to the inadequate processes that have been used in establishing this. It was only within the second reading speech of the Minister that I was able to discern the formality of this process. I enunciate to the House that the first step in the process is a detailed exchange of information between the countries affected, including written material and face to face meetings, to enable both countries' officials to understand each other's social security systems. The second step is consultation with communities in Australia which are likely to be affected by an agreement. The third step is negotiation of the terms of an agreement, taking into account community views, that is, the tight negotiations between Australian officials and those of overseas countries. The fourth point is the ratification and implementation of the legislation.

In seeing it for the first time, it is not a bad process and I could not think of many ways in which to improve it, but it has not been implemented in the way it should have been. There were all the wheel wobbles at first when the Minister made these wide statements about working lives of 35 or 40 years. The community groups around Australia-the Italians, Greeks and everybody else-said: `Hey, wait a minute. Come and talk to us'. The Minister was dragged with some unwillingness to talk to people who were gravely concerned about those initial statements. He set up a consultative process. The Opposition was never involved in any consultation, but apparently the consultative process satisfied the Minister at the time. The current state of play suggests, however, that there are a few likely difficulties.

Papers have been exchanged with Greece and it is likely that there will be a visit by representatives of the Greek department of social security in December, and then consultations with the community will start. That is fine, but the Greek community should know that and know it in advance. I take it that it does. There have been no discussions with the Maltese people in Australia and I understand that there have been no discussions with the Maltese Government. There have, however, been exchanges of information and some tentative exchanges with the community. I will come back to that. We have an interim patch-up arrangement, as I call it, with New Zealand pending proper renegotiation. The Minister said in his Press release that he was renegotiating with New Zealand, and I draw his attention to the Press release of 4 November 1985, which contains a joint statement by the Minister and the New Zealand Minister for social security. The Press release reads:
The Minister said that the reciprocal social security agreement between Australia and New Zealand was being renegotiated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My problem was that I had told the shadow Minister months before that the agreement was being renegotiated and that it would go to the question of unemployment benefit and the matters about which he had been concerned.

—That is fine, but when there is part renegotiation the expectation is that the whole job will be done. I think that my description of a patch-up arrangement is apt. Such an arrangement is not what the Opposition was expecting, and that has been made obvious from the exchange that took place earlier. It may be up to three years before we get things fixed up with the New Zealand Government-who knows? There are uncertainties about the United Kingdom and real difficulties on which I shall not dwell. Further discussions with West Germany and Austria will take place in late November or December. Discussions with Yugoslavia have started. I come back to the Maltese situation. There has been a protest meeting of the Maltese community in Sydney because it is distressed about some discrimination. There has not been proper consultation yet. The Maltese community is one of the most structured and well informed in Australia. All Maltese community groups in Victoria and New South Wales belong to a council of the relevant State. There is a Maltese community council of New South Wales and of Victoria. Both councils have talked together and have nominated a group to consult the Government. Consultation has not taken place in the proper way and there is real concern. It is essential to use the proper channels of any community. We should not doubt people's ability or hurt their feelings by avoiding what they would regard as the correct processes of consultation. I hope that some of the difficulties that have already been experienced by the Maltese community can be overcome.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the Government is moving in the right direction. There has been confusion and there have been statements that have sought to placate concern. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) never helps when a position is delicate. He paints the big picture and his attitude is: `She'll be right, Bob'. Things are not right, however, because the fine and detailed work has not been done. We have seen that with capital gains tax and we have seen it with this issue as well. It will be some time before the agreements are properly in place and we hope that the negotiations and discussions will continue satisfactorily. I should like to see the wording of all documentation and the information flowing to community groups to be simple in form and non-bureaucratic. I have had difficulties understanding what the Government has been doing and I know what community groups have felt about the information that they have received. I ask the Minister to try to achieve the proper expression of normal English. It is bad enough if English is not one's first language, but if it is and it cannot be understood, there are particular difficulties.

I do not think that the Minister has been to see Scoop. Scoop knows the people to whom the Minister should talk. He knows also how to express himself when talking to groups. There should be consultation that involves the Department. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) is a great representative of many groups that have come to Australia, and particularly of the Maltese community. I know that he endorses what I am saying.

I cannot find any reference to assets tests. I do not know how they will be carried out 10 years later when someone is living in Italy and has bought up half the countryside around his home village. It seems that there is nothing for the Italian Government to do to comply with this procedure. That is something that does not feature in the agreement. How will the tests be conducted? Will we send a tax officer to knock on the door to ascertain what someone possesses 10 years later? If that is done, there might not be a good reception in some parts of the world. People might not take very kindly to Australia applying its assets test laws on foreign soil 10, 15 or 20 years later.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not take kindly to their being applied here.

—So I understand. I thank the honourable member for his intervention. He is an effective member. Cost effectiveness has not been spelt out and communication has been poor. The big claim has been too big and that has caused real concern in some sections of the community, particularly the Italian community. As time passes I hope that the Minister will be able to rectify some of the problems to which I am referring in the way in which the Government is to endeavour to rectify all the inadequacies of the fringe benefit tax. A change of government would solve so many of these problems. If the Minister listens to us, it will help-
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Amendment (Reciprocity with Italy) Bill brings nearer to completion what has been quite a lengthy procedure. Discussions for an Australia-Italy agreement have been proceeding intermittently since 1952. Formal negotiations for a cost-sharing agreement commenced in 1983 and the agreement was signed in Rome on 23 April 1986. It is hoped that implementation will be in mid-1987. It is a measure which has in principle attracted a great amount of bipartisan support in this place. The Bill implements the cost-sharing reciprocal agreement with Italy that was entered into on 23 April. It also makes minor amendments to proportional portability legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In May 1985, when announcing the Government's decision to sign a reciprocal social security agreement with Italy, the Minister recorded his belief that the agreement would bring many benefits for Italians residing in Australia and Australians residing in Italy. Of course, the former constitutes a significant component of our population. In the period 1945 to 1982 more than 446,000 Italians have come to Australia as permanent settlers. As revealed by the 1981 census in my home State of Victoria, people of Italian birth constituted 3 per cent of the total population. On the basis of the same census in my electorate of Scullin, there were more than 11,700 residents of Italian birth, over 10,000 of whom had resided in Australia for longer than five years, and over 50 per cent of these were in the 40-plus age group.

The legislation comes at a time when the importance of the contributions of our extensive Italian community is fully evident. It has come at a time when the Spoleto Festival of Three Worlds has just finished entertaining the people of Melbourne. This international arts festival originated 27 years ago in Spoleto, Italy. This legislation has come in the year when patrons of the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show have enjoyed extensive exhibitions from Italy in its capacity as a guest nation. The show's theme, `Italy on Show at the Show', recognised the contribution that Italians have made to Australian culture. The Italian theme certainly added some spice to a great Victorian institution.

The Bill has also come at a time when the Brownlow Medal, the highest honour in Australia's great game, Victorian Football League, has been awarded to a son of Italy, Robert Dipierdomenico. I might add that the Minister for Social Security, being a staunch Hawthorn supporter, should be pleased with that. As I mentioned earlier, over 50 per cent of the large Italian population in my electorate is in the 40-plus age group. This is one of the groups that will benefit from the Bill. Many of those Italian Australians have been residents in Australia for a long period. It is worth recalling that their experiences have often been difficult. In the immediate post-war years, many new immigrants faced hardship, exploitation and prejudice.

In leading for the Opposition, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), in a rather condescending manner, referred to the Whitlam Government's implementation of the portability of pensions principle. I wish to refer briefly to the debate that occurred at that time. In April 1973, the then Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden)-the present Minister for Foreign Affairs-when introducing legislation which enabled portability of pension said:

For too long, migrants have been told by past governments of their valuable contribution to the development of this nation. But for equally long too little has been contributed by those governments towards the special needs of so many migrants, especially during their difficult period of adjusting to a new, alien and not always hospitable society.

In 1980, FILEF-the Federation of Italian Labourers, Emigrants and their Families-published a book edited by Morag Loh entitled With Courage in their Cases. FILEF is a well-respected organisation which provides essential support for the Australian Italian community. Unfortunately, a few weeks ago, the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, in an unwarranted attack, tried to discredit FILEF on the basis of government grants that the organisation had received, mostly to support the cultural endeavours of the organisation.

The basis for the attack was blatantly political. Honourable members opposite who are involved with the Waste Watch Committee do themselves no credit by failing to recognise or give credit to FILEF, which caters for sections of the Italian community, for the good work it does, particularly amongst blue collar workers and the elderly. The book related the experiences of 35 Italian migrant workers and their families. It is compelling reading and a testimony to the courage of ordinary people. An example of some of the experiences given by a woman who subsequently settled in my electorate is typical. It reads:

My husband came in 1952 and at first he couldn't get a job because he couldn't understand English. His aunty in Shepparton had friends in Naracoorte and they wanted a bricklayer to help build a house. My aunty sent him. She wrote on a piece of paper and he had to show it to the people at the railway station, ``Please help this young man catch the train to Naracoorte!''
The story goes on to show how he learned to do many things and many kinds of work:

``He picked tomatoes, picked fruit, helped to build a dam in Murchison, worked as a builder's labourer, everything. He learnt English, he stayed here, I came to join him, we are settled. But he worked around, he worked hard.''
Later she related how her husband wanted to live in Carlton:

A lot of Italians lived there, but he didn't have enough money. He bought land in Thomastown with a bungalow, put three hundred pounds deposit, and started to pay it off. We built the house later. When I came we lived in the bungalow. I was very happy. We were lucky, we didn't have to board with other people, I could stay by myself during the day. But sometimes I was afraid. There was nothing in Thomastown in 1954. There was wilderness, bush all around, the sheep would come and sing songs under my window.

This example, like so many others, provides insight not only into the hardships faced by many migrants but also into the numerous and often unacknowledged day to day ways in which these people have contributed to the development of Australia since their arrival. This is a point worthy of emphasis. Again, in April 1973, the then Minister for Social Security stated:
The presence of migrants in this country has been valuable to the nation and has given it and its people a far better future than would have been achieved otherwise.

The Bill completes the Australian end of a procedure which will see the balance of money flowing between the two countries heavily in our favour. Indeed, in the first year of operation, it is estimated that the Australian Government's outlay of approximately $4.6m will be in contrast to the Italian Government's outlay of $38.3m. Nevertheless, should any of our Italian immigrants return to Italy, the provisions of the agreement constitute a recognition of that proportion of their working life spent in Australia during which time they contributed in all sorts of unseen ways to our development.

In a more general sense, of course, reciprocal social security agreements are an internationally recognised means of protecting the rights of people who move between different countries. Like most other European countries, Italy has a network of agreements designed to ensure that the social security needs of its migrant workers are protected. This agreement with Australia is a further widening of that network.

As the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) indicated, the agreement covers seven Australian benefits and 11 Italian benefits. Because it was difficult to obtain reciprocity on a benefit to benefit basis, due to the differences in the systems, a global approach was finally agreed. The measures will affect some 17,000 people in Australia and some 3,000 in Italy. There are expected to be considerably more people in Italy who will benefit from obtaining payments, but at this stage it has not been possible to confirm that.

Much has been said by honourable members opposite about what they appeared to claim was inadequate consultation in coming to the agreement. They fail to recognise that the Minister was involved in some 50 meetings in Australia with the relevant migrant community groups and those meetings were well before the Government's position was settled. The honourable member for Grayndler indicated that there was a committee of five, including two Italian Australians, which advised the Minister on the way the consultative process should be carried out and on the policy issues involved.

It should be acknowledged also that, over nine formal negotiating sessions totalling 54 days, officials of Italy and Australia exchanged information to enable the negotiation of the agreement. Before the agreement was signed, the Italian Australian community indicated its satisfaction with the Government's approach. That is the important feature. We are talking about negotiations taking place over a considerable period and the fact that a system of consultation has been entered into. I am sure that the problems which the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) outlined with other migrant groups will be catered for in further consultations to set up agreements that will cater for their needs.

Another aspect on which I want to touch is publicity. I know that the Minister appreciates the need for publicity in all facets under his administration. He has a keen appreciation of the needs of the legislation. His electorate of Batman neighbours mine and it has a considerable Italian population. As I have already stated, Italian Australians have made a considerable impression on the development of the northern suburbs of Melbourne. I know that the Minister has a long-standing appreciation of the needs of that community. After the April agreement was put into place, a very effective brochure was produced by the Department. It was in Italian and English. Even more importantly, a bilingual telephone query service was put into place. Those are important measures that I am sure the Minister will keep in mind when the measures covered by the agreement are implemented next year.

It is also hoped that the agreement with Italy will be a catalyst for some of the other migrant source countries. There are about 18 of them. Informal and formal discussions have been ongoing in Australia with the respective communities of those countries. It is hoped that further agreements will be reached when those negotiations have been completed. The agreement and the negotiations which preceded the signing of the agreement provide a workable model for further developments. There is sufficient flexibility, as demonstrated by the results of this agreement, to allow for the peculiarities of the social security systems of other countries.

The Minister, in his second reading speech, emphasised that future agreements will be based on four main principles. It is important to repeat those. The first principle is that of shared responsibility, where each country contributes to a person's social security coverage. The second principle is that of equality of treatment, where the residents and citizens of both countries will be given access to the other country's social security laws. The third principle is totalisation-periods of residence in Australia during working life will be added to periods of contribution in Italy to allow people to meet the minimum period of residence or contributions required for a pension from either country. Lastly, it is on a pro rata basis. The amount of pension paid by Australia will be based on actual residence during working life and Italy will calculate its pension on actual contributions.

The Minister also indicated in his second reading speech that the development of the agreement is based on a four-stage process which will be used as a formula for further agreements. The first stage is the detailed exchange of information, including written material and face to face meetings to enable both countries' officials to understand each other's social security systems. Indeed, the agreement that has been signed does not imply the end of this process. A number of queries were raised by speakers opposite about how some of the technical bureaucratic details would be developed. There will be a continuing process of consultation between officials of the two countries to establish those necessary administrative arrangements. The second part of the process is the consultation with the communities in Australia likely to be affected by the agreement. The honourable member for Grayndler indicated that in this case those procedures had been carried out. I think that the honourable member for Mitchell should await further developments when the agreements with other countries are developed. The third stage of the process is the negotiation of the terms of the agreement, taking into account the community views received from the Australian groups. The fourth stage, which is the stage we are at now with the agreement with Italy, is the legislation, ratification and implementation.

The measures covered by this agreement will be implemented after the ratification by this Government and the Italian Government according to the respective procedures of those governments. It will then come into force on the first day of the month following such ratifications. The passage of this Bill will put Australia in a position where it is ready to ratify the agreement as soon as Italy has completed its parliamentary processes. It is therefore to be hoped that the Italian Government will be in a position early next year to complete its form of procedures so that the measures can be implemented without too much delay by mid-1987. I have much pleasure in supporting this Bill and commending it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with a great deal of pleasure to speak on the Social Security Amendment (Reciprocity with Italy) Bill 1986 because in reality this Bill is a landmark. It marks the culmination of 34 years of striving by Australians of Italian birth or Italian descent to come up with a solution which will provide for them justice and equity. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, knows I am never backward in harshly criticising many of the things he does. It comes as no surprise to him to hear me frequently repeat my opposition to the assets test. But while it is certainly appropriate for me and other members of the Opposition to do our utmost to divert the Minister from his wrong ways, it is also appropriate that when he has done the right thing, I, at least, should stand up and say: `Minister, I praise you. This is a step in the right direction'. I think that when the Minister does the right thing, it is only right, proper, fitting and appropriate that I should praise him-although that may be the kiss of death.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, as has been made clear by some other speakers in this debate, in particular the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the Opposition does have some reservations about the Bill. The honourable member for Richmond pointed out that the Minister's claim that there were all winners and no losers is not necessarily correct. But I will leave that aside and again compliment the Minister on getting this Bill through. As I said, this solution has taken 34 years-until in April 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Italian counterpart, Mr Craxi, signed the agreement which is the basis of this Bill. I welcome it, and I believe that with some modification and some additional consultation, where required, it will serve as a model for the other agreements which will become necessary or are necessary now. We need to make progress with countries such as Greece, Malta, Turkey and Yugoslavia.

I am particularly pleased that the provisions of this Bill will apply to all pensions, particularly age, invalid and widows' pensions. These areas have been a source of major concern to the Italian Australian community. Legislation providing for proportional portability of pensions based on a 25-year working life in Australia is desirable, and as far as I am concerned it is certainly a step in the right direction. The new agreement will mean that a person who has lived in Australia for 10 years will be entitled to a proportional pension if he or she goes back to live in Italy. If the person has lived in Australia for 25 years and goes back, he or she will be entitled to a full pension. Reciprocal arrangements apply through the Italian Government for people who return to live in Australia.

It should be made quite clear that while Italy has a contributory system, the Australian system is funded and based on tax revenue. Italian pensions are based on periods of contribution combined with a level of earnings with a minimum level of pension, while Australia pays a fixed rate pension. In addition, the Italian system applies only to income earners, whereas our system applies to all adults living here.

I am really very pleased that the agreement embodied and introduced in this Bill will enable Australia to pay pensions to many people who have made a very significant contribution to this country but for reasons of their own have chosen to retire and live in Italy. It is most appropriate that we should now make it very clear that there is nothing wrong in this Bill providing benefits to people who have come here, worked and contributed, and who go back to retire in the bosom of their families in their native country. How would any Australians, of whatever ethnic background-Scottish, English or whatever-react if they had lived and worked overseas for a couple of decades and lost out by retiring in their own country? It would be unjust and it would not be right. Therefore, it is extremely appropriate that this should apply.

Every thinking Australian should be proud that some 300,000 people of Italian birth have chosen to come and live in Australia. I was born here, I had no choice in the matter. I am very happy that I was born here. I do not want to live anywhere else. But the people who have come here from other countries have made a deliberate choice. It is like choosing a wife. I think they honour us-

TALK.START.PARA: —They are pioneers.

—They are pioneers. I know the difficulties from personal experience, having worked in the management of migrant hostels for some two years. I know how hard it is for people to up stakes, leave everything, set off on a plane or a boat, and arrive here unable to speak the language and knowing nothing about the country. By crikey, I think every one of us must pay tribute to the migrant people who have come here, and not only to those who have arrived since World War II. All of us, unless we are Aboriginal, are the descendants of migrants. My name, Nehl, has a rather unusual spelling. It comes from a Danish great grandfather. We have all descended from migrants. As the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) so aptly put it a short while ago, the first generations to come to Australia, be it from Italy or wherever, were pioneers. The difficulties that people suffer when coming here are sometimes quite monumental. So I certainly pay tribute to those people of Italian birth who have come here and made such a significant contribution to our economic, social and cultural development in Australia. We have benefited and gained enormously, not only from Italians, of course, but also from the whole range of migrants who have come to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make passing reference to people of Italian descent or birth who live in my electorate. I count myself fortunate indeed that I enjoy the friendship of a great many people of Italian descent. Whether in growing bananas, fishing or any of those productive capacities, they work hard and contribute to the community. They are a definite and valuable part of any community in Australia; this is particularly so of the people to whom I refer. I must take this opportunity to make reference to one lady in particular, Mrs Nellie Spagnolo, who is perhaps the matriarch of the Italian community in Coffs Harbour-a tremendous lady who has made a marvellous contribution to Australia. Of course, there are many, many families of Italian birth and descent-the Costanzos, the Barbaratos, the Dal Pozzos-all of whom have made significant contributions to Australia.

I think that it is probably time we put to rest the outrageous furphy, myth and intolerance that suggests that, where we have pension portability and reciprocity, Australia is paying out money by the tens of millions of dollars. The reality is that from this particular arrangement Australia will gain a great deal of money. Unfortunately, wherever one finds a little nest of prejudice or intolerance one gets people who pour forth vicious, vile rumours and try to destroy and divide. I think that every one of us in this place should take every opportunity to let Australia know that there is no truth in the claims of the people who go around saying these sorts of things. I will not even use the words they say, but they make pejorative references to people whom we all respect. These people claim that the money is rolling out of Australia back to those people living in other countries. I think it was the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay)-yes, indeed, it was you, Mr Deputy Speaker, when making your measured and worthwhile contribution to this debate a little while ago--

TALK.START.PARA: —He always does.

—As the honourable member for Lyne said, he always does. He speaks thoughtfully and makes a very valued contribution. The honourable member for Grayndler pointed out that something like 17,000 Australian residents of Italian birth will benefit from the Italian Government. On the other hand, only 3,000 back in Italy will benefit from the Australian Government. I think this particular instance makes it very clear that the benefit is coming to Australia and to Australians, because those people of Italian birth or heritage are first and foremost now Australian. There are very few indeed who do not see themselves as Australians. That is why they came here-to contribute to Australia-and indeed they have made that contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to amplify and provide a basis for those statements I have just made. It should be noted that the financial impact of the changes in the years 1987-88, 1988-89 and 1989-90 will be very significant for us because, after all, the net inflow to Australia in 1987-88 will be $35.2m. In the next year, 1988-89, it will be $36.5m. The amount will rise again in 1989-90 to $37.9m. That is the net extra income to Australia after the outflow of payments from Australia to Italy. So let nobody tell me or anybody else in this Parliament that Australia is not benefiting from this Bill. Again, I would really like to compliment the Minister for what he has achieved with this measure and I look forward to his taking further steps down the track for other migrant groups in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least you are on good terms with him on this matter.

—The Minister knows where I stand on the assets test. But I was also interested to hear the remarks of previous speakers. I think it was the honourable member for Mitchell who raised the matter of the assets test and its application. I hope that the Minister for Social Security, who is at the table, is able to get around to looking at this matter. I know that he and the rest of the Cabinet are occupied looking at minor discrepancies in the fringe benefits tax at the moment. Of course, the people of Australia know that there is no solution to these problems except for the abolition of this tax, which will happen when the Hawke socialist Government goes out of power and the coalition takes office. I must take this opportunity to say again once and for all that the assets test will go and I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that deep in your heart you will be glad that it is gone, too, because, as I have said already, your contribution to the Parliament is always significant.
—I think I asked another honourable member yesterday not to involve the Chair in his own debating techniques. I would not like the honourable member for Cowper to put words into my mouth.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, if you are going to make that sort of observation, surely you should have made it a little earlier when I was praising you. At least you should be consistent.
—I thought you were putting those words into other people's mouths.

—Oh, no. I would also like to say that I was particularly pleased by the attention given to this debate by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who unfortunately are not able to be with us at this moment, but were for most of the debate. I pay particular tribute to the contributions from the honourable member for Richmond and the honourable member for Mitchell. I have already mentioned the contribution from the honourable member for Grayndler, but I would also like to mention in passing the contribution made by the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins). He is, indeed, the true son of a great father, and he is filling that seat very well. He was not always right on the track, of course. He is misguided, but perhaps with a little time, a little more age and a little more knowledge he will be able to tread the straight and narrow path. But I certainly pay tribute to him.

SPEECH.PARA: Before this debate is concluded, we will have probably three more speakers. I know that the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard), in his usual way, will make a contribution that will be stimulating and rewarding for the people who are lucky enough to hear it. Of course, the next speaker for the coalition, the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), needs no introduction to the members of the Italian community living in his electorate, because he is with them all the time and has a tremendous interest. I know of no member in this House who takes a greater interest in the Italian community and in serving and working for that community than the honourable member for Riverina-Darling.

Of course, the final speaker in this debate will be the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). I must confess that I do find it a little difficult to surround the honourable member for Capricornia with the same degree of harmony and praise that I have provided for other speakers in this debate. It seems to me-I say this with the greatest good will-that the honourable member for Capricornia, when he speaks in this place, spends most of his time barking rather like a castrated sea-lion, or, perhaps, bellowing like a mickey bull. I say, with all the good will in the world, that I know that the honourable member for Capricornia, when he gets up in a little while, will get stuck into me like anything, because this is what he does. All he does when he comes here is attack people.

I just want to say, in concluding my contribution to this debate, that we, whether on the honourable member's side of the House or on this side, are all seeking to serve Australia. I have the greatest respect for the vast majority of people on the Government benches as individuals. But I think that it is fitting, proper and appropriate that we deal with each other with a degree of respect and, hopefully, a degree of liking-that is possible in the vast majority of cases-and make positive contributions, not just attack people endlessly. I do not believe that the purposes of this place or of the people of Australia are served by negative attacks. I am probably guilty of doing that at this moment. But I repeat that I make these comments not in any harsh frame of mind. I have listened to and observed the virulent and sometimes vicious approach of the honourable member for Capricornia.
