SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Social Security Amendment (Reciprocity with Italy) Bill 1986, which seeks to implement the cost sharing reciprocal social security agreement with Italy. I feel that I have a very hard task in doing so because the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), with the fine bonhomie that he displayed in the debate this afternoon, is a very hard act to follow. I feel that I should acknowledge the fact that at least the honourable member was prepared to give credit where credit is due, to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table. In debate on a Bill in which there is a fair degree of bipartisanship, it is obvious that what we have had from the honourable member for Cowper is a genuine expression of how he views the Bill. Unfortunately, this contrasts with the somewhat carping criticism of the Bill from other members of the Opposition who have contributed to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Cowper and the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) have said, Italian migrants have played an important role in the economic and social development of Australia in the post-war years. As we have already heard, today there are about 300,000 persons resident in Australia who were born in Italy. It is useful to remember that the first reciprocal agreement, the first attempt to look at this area of reciprocal agreements, goes back as far as 1943 when this country decided to have a reciprocal agreement with New Zealand. At that time it related to just age and invalid pensions; it was not the sort of agreement that we are talking about here. It was not until 1953 that the first agreement with the United Kingdom was reached. That agreement covered a fairly wide range of benefits. Now, 43 years on, we are entering what I consider to be a new phase of reciprocal arrangements in the social welfare area.

The initial thrust for a reciprocal social security agreement came from Italy in 1952. As was pointed out by previous speakers, Italy, like most other European countries, has a network of agreements designed to protect the social security rights of its immigrant workers. The absence of a comprehensive agreement with Australia represented a significant gap in that network. It should be noted that the Italian Australian community generally welcomes the agreement, although there are of course some concerns that there may be delays in implementing the agreement.

Australia amended its law for payment of pensions overseas on 1 July 1986. That legislation introduced a concept of proportional portability. This concept means that pensions generally will be paid outside the country on a proportional basis according to the period of residence in Australia of the claimant during a working life of 25 years. The amended law for payment of pensions overseas in fact provided a basis for cost sharing arrangements of which the Australia-Italy agreement is the first. This agreement embodies basic principles which will be reflected in all future agreements. Again, it has been mentioned that currently about 18 other countries have indicated an interest in negotiating a cost sharing agreement with Australia.

I will turn to the principles of an agreement. The first principle is that of shared responsibility. Each country will contribute to a person's social security coverage. The second principle is equality of treatment. This means that the residents and citizens of each country will be given access to the other country's social security laws. The third principle is totalisation. This means that periods of residence in Australia during a person's working life will be added to periods of contributions in Italy to allow people to meet the minimum period of residence or period of contributions required for a pension from either country. The fourth principle is that of the pro rata basis. The amount of pension paid by Australia will be based on actual residence in Australia during a person's working life; Italy will calculate its pensions on the period of actual contributions.

The agreement is wide ranging and will cover people who move between Australia and Italy, enabling them to qualify for a large number of Italian and Australian social security benefits. The effect of the agreement will be that no person will be disadvantaged. It is estimated that some 17,000 people in Australia and some 3,000 people in Italy will benefit when the agreement starts to operate. In the first year of the scheme Australia will outlay approximately $4.6m on social security payments while Italy will be required to pay about $38.3m. This debunks the argument that has been heard in this debate that this agreement, when finalised, will cost this country money. In fact, the reverse is the case.

The agreement has a large degree of flexibility. Claimants will be able to apply for Australian benefits while living in Italy and to apply for Italian benefits while resident in Australia. Additionally, people currently not eligible will be able to make up the minimum eligibility period for the benefits covered-that is, for an age pension, 10 years in Australia and 15 years in Italy-by combining the period of Australian residence with the period of contributions in Italy during their working life. Australian benefits to be paid in Italy will generally be a proportion of the rate based on a person's actual residence in Australia during a 25-year working life. For example, a person in Italy who has had 10 years residence in Australia could qualify for 10/25ths of an income/assets tested Australian pension. Applicants for Italian unemployment benefit will be able to count Australian employment for eligibility purposes. Australian unemployment benefit is not included in the agreement as anyone coming to Australia as a permanent resident and able to meet the normal requirements for unemployment benefit has access to that benefit.

At this point I must pay tribute to those persons from both this country and Italy who were involved in the very delicate negotiations that took place prior to the reaching of the present agreement. It is difficult to obtain reciprocity on a benefit to benefit basis due to basic differences in the social security systems of two countries. If one thinks of the exchange of information provisions for the agreement, they required delicate negotiations because of genuine concerns about confidentiality and privacy.

Another issue which must be emphasised is the consultative process which was involved. The Minister for Social Security has been sensitive to the need for full consultation with migrant community groups, despite what was said by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). In fact, as we have already heard in this debate, the Minister had 50 meetings with such groups before the Government's position was finalised; yet the honourable member for Mitchell tried to argue the need for full consultation. The consultation was there. Additionally a committee of five, including two Italian Australians, advised the Minister on the consultative process and on policy issues. There were nine formal negotiating sessions, totalling 54 days, to exchange information and negotiate the agreement. It is clear from what I have said that the Minister has attempted to ensure that consultations were carried out to the fullest. There is a large measure of agreement within the Italian Australian community that the agreement will benefit that community. It is good to see that the Opposition does not intend to divide on this matter and supports the measure in general terms. I therefore support the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the Social Security Amendment (Reciprocity with Italy) Bill is to provide implementation of the reciprocal agreement on social security signed with Italy on 23 April this year. It involves minor amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 to ensure that the agreement meshes with the Act. Reciprocal social security agreements are formal arrangements which countries enter into to ensure that people who move between them receive social security pensions on a fair and equitable basis. Like the agreement with Italy, Australia's future agreements will be based on principles that are in line with international practice. The first of those principles is shared responsibility-and I know that these matters have been mentioned by previous speakers-under which each party to the agreement will contribute to a person's total social security coverage. The second is equality of treatment, whereby the residents and citizens of both countries will be given equal access to each other's social security laws. The third is totalisation. Periods of residence and/or contributions in both countries will be added together to give people the minimum period of residence or contributions required to qualify for a pension from either or both countries. The fourth is a pro-rata basis. The total amount of pension to be paid by each country to people residing in the other will be based on the length of a person's residence or contributions. The Social Security Proportional Portability of Pensions Act 1986 enabled this principle to be adopted for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that Italy's social security system is contribution based. It depends on the period of contribution applicable to salaries while Australia's is needs based and provides for indexed flat rate pensions which are subject to the income and assets test. This legislation provides that residents of Australia on 8 May 1985 who qualify for pensions and leave Australia before 1 January 1996 will not be subject to proportional portability. This development has been long awaited by Australian and Italian citizens, and no doubt people from other countries, who are looking forward to reciprocal agreements between their nation of birth and Australia.

Unfortunately, there have been a few problems, and I understand from various media reports-and I do not know whether this is true; this is only what I have read-that there has been a lack of consultation, although a number of speakers in this debate have praised the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and said that this is not the truth. But there seems to be some misunderstanding in that area. The shadow Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), has explained to the House some of the anomalies that may arise and I am sure that the Minister will look into them. One problem that has arisen is that a number of citizens have telephoned my office asking me to explain how exactly the Bill will work. I have done some study of the matter and I think I am reasonably clear about it, but I would ask the Minister to assist the ethnic communities of Australia by issuing a simple document to explain to those people exactly how the legislation will work. Some people are confused about its effects.

This is not the first reciprocal agreement that has been signed by Australia. I understand that social security agreements were signed with New Zealand in 1943 by the Curtin Government and with the United Kingdom in 1954. I am pleased that Italy is the first non-English speaking nation to enter into an agreement with Australia. It is fitting that agreement has been achieved with the great country of Italy. Most people would agree with me that there is something special about the Italian nation. Italy has given the world Leonardo Da Vinci, Michelangelo, Fermi, Nervi, Caruso and Marconi, to mention a few. I know that other honourable members could give similar examples.

Italy has contributed so many migrants to Australia. In fact, there are in Australia today nearly 300,000 people who where born in Italy. Indeed, there are a million people in this country one of whose parents were born in Italy. If we look to those with at least one grandparent born in Italy, we find an even greater number-some 9 per cent of Australia's population is of direct Italian heritage. I believe that this is a great thing for Australia and I know that most Australians are proud of that fact. In looking at the Italian heritage and in mentioning some famous Italians of the past, one must appreciate that they lived in an Italy that was not the united nation it is today. One has only to look at Italian design to appreciate the achievements of Italians. Who in the world other than the Italians could have produced a Lamborghini, an Alfa Romeo or a Maserati? Very few people could have given us such fine example of design.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have the greatest sense of style in the world.

—I agree that they are the greatest stylists in the world. One has only to look at Italian furniture to see the truth of that statement. Italy is renowned for its furniture and perhaps the greatest designs come from that country. The same argument applies to Italian clothing designs. One knows that the Italians dress with flair and that their fashion designs are magnificent. In thinking of Australians of Italian heritage, one has in mind particularly Carla Zampatti, who has international fame, or Nevis Piccoli of Griffith. Both have a great flair for design and dress sense. One also has in mind the earthmovers of Australia such as Abignano, one of the greatest earthmoving companies in Australia, or Jim Ambrosini, who has done most of his work in the Wilcannia area and who now resides in Adelaide. These are all people of whom we can be proud.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish briefly to touch on my electorate of Riverina-Darling, which is approximately the size of Italy. Although we have a large number of Italians and people of Italian heritage in the electorate, we could nowhere match the population of Italy, which I believe is over 60 million. The contribution of those Italian residents to my electorate, whether in the growing of wheat, rice, citrus crops or wine grapes, is unquestionable. I mention some of the wineries in the area-Rossetto and Sons, the Lillypilly Estate Winery of the Fiumara family, De Bortoli Wines Pty Ltd, San Bernadino Wines, Cinzano (Aust) Pty Ltd, Rubertos of Hay, Franco's Wines and Miranda Wines Pty Ltd. These are all people of Italian heritage who have added not only to my electorate but also to Australia's heritage. They have changed our way of eating and drinking; they are masters of cuisine and have added greatly to our heritage.

Some people in Australia think of Italian migration or migration of other people to this country as flowing from the Second World War. However, some four million migrants have come to Australia since that time. As the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) said earlier, we are a nation of migrants. There are theories that even the Aboriginal people in their different way came to Australia. But certainly since the white man came to Australia, we are the sons, grandsons or great grandsons of migrants-an aspect which some people tend to forget. As I am talking about the Italian population, I would refer honourable members to a recently published book whose author Father Tito, of the Scallabrini order, now resides in the River Murray town of Red Cliffs. The book is entitled Non Siamo Arrivati Ieri. That means `We did not arrive here yesterday'. That is true, because the Italians have had a connection with Australia since the days of Captain Cook. I do not think that many people realise that. This book is written in Italian, but it will soon be published in English and I am sure that most honourable members will get a copy and read it so they can see what a great contribution the people of Italy have made to Australia.

When I speak to my Italian friends in my electorate I think of the great Snowy Mountains scheme and all those people who came here after the Second World War to work on that scheme. I would suggest that anyone who has not been to the Snowy Mountains to look at that scheme should do so, particularly if he or she is a child of grandchild of a migrant who worked on that scheme. Anyone in that position could feel justly proud after seeing the work that was done there. I was recently in Italy, where I was talking about this reciprocal arrangement with Italians who had returned to their country of origin. I spoke particularly to people in northern Italy who worked on the Snowy Mountains scheme. Some of them worked in water up to their chests and in dangerous conditions. Some of them did not live to return to their country of origin. We are very proud of them and their country is also proud of them.

Let us look at farmers in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area, particularly in Griffith and Leeton. The Italians there have a great heritage and they have done much great work from 1912 onwards. Let us look at the miners of Broken Hill and Mount Isa, many of Italian origin. I believe that the first people who came into the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area were from the Broken Hill area. The honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) will know well the colony of `new Italy' which consisted of Italian migrants who settled in Australia before this century. I believe that there was some heartache in that settlement, but the remains of it are still there and the Italian heritage is very much in evidence. While I am speaking about the honourable member for Page, I must refer to the great work that he did in the Inter-Parliamentary Union when he spoke with the Italian Government about this problem of reciprocal arrangements in the area of social security. If we look at any field of activity in Australia, whether is be commerce, farming, fashion, industry or government, we find people of Italian origin. They are in the most isolated mining camps of Australia and in the major metropolitan areas.

In my area, the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area, when many of these farmers of Italian origin retire, they move into the towns of Leeton and Griffith. I invite any honourable members to visit these towns and any other towns in the area and see the meticulous way in which those people care for their homes and the surroundings. Both Leeton and Griffith are beautiful towns and provide an excellent example of assimilation. I am one of those people who are very much afraid of the word `multicultural' because I really do not know what it means. If honourable members come to Griffith or Leeton, they will see assimilation. Whether the people are from Friuli, Venezia, Calabria, Sicily, Toscana, Romagnana or any of those places, they work together well and they are really great Australian citizens. In Griffith last night there was a meeting of the tourist association calling together all the people to see how they could promote the area. I would like to see the tourist association promote the Italian influence in Griffith because it has been a wonderful blessing to the town. Those people have stood shoulder to shoulder with migrants from other countries and with Australians to develop that area. I am not saying that the Italians are the only people who have done anything; they certainly are not. However, they have stood shoulder to shoulder with the others and faced the ups and downs.

In conclusion, I repeat what the honourable member for Cowper said earlier: There are some people in Australia who begrudge the right of these people to return to the country of their birth. This applies not only to the Italian people but also to Greeks, Germans and so on. I do not agree with those people because if we think of the great work that these immigrants have done on the Snowy Mountains Scheme and in other areas, we must realise that if they have any yearning to return to the country of their origin, they have earned the right to do so. Australia will certainly benefit more than Italy from this agreement, but that is beside the point. I am sure that most thinking Australians would agree with me that this reciprocal arrangement can do only good for Australian citizens.

I pay tribute to honourable members who have spoken on this Bill, particularly the honourable member for Cowper, our Shadow Minister-the honourable member for Richmond-and the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). I support this Bill. I hope that, if there are any problems arising from it, particularly in relation to the dissemination of information to enable the various ethnic groups to understand the situation, the Minister will take note of them. That will certainly be much appreciated. Anomalies have been mentioned and I hope that the Minister will look at those and try to sort them out. I am sure that Australians of Italian heritage in my electorate will welcome this Bill and I am sure that all migrant groups will welcome what the Minister has done here and what he is doing to develop other agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the Bill: This legislation is evidence of the fact that perseverence pays off. As other honourable members have pointed out, discussions have been continuing between the Australian and Italian governments for many years. In fact, the discussion started something like 34 years ago. Over more than three decades constant representations were made to the Australian Government and the Italian Government by the Italian community to set up reciprocal arrangements. I was going to give credit to the honourable member for Cowper because at least he gave credit to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), which was not the total thrust of the speech of the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman).

The agreement was signed in Rome this year and the necessary legislation is now being debated in this House. As the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) explained, Australia will be the overall beneficiary under this agreement. Clearly both governments will have to contribute, but if one measures the amount of contributions one finds that the Italian Government will spend approximately $38m in any one year as against the $4.6m that will be paid by the Australian Government. When this agreement is finally dealt with by the Italian Parliament some 17,000 people in Australia and 3,000 people in Italy will benefit. Under the agreement each country will contribute to a person's social security coverage and the residents and citizens of each country will be given access to the other country's social security laws. This has to be applauded. The amount of pension paid by Australia will be based upon actual residence during a person's working life, while Italy will calculate its pensions based upon actual contributions by the recipient. We all accept that it has taken a long time to finalise the agreement, but given that Italy will soon take action, the new scheme should prevail next year.

I noted that the honourable member for Mitchell, regardless of the pluses and positive aspects of this legislation, still had to criticise the Government. I suppose that is the role of the Opposition and having been in that role in Queensland I understand it. The honourable member talked about a patch-up approach. I note also that he criticised the Government about the New Zealand situation, where some New Zealanders have come here and have been having holidays around the country while bludging on our social welfare system.

Let us make a comparison between this Government and previous governments. This is the Government which has acted on the Italian-Australian agreement. I have mentioned that the agreement has taken 34 years to complete, since 1952. The Liberal-National Party coalition which sits opposite was in power for 28 of those 34 years. It is worth noting that nothing was achieved during that time. We can contrast that inaction and apathy with the expeditious way in which the Minister for Social Security and this Labor Government have acted on this matter in the three years since we were elected in March 1983; the agreement was signed in April of this year. The Opposition, instead of being critical, should at least give due credit.

The situation is exactly the same with regard to the New Zealand problem. New Zealanders have been coming to Australia for years and years. We had a reciprocal arrangement with New Zealand, going back to 1949, which simply allowed New Zealanders to land here and state that they would be permanent residents, then automatically claim social security benefits. I followed up this matter this year. Some figures given to me at that time showed that 400 Australians were receiving social security benefits in New Zealand, but some 11,000 New Zealanders were getting benefits in Australia.

Earlier this year I took it upon myself to approach the Minister for Social Security with a list of cases of abuse of the system, particularly on the east coast, but also in most capital cities. A person would go to Adelaide and apply for a social security benefit and would next be found enjoying the beautiful weather of Cairns. There were cases and cases of people coming into Australia and abusing officers in the Department of Social Security because those officers would not automatically give them a pension. In one instance it was well known in Brisbane that if someone could not get his or her way with the Department of Social Security people, he or she went to a certain senator who is the wife of the Queensland Premier and her staff would ring up and question why that person had not received a social security benefit. If that figure of 11,000 is correct, as I have every reason to believe it is, it means that Australian taxpayers are paying $1m a week or $50m a year, calculated on an average of $100 per person.

I congratulate the Minister not only on acting on the Italian-Australian agreement but also on acting on that complaint and on the revision of the social security agreement between Australia and New Zealand. This Government has taken action to stop the waste, fraud, misuse and abuse under the system. New Zealanders coming to Australia now will not be able to claim unemployment benefits during the first six months. Only after there has been a six-month period of residence and they can show that they have been working for at least two months, or have purchased a home, are they eligible to claim benefits. This Government has taken that sort of action, yet time after time members of the Opposition stand up here and criticise us, as the honourable member for Mitchell did. During the eight years that the Opposition was in government, from 1975 to 1983, New Zealanders flooded across the Tasman. The problem was there, but the Opposition did nothing to solve it. Opposition members are always quick to criticise but very slow to give credit. I had a note to give credit to the honourable member for Cowper, because at least he got up and gave credit where credit was due, but Opposition members are quick to forget their inaction and procrastination. I know that the honourable member for Cowper will call a quorum and it will be typical of him. Did you bring in your mate to call a quorum?

—After the quorum called by the Opposition Deputy Whip, it is easy to see the lack of interest shown by the Opposition in this debate. I was making the point that Opposition members are quick to criticise the Government but easily forget their inaction, procrastination and apathy in dealing with matters which affect the quality of life of those Australians who are aged or disadvantaged. It was the Hawke Labor Government which, in its first Budget, in 1983, introduced a remote area allowance for people on social security and living in tax zone A. It has also been the Hawke Labor Government that has reversed the downward trend of the age pension under the Fraser Government compared with average male earnings. SPEECH.PARA: It has been the Hawke Labor Government that has acted to address the poverty traps. The family income supplement has been increased by 70 per cent, from $10 to $17 a week. From July 1987, the additional income that pensioners can earn for each child will double, from $6 to $12 a week. The additional pension for children has been increased from $10 to $17 a week. The assistance given for pensioners renting privately has been increased by 50 per cent, from $10 to $15 a week. This has been the Government that introduced a carer's pension that is paid to a person providing constant care and attention for a severely handicapped or infirm relative.

If one contrasts that with the record of the Opposition, one finds that we have a Liberal-National Party Opposition that wants to abolish the unemployment benefit for the long term unemployed. Now it is wanting to get rid of the unemployment benefit for people under 21 years of age. It wants to privatise the social security system. It wants to slash welfare spending by $3.5 billion. It wants to introduce compulsory work for single parents and the unemployed. It wants to abolish the assets test and allow people with $500,000 in the bank to get a pension. On the other hand, it wants to make the poor pay more tax and the rich pay less tax. It wants to abolish or tax family allowances. Yet it says that it really cares. I think the record shows what the situation is.

As I said earlier, I welcome this Bill because it is the beginning of major changes in reciprocal social security arrangements. Whilst we have now acted in relation to the Italian situation, the people of Australia ought to know that an Australian delegation is visiting the United Kingdom this month to discuss renegotiation of the United Kingdom agreement. The items on the agenda will include indexation of United Kingdom pensions in Australia, negotiations along the lines of the Australian model agreement and working holidaymakers. An Australian delegation visited New Zealand in July, and a new draft agreement has been prepared for consideration by both governments. This draft addresses the problems of New Zealanders receiving the unemployment benefit, to which I referred before. Fact finding discussions are taking place in Athens, Greece, this month. The Greek community will be informed of the results of the exchange and will be consulted as to whether negotiations should take place. Fact finding discussions are taking place in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, this month. There is a possible visit by a Spanish delegation for informal discussions later this year. Preliminary discussions began in December last year in Bonn, West Germany, and Vienna, Austria, and further negotiations will take place in November and December this year. A Canadian delegation visited Canberra during April for preliminary discussions, and an Australian delegation will visit Ottawa in October for detailed negotiations. Even Malta and Switzerland are being covered.

The point that I make in conclusion is that this is the Government that is redressing the problems when it comes to reciprocal arrangements for those who are on social security benefits. This is the Government that ought to be commended for taking the steps and showing the initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I begin by thanking people for their contributions to the debate on the Social Security Amendment (Reciprocity with Italy) Bill. This Bill represents the culmination of discussions that have gone on for a very long time. It is an historic agreement between Australia and Italy. An illustration of what I think must have been one of the more extensive processes of community consultation, leading to the legislation on proportional portability and then to this Bill, is the fact that we would not sign agreements without there being a specific Bill in relation to each agreement. The purpose of that was to make it very clear to the various communities that nothing would be done in anything but the full light of day and that people, and indeed the Parliament, would have the opportunity to scrutinise the agreements as they are achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) has come into the House. I made a reference earlier today to his mendacity, which I withdrew at the time and for which no doubt I could have apologised. I made that reference to the honourable member because he has deliberately failed to represent accurately publicly the fact that he and I had a conversation within this Parliament in which I made it clear, very early in the time for which I have been Minister, that in the process of renegotiating the agreement between Australia and New Zealand we would deal with the questions of the unemployment benefit and the supporting parent benefit as matters that were properly of concern in Australia. I having informed the honourable member that that was my intention and of the sensitivity in terms of Australia-New Zealand relations on this issue, he went ahead and made a series of public statements which resulted in what I think was a fairly rare occurrence in that Ann Hercus, the New Zealand Minister, and I felt that we needed to put out a joint statement deploring the attacks, which were, in my view, often indiscriminate, on New Zealanders in Australia. Ann Hercus and I were both quite concerned about the questions of fraud and people misrepresenting their circumstances. There is a certain relationship on some matters in which I think some respect and some sensitivity could be shown. With respect to the question of New Zealanders, the honourable member for Richmond has simply sought to use it as a political football. I guess that he has got some small advantage out of that, but frankly I do not respect him for it.

I go to the more specific points that were made in the contribution by the honourable member for Richmond, which completely lacked any graciousness, which was somewhat carping and which seemed to show very little understanding of the facts. There seemed to be some suggestion that, even though the Opposition joined the Government in supporting this measure, there would have to be anomalies; there would have to be people who would lose somehow as a result of this social security agreement between Australia and Italy.

The honourable member, who had his speech interrupted by lunch, lost no opportunity today-not a day for the long lunch-to get out a Press release outlining the principal points made in his speech. He nominates two specific cases in which he suggests that people may lose as a result of this agreement. He cites the case of someone who arrived in Australia around 8 May 1985-I think it was the day before-who is here for 10 years, having arrived in Australia at something like 55 years of age, and then who leaves Australia, as I understand it, just after 1 January 1996. The honourable member claims-I think correctly-that such a person will be eligible for only something like 43 per cent of the Australian pension. Would not someone who is aged 55 years and who has come from Italy have some rights with respect to the Italian social security system? He is very likely to be insured and, simply as a result of that insurance, on his return to Italy he would be able to pick up some rights. Even if he were not insured, even if he were on a minimal pension, by virtue of this agreement he would certainly be receiving in Italy something like the equivalent of the Australian pension. In most instances he would receive rather more in total as a result. Is the honourable member for Richmond seriously suggesting that, despite the fact that Senator Chaney talked about proportional portability and 40 years, there is something unfair about someone being 10 years in Australia, receiving his proportion from the Australian Government, returning to an agreed country and then receiving the balance? It seems that that is what proportional portability is all about. That is simply an illustration of the principles that are involved in the Bill.

A further problem-apparently it is a sufficient problem to merit its inclusion in the Press release of the honourable member for Richmond-is posed by those who go to a country with which we have a reciprocal agreement without full portability and who have no pension entitlement because it is not their country of origin. As we have been talking about Italians, let us take the position of the Italian who prefers to go to Greece rather than to return to his native Italy. He is someone who presumably will have some entitlements by virtue of the agreement in Italy, and some entitlements in Australia by virtue of proportional portability. That person is helped by the Italian-Australian agreement to achieve portability of the Italian rights that he has as someone who spent time in Italy. The current agreement would be quite relevant to someone receiving a pension in Greece. An Italian in that position would have rights under the Australian social security system and the Italian social security system. The Press release states:

Those people born in Europe, who work in Australia then return to Europe but don't return to their country of origin are in a real bind. As the number of agreements increase this problem will trap more and more people.

One of the problems of the honourable member for Richmond is that he is fundamentally lazy. He is not prepared to do the necessary work and prepare for what I think is an important measure. We intend to achieve a network of agreements and we have allowed ourselves a period of time--

TALK.START.PARA: —But what about the Europeans?

—The honourable gentlemen has had his say and I will have mine. We have allowed ourselves a period of time to achieve a network of agreements. Someone of Italian origin who has spent time as a guest worker in Germany and comes to Australia to work here for a period could receive part pensions from all three countries as a result of a network of social security agreements. There are obviously quite strong possibilities that we shall achieve quite a comprehensive network of agreements with European countries over the 10 years. It seems that the honourable member for Richmond has not done his homework. To issue such a Press release is some kind of joke.

SPEECH.PARA: We move on from the Bill, which seems not greatly to have interested the honourable member for Richmond, to a number of problems that really have nothing to do with the measure that is before us, which deals with the Australian-Italian agreement. Others have talked about New Zealand and I have touched on it myself, but the honourable member referred to portability and asked why portability is not included in the renegotiated agreement. I cannot make New Zealand introduce portability. All that I can do is argue for it. I can understand and accept a commitment to conduct an inquiry into portability. I can set a time limit, in a sense, to allow the agreement to run, and the New Zealand agreement provides for three years during which the matter can be discussed. I can accept the fact that there are quite difficult problems and serious reasons why New Zealand has not introduced portability at this stage. I hope that it will do so, and I have put that view strongly to the New Zealanders. I think that the model of proportional portability might be a solution to some of the problems that New Zealand sees in the South Pacific.

Let it not be suggested that somehow I am unaware of, not taking seriously, or not trying to meet the problems. In many instances I am aware of them and trying to deal with them long before they are mentioned. The honourable member for Richmond referred to a 38-page or 41-page child support paper. He complained in the House yesterday that it had come to his attention only two hours previously and that he had had no opportunity to read it. I know where the honourable member was for the two hours in question and I know also that he had every opportunity to read it. It is a pity that propositions were thrown away, as it were. If the honourable member had read the paper and other work on maintenance he would know how complicated and difficult a subject it is. The proposition that is included in the discussion paper on child support is one which does not go merely to enforcement but to a method of assessing the relevant contribution from liable parents. That has been a major problem in the history of discussion of maintenance. I hope that Parliament will address this issue. The honourable member for Richmond referred to the $87m that we are contributing to former Australian citizens who are living overseas. He spoke as if this were an immense sum that we would not be able to monitor and control. He should understand that $300m is being paid into Australia by overseas governments and pension schemes currently and that the problem to which he refers arises for all the governments that are paying moneys into Australia. They are not always able to locate people in Australia but there are different ways of achieving--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the assets test?

—The honourable member is obsessed about the assets test. Other countries have wealth taxes and regulations that are implemented to assess people's real wealth. Such assessments are not confined to current income when there are payments that might be made. We can deal with the assets test when we come to the Social Security Bill so I shall not allow myself to be drawn on that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) said that there had been a dearth of figures. Estimates in this area are difficult to achieve and are often chancy, but they have been provided by a number of contributors to the debate. The figures suggest that the agreement is of considerable value to Australia in terms of net flows of funds. I do not think that anyone would argue that the agreement is not favourable. At the same time it is difficult to estimate what the balances would be across the range of agreements. It is difficult to be precise.

We have done a great deal of work on consultation but it is my view that we should proceed fairly slowly and cautiously with future agreements. Some of the discussions which have been referred to are at an early stage and represent exchanges of information. Where there are substantial negotiations, I shall ensure that consultations occur along the lines that were set out in the second reading speech, namely, appropriate procedures. I appreciate very much the contribution of several members of the National Party in the debate. I shall take up the problem raised by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks). It is important that we communicate effectively with communities and I shall try to ascertain whether there are any special measures that we need to take in the area which he represents. In my electorate we recently ran a quite well-attended seminar for Italians on the agreement. I think that I am probably running out of time so I shall close by thanking honourable members for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

Bill (on motion by Mr Howe) read a third time.
