SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill has the purpose of winding up the activities of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia. I might say with no thanks to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford), who made the second reading speech and did not mention it, that it also seeks to have the remuneration of the Governor, the Deputy Governor and Board members of the Reserve Bank subject to the determination of the Remuneration Tribunal. At present, the remuneration of those people is determined by the Governor-General. The Opposition has no objection to that second half of the Bill, but it would have been nice to have it mentioned by the Minister in his second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The main part of the Bill is the winding up of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank. The Rural Credits Department was established in 1925 to make short term advances to statutory marketing authorities and to co-operative associations of primary producers to assist in the marketing, processing or manufacture of primary products. Those arrangements helped to smooth seasonal fluctuations by providing finance in advance of sales. Essentially, it was short term accommodation. In the early days, and up until more recently, finance was provided at rates of interest lower than market rates. So there was an element of subsidy involved in the activities of the Rural Credits Department.

In the past, the largest borrower has been the Australian Wheat Board, which accounted for about 75 per cent of the borrowings. However, in recent years the Board has relied on its own commercial funding. That was perhaps the biggest slice of lending from the Rural Credits Department removed. Both the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System, which was established by the present Government, had recommended the phasing out of the Rural Credits Department.

Since the two reports were presented over the past few years advances by the RCD, which had previously been at concessional rates, have been brought into line with market rates. This, together with the fact that customers had made alternative financing arrangements, led to a substantial decline in advances and number of borrowings, quite apart from the removal of the Wheat Board's borrowing.

The phasing out of the Rural Credits Department was announced by the Government in April this year. Certain areas have still been assisted in a relatively minor way compared with previous levels of activity. These have included advances in dairy products, rice and cotton and, to a lesser extent, superphosphate, canned and dried fruits, eggs, sugar and ginger. The Opposition agrees with the proposal which was recommended initially by the Campbell Committee, which was established by the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he was Treasurer, and confirmed by the Martin group that was set up by the present Government to look at financial markets in much the same way as the Campbell Committee.

However, we express some concern about the fact that there is an avenue for the supply of research funds from the RCD. A number of smaller industries which have not generally been supported by the more established forms of funding for rural research have relied on the profits of the RCD to fund their research. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:
Consideration will be given to supplementing funds available for rural research in future years as the activities of the RCD are phased out.

There is no commitment from the Government to do that. No procedure is indicated by which the Government would actually do that. We are concerned that that funding for the smaller areas in rural research should continue. Therefore, the Opposition moves:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is concerned that the Government has not made alternative arrangements for replacing the funds normally generated for rural research from the activities, now to be phased out, of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank'.

The amendment will be seconded by my friend the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I shall not delay the House further as I know that other members wish to speak. It is a rationalisation measure. It is part of the reforms of the financial system recommended by the Campbell Committee. Clearly, it is not a proper function for the Reserve Bank, as a central bank, to be involved in the supply of rural credits. Under a deregulated financial system, it is proper that these funds be supplied in a commercial manner. If any assistance is to be provided to rural industries-in many instances there is a need-that should be provided by explicit action of the Government rather than through a particular department of the Reserve Bank. The Opposition will not oppose the measure. It merely draws attention to the need for the Government to give a quite explicit undertaking that the important rural research funds provided previously by the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank will be provided in some other manner.
DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay)- Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.
—Before calling the honourable member for Charlton, I call the honourable member for Gilmore, who wishes to make a personal explanation.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, I do. Earlier today in Question Time, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) said that I had been wrong in a Press release announcing the coalition's drugs task force survey of recipients of government funding under the drug offensive launched in April this year by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I am the chairman of the task force and it is for that reason that I claim to have been misrepresented. The survey had indicated that only six out of 71 organisations surveyed had received new funding as a result of the drug offensive. To illustrate how I have been misrepresented by the Minister, I shall use an example-one of many that I could have used. The Minister said in his answer that the drugs task force had claimed that We Help Ourselves had received no new funding as a result of the drug offensive. The Minister said that the WHOS group had received $104,000 of new funding under the drug offensive. In 1985-86, WHOS received $125,414. In this financial year, WHOS will receive $104,373. How the Minister can call a reduction from one year to another new funding under the drug offensive is beyond me. There is no way that the amount of $104,000 is new funding. I am left to conclude that that example, along with others I could have given to the House, is an illustration of how the Minister has misled the House. He should be ashamed of himself.
—Order! the honourable member is starting to argue the matter.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 has a number of principal purposes. The main purpose of the legislation is to provide for the winding up of the activities of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia and, when its operations have ceased, to allow for the termination of the Department. There are at least four major provisions in the Bill. The first one is to provide a revised definition of organisations which are eligible to receive seasonal advances from the Rural Credits Department to remove any doubt as to the eligibility of co-operative associations to receive advances as the activities of the Rural Credits Department are phased out. Secondly, there is the provision to restrict the Rural Credits Department from making seasonal advances or discounting Bills after 30 June 1988, or such later date as is determined by the Treasurer, which will enable sufficient time for customers of the Rural Credits Department to exercise final drawing rights under the transitional arrangements for the phasing out of the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The third provision is that as the activities of the Rural Credits Department are wound up, capital and reserves that are surplus to its operational requirements can then be distributed either to the Reserve Bank Reserve Fund or to Consolidated Revenue as determined by the Treasurer following consultations with the Board of the Reserve Bank. Finally, the Bill provides for the repeal of legislation establishing the Department on a date to be fixed by proclamation and which could be expected to follow the cessation of activities of the Rural Credits Department and the distribution of its capital and reserves.

As far as the financial impact of this proposal is concerned, the Bill does provide for the distribution of capital and reserves of the Rural Credits Department which stood at about $140m at 30 June 1986. As I indicated earlier, one of the provisions was for that to be distributed either to the Reserve Bank Reserve Fund or to the Consolidated Revenue as the Treasurer may determine.

I suppose in terms of the types of provisions and arrangements that have existed in Australia to facilitate the provision of finance for marketing authorities in particular and various types of rural co-operative arrangements, the Rural Credits Department, since it was established in 1925, has fulfilled a fairly important function. In more recent years, however, we have seen fairly dramatic transition concerning the structure of financial institutions and the types of facilities and arrangements to which they have given rise. I do not detract from the fact that the previous Government did initiate some changes in the structure of financial institutions in Australia and the role and functions that they fulfilled and embarked, at least in part, on the process of de-regulation in order to make it possible for Australia's financial system to respond more adequately to the types of contemporary demands that were being made on it. It is of interest that it was left to a democratic socialist government in Australia to complete that process. I think it was important that the process should be undertaken.

I am not one of those people who subscribe to the belief that deregulation is necessarily good in itself. I do not believe that for one moment. But I am prepared to agree with the fact that once we have had an accumulated series of regulatory debris of the kind we had in Australia, which seriously impedes the efficiency with which institutions are able to fulfil the special responsibilities which they have, advantage should be taken of any opportunity which makes it possible to haul that debris out of the system. This Government more than any other government has been responsible for doing that to the financial system. If it then becomes necessary for us to identify the particular deficiencies which have resulted from the removal of all of those unnecessary obstacles and unnecessary inhibitions on the free and efficient operation of those institutions, increasingly in the future we will give consideration, as any government should, to the need to address those particular problems and deficiencies as they arise. This is certainly the most recent attempt by the present Government to get rid of some of this debris. The Rural Credits Department has long ceased to fulfil those particular responsibilities with which it was charged.

I do not believe that the National Party of Australia has indicated any significant degree of concern about the gearing down and the phasing out of the Rural Credits Department. I indicated before that it was established in 1925, the chief purpose being to make short term credit available for the orderly marketing of primary produce. It was continued in that same form under the provisions of the Reserve Bank Act 1959, when it became a department of the Reserve Bank which was then established to take over the central banking functions of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Over the years the Reserve Bank has made advances through this Department to co-operative associations and marketing boards for the processing and marketing of primary produce. Until relatively recently the Australian Wheat Board, which was by far the Department's biggest customer, borrowed enough money from the Rural Credits Department at a concessional rate of interest to make advance payments to growers. Deliveries of wheat were made before the actual wheat crop was sold. The Wheat Board then took advantage of the credit facilities available through the Rural Credits Department. The Board subsequently repaid the Rural Credits Department when the crop had been sold.

In the Reserve Bank report and financial statements for this year, the balance sheet for the Rural Credits Department indicates that the total reserves, both within the Rural Credits Department Reserve Fund and the reserve for contingencies and general purposes, together with initial capital of in excess of $9m, were roughly $140m. As I indicated, that money will be disbursed either to the Reserve Bank Reserve Fund or to Consolidated Revenue at the discretion of the Commonwealth Treasurer.

It is interesting to see some of the variations from year to year in the advances that have been made by the Rural Credits Department. For example, going back to 1969-70, there was an actual reduction in the level of outstanding advances. This was particularly due to the fact that after the March quarter, when most of the advances were being made following the wheat harvest, there was a reduction in the level of advances of $140m over the year. In 1974-75 there was a reduction of $6m in the level of outstanding advances. In 1976-77 there was an increase in the level of outstanding advances of $378m. Concern expressed in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, and then more recently in the Martin group report on the Review of the Australian Financial System which reported to the Hawke Government on the recommendations of the Campbell Report, about the way in which the Rural Credits Department was operating was such as to exaggerate the types of liquidity variations which took place within 12 months. For that reason, among others, the Campbell report recommended that the Rural Credits Department should be phased out. The recommendation was adopted and taken up by the Martin group report and it made a similar recommendation.

The advances that were made by the Rural Credits Department were primarily secured by a charge over the commodity and related book debts and some advances were secured as well by Commonwealth or State Government guarantees. In June 1980 most of those interest changes on advances from the Rural Credits Department ranged from about 9 1/2 per cent through to 10 per cent per annum. I indicated earlier that the advances were made available particularly to those marketing authorities and various types of rural co-operatives on a concessional basis. At that time the level of the concession on interest was only about one per cent; nevertheless, the concession was built into it. I think at that time the interest rate for small advances through the banking system-those of less than $100,000-was about 10 1/2 per cent, which was about 0.5 per cent above the maximum that was being charged by the Rural Credits Department. For advances over $100,000-that is, the larger advances-through the banking system, the interest rate in June 1980 ranged from about 12 1/4 per cent to about 12 1/2 per cent. So a fairly significant inbuilt concessionary interest rate was available to those authorities and co-operatives which were able to take advantage of it.

I indicated that the Campbell report itself suggested that the liquidity base of the Australian financial system was subject to substantial within-year swings, principally as a consequence of the uneven flow of income tax receipts but also reflecting other factors such as the seasonal concentration of rural sector output and associated financial arrangements. A number of proposals were put forward in order to take out those seasonal swings in liquidity and to improve the general across the year financial and monetary credit arrangements in Australia. The third of the recommendations made by the Campbell Committee argued that, as a result of the advances made by the Rural Credits Department having the effect of accentuating those seasonal variations in liquidity, the problem might be eased if all or part of the seasonal financing needs were satisfied by commercial lenders. Of course, the fact that the Reserve Bank itself-and the Reserve Bank's relationship with the Commonwealth and its instrumentalities-has increasingly assumed a more commercial role and has applied more commercial rates and arrangements in its relationship with the Commonwealth and its agencies has, of course, flowed over as well to the Rural Credits Department. So the provision of short term finance through the Rural Credits Department increasingly assumed the type of commercial characteristics that existed elsewhere in the economy.

The Government, of course, has responded to all of those types of provisions and arrangements and to the concerns that have been expressed by those two most significant inquiries into the financial system. I know that the first, the Campbell Report, was initiated by the previous Government. I notice that the former Treasurer and now Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who was responsible for initiating that report, is in the chamber at present. I appreciate the fact that the honourable member for Bennelong has shown me the courtesy, as he normally does, of coming into the chamber to hear the very significant contribution that I am making.

The authority which took greatest advantage of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank was the Australian Wheat Board. It traditionally was the Rural Credits Department's largest customer. It generally accounted for about three-quarters of the total advances made through the RCD. However, since 1981-82, as a result of Commonwealth requests, the Australian Wheat Board has fully met its seasonal finance requirements from commercial sources. So the largest customer and beneficiary of the operation of the Rural Credits Department ceased to depend upon it.

Of course, it continued to provide a number of services for a number of other boards, such as the Australian Dairy Corporation, the State egg boards, the Australian Egg Board, the Australian Honey Board and the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. All of those advances were guaranteed by the Commonwealth Government. In addition, it continued to lend, without the security of any Commonwealth guarantee, to about 45 other marketing authorities and rural co-operatives covering about 20 different commodities. But, as I have said, the biggest single beneficiary from the initial operation from 1925 of the Rural Credits Department, the Australian Wheat Board, ceased to depend upon the Rural Credits Department. It became apparent to the Government and undoubtedly to the Opposition as well that the Rural Credits Department had outlived its usefulness and was no longer fulfilling any satisfactory or necessary purpose. The nature of the concessional arrangements that had been made available and ceased to be contemporarily valuable and it was seen that the Department could well be phased out. Of course, the Reserve Bank has recently been in the process of phasing it out.

The interest subsidy that was given to the Australian Wheat Board when it finally moved from the Rural Credits Department financing to the private sector financing which, as I indicated, took place in the 1981-82 financial year, amounted to about $70m, which was then spread over about four years. This gives some idea of the extent of that inbuilt subsidy as far as the concessional interest rates were concerned. No really serious claim has been made either by rural interests or by operators within the financial system that there was any need for that type of arrangement to continue.

I think that this measure is important in connection with the general position which has been adopted by this Government in respect of its overall economic policy. I have no doubt that members of the Opposition, just as members of the Government and particularly members of the National Party, would have taken advantage of the opportunity to study very closely, as they should have, the economic and rural policy of the Hawke Government which was issued in April 1986. I am sure that the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), who has come into the chamber to hear and participate in this discussion, has read this statement very closely. It is an extremely important statement in respect of all of those areas of rural policy, particularly for those people in rural areas who are pursuing legitimate rural interests, those people who participate in the great rural industries of Australia which have been given so much consideration, attention and sympathetic understanding by the Hawke Government. Those people who have taken advantage of the opportunity to study the economic and rural policy of this Government that was published and made available in April 1986 will know the extent to which that rural policy is dependent upon and related to the general economic approach of the Government. Page 8 of that statement provides:

The Government's overall approach to economic policy is firmly established. It is based on a realistic appreciation of the facts, careful analysis of the options and the negotiation and implementation of sound programs. Our aim--
that is, the aim of the Hawke Labor Government--
is to continue to implement policies that will lead to a demonstrable improvement in national economic performance and social welfare, including that of the rural sector.

In terms of necessary deregulation of the financial system, the achievements of the Hawke Government have been nothing short of spectacular. From the floating of the Australian dollar and the removal of exchange controls in December 1983-at the end of the first calendar year of the Hawke Government-right through to the most recent measure, the abolition of the controls on savings bank interests on new housing loans from March 1986, and this present measure, the Government has shown that it will not adopt a doctrinaire attitude to questions of this kind. It has shown that it will be flexible, it will be pragmatic as is required and it will respond, as it is required to do and as it should do, to the aspirations of the Australian people and the particular problems of the Australian economy as those problems are identified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In more ways than one, perhaps, tonight is a sad night for the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 embodies a move to abolish the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank. I want to take this opportunity at the outset to draw the attention of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) to the fact that in his comments he was really having two bob each way on the question of deregulation. There he was, making perhaps not an unreasonable contribution to this debate, when suddenly the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), by way of interjection, drew to his attention the possibility that he should extend that argument of deregulation to the trade union movement of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that is where the honourable member for Charlton went off the rails. For the rest of his contribution he was skating on fairly thin ice. When he started to pick up that flawed document, the Government's rural economic statement of earlier this year, he was skating on very thin ice because that flawed rural economic statement did very little for the primary producers of this nation. It ignored fundamental sections of macroeconomic policy as they apply to the rural sector. Whilst it tried to address one or two specific areas at the time it was delivered by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), the outcome of that statement is that six months later many more primary producers are having great difficulties in this nation, and not all of those are due to international reasons. Some of those difficulties are due fairly and squarely to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government of this nation.

We know that what is really happening here tonight is that the honourable member for Charlton, in giving a 20-minute rendition on the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill, is strutting his stuff to move into the chair of the Treasurer. If he could do that while the Treasurer is in London, all the better. That is where he wants to end up. But I can tell the House that where he will end up is as shadow Treasurer straight after the next election. He will make a very good shadow Treasurer. I commend him for that role. He has learned in the university of hard knocks in Macquarie Street. There is no better school of education in politics in Australia than the bear pit in Macquarie Street where both the honourable member for Charlton and I served for many years. I wish him well in his career to become Australia's next shadow Treasurer. I am sure he will be a very good shadow Treasurer after the next election.

I want to tell the House in all honesty that I believe that, had the honourable member for Charlton been Treasurer over the last 12 months, he would have handled the fringe benefits tax issue in a far more rational and pragmatic way. He would have eased the Government through the pains of the administration associated with the fringe benefits tax legislation, which is causing such acute trouble across Australia, particularly rural Australia. I wish the honourable member for Charlton well. I acknowledge that his contribution was not unreasonable, particularly on one aspect. He referred to the work of the honourable member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in the setting up and conduct of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. In that report lies the genesis for what is before the House tonight in the abolition of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

As these proceedings are being broadcast, I point out by way of explanation that, if it is thought by those listening that this measure will in some way reduce direct lending to individual primary producers, or for that matter reduce the general availability of loan finance to various marketing boards, as the name Rural Credits Department may suggest, that is not the case. The reality is that the role of the Rural Credits Department has contracted sharply over recent years. I will give some figures on outstanding lendings at various times. In March 1984, the figure was $419m; in July 1985, $233m; and in August 1986 it had dropped down to $18m. Many organisations, including the Australian Wheat Board, have long since ceased to use the facilities provided by the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank. The few organisations that are still using it are to be given sufficient time for the transition. They have had sufficient warning. Other speakers will refer to the number of bodies that do still use the Rural Credits Department. In that regard, in speaking about this measure, the Opposition is not unmindful of the streamlining that this will bring to the Reserve Bank and perhaps the correction that it will make to allow the Reserve Bank to fulfil its traditional, proper and fundamental role as a central bank in the developed nation of Australia.

I accept the rationale behind this move but, in so doing, I want to highlight two other areas. Firstly, I refer to the need for loan finance at reasonable interest rates to be made available throughout the whole of the economy, quite apart from the rural sector of the economy. This Government cannot have it both ways in terms of interest rates and loan finance being available. Because this measure abolishes the Rural Credits Department it is appropriate that I sound the note that we know full well that the Reserve Bank is being utilised to take an active and aggressive role to prop up the Australian dollar. That is effectively being brought about by an artificially high interest rate being maintained in the Australian economy through the various mechanisms available to the central bank to ensure that this artificial increase is built into the standard interest rate component to attract funds from overseas. In turn this add-on of interest rate levels is hurting deeply particular sectors of the economy. In particular, it is hurting the rural sector.

The coalition's approach has always been to say that, if one is to deregulate, one must deregulate properly. One does not have a dirty float of the Australian dollar; one has a clean float. A clean float of the Australian dollar would have given a lower interest rate at this time and at various stages in the last 12 months, including December last year when we were given figures from the Westpac Banking Corporation and elsewhere that the artificial component of the current interest rate levels was as high as eight and nine percentage points-a massive cost burden on so many primary producers battling to survive through very difficult seasonal conditions, and a massive cost burden on so many small business operators right across the economy. We know who to blame for that. It rests with the Treasurer and with the Government's macroeconomic policies. Let there be no equivocation about that.

The second aspect I raise in this Bill is a specific one. The Bill abolishes totally a department of a government instrumentality, our central bank. It abolishes the Rural Credits Department. One would think in such legislation that there would be some reference to what might be happening, or has happened in recent years since business started to contract, to the staff of the Rural Credits Department. After all, the Government claims to represent in this chamber the workers of Australia. It prides itself on its links with the white collar and blue collar workers. But nowhere in the second reading speech on the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill is there any reference to what might have happened in recent years to the staff of the Rural Credits Department or to the few full time staff who may still be left. It is reasonable to assume that they have been transferred to other sections of the Reserve Bank, or that in some cases through natural attrition they have retired, so that nobody has had a job terminated and no contraction in the number of people employed by the Reserve Bank has come about through the abolition of the Rural Credits Department.

If that is so one may well ask how much featherbedding is going on in the middle echelons of the Reserve Bank. I challenge the Government and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), who is at the table, to give the House, in his response, chapter and verse the detail to which it is entitled about what happened to the staff of the Rural Credits Department. The Government cannot have it both ways. If the staff has been transferred or if natural attrition has been utilised, that suggests a degree of featherbedding if we cannot be told that a number of positions will be abolished because of the abolition of the Rural Credits Department. On the other hand, if a number of positions have been abolished, we should be told how many and whether the Reserve Bank is contracting because of the cessation of the activities of the Rural Credits Department.

I sound a warning note on the size of government and government instrumentalities. In the 15 years from 1970 to 1985 the Federal Public Service grew by 31 per cent, the six State government public services grew by an average of no less than 71 per cent and the number of staff working for government grew by 47 per cent. This country is living beyond its means. Those growth rates far outstripped population growth and growth of gross domestic product.

Tonight the Parliament is abolishing the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank. How many positions is it abolishing in the Reserve Bank? I suggest that in reality it is not abolishing any positions. I challenge the Minister for Housing and Construction to state clearly and categorically whether there is a reduction in the number of positions and, if not, why not. Where will the extra featherbedding occur in the Reserve Bank following the abolition of the Rural Credits Department?

The profits from the Rural Credits Department were applied to research, and indeed the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) moved an amendment expressing concern that the Government has not made alternative arrangements to replace the funds normally generated for research from the activities, now to be phased out, of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank. I strongly support that amendment, and would point out that in these difficult times for rural industry we must have more research into salinity, diversity and productivity if our rural sector is to survive the massive pressures it is now undergoing. I again invite the Minister to explain this aspect of the Bill and to ensure that Consolidated Revenue does not gain at the expense of research-vital research in the rural sector. Research is underfunded and there have been cutbacks in recent years when such research is vital to the future of the rural economy.

Finally, in considering the abolition of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank, I pay tribute to the work it has carried out over the years, particularly in the pool financing of the Australian Wheat Board and other marketing boards and authorities. It has fulfilled a vital role. Some people believe that, because not quite so much concern has been expressed in recent months by the rural sector, somehow the rural economic crisis is perhaps not so great as it has been made out to be. I assure the House that the rural economic crisis is every bit as great as it has been made out to be, but it varies from industry to industry. A number of industries I could name face a crisis. Hundreds of primary producers are facing bankruptcy. One cannot blame international terms of trade and other international factors for all the pressures that are being brought to bear on primary producers. It is the Government which is adding to those pressures with its macroeconomic policy on interest rates and its taxes and charges across the board, particularly as they affect the price of fuel. Let us remember that there is no rebate on petrol and many primary producers do not use diesel alone, but use petrol. They are at a sharp disadvantage when using petrol on-farm off-road compared with the use of diesel on-farm off-road, where a rebate applies.

At this moment, the seasonal conditions in many parts of Australia are almost perfect. The corridor from Melbourne to Albury, to Canberra and to Sydney is probably enjoying one of the best springs for many years. Let that not camouflage the economic problems of so many primary producers. Sadly, because it is a corridor travelled by many public servants, Ministers and members of Parliament, I suspect that a false attitude is gathering momentum in the corridors of Canberra during this magnificent spring over much, but not all, Australia. The fact is that in many sectors even in my electorate of Farrer, in the north of Wentworth, parts of Queensland, parts of Western Australia and other parts of Australia drought conditions still exist. There is concern that it may be thought that, in view of the excellent season in parts of Australia, particularly in the corridor from Melbourne to Albury, Canberra and Sydney, all is well in the rural sector and that the rural economic crisis has departed the scene. Nothing could be further from the truth.

I sound a note of warning that people should look beyond the magnificent picture which unfolds in those areas that are enjoying this spring and realise the sharp reality of the rural economic downturn.They should not forget the contribution made by the Federal Government to that downturn, with all the added charges and taxes, and the Government's failure properly to address macroeconomic policies. Above all, they should appreciate the effect of the fringe benefits tax, with payments falling due, though slightly deferred following the pressure applied by the coalition over the sitting days of this week and in the campaign we have conducted on this tax around the nation. Unless the Government sees the error of its ways the fringe benefits tax will more correctly bear the title the farewell Bob tax. It will bring about a change of government and the elevation of the honourable member for Charlton to shadow Treasurer, and I am sure he will be very good in that position. I support the amendment to the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill. I hope that the Government will provide information on research funding, the arrangements for which are to be altered by this Bill. At the same time, I hope that it will give information on the new staffing arrangements and the possible contraction of staff or otherwise following the abolition of the Rural Credits Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend honourable members who have spoken in the debate on the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill. It is good to be involved in a civilised debate. I was a little concerned when the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) implied that the Australian Government was responsible for the drought in their electorates. They want to spread the blame wide and far. I know that Mr Menzies got away with it, but we will not let the Opposition get away with blaming the Government for droughts.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) addressed themselves to the question of the winding up of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia. The important thing for those who are listening to this debate to observe is that that Department operated within the context of the Reserve Bank to provide funding by way of seasonal advances to rural industry. The terms and conditions of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System indicated that we should be moving towards a more deregulated financial system. This Government has implemented that suggestion. It is interesting to observe that the coalition Government thought about that idea but did not move upon it. It was left to this Government to implement deregulation of the financial system.

The honourable member for Farrer mentioned the value of the Australian dollar and interest rates. It is important to bear in mind that there have been difficulties with the value of the Australian dollar and that they are largely attributable to the decline in commodity prices. I have selected some commodity prices to illustrate the point. For example, let us consider iron ore. Between 1982 and June 1986 iron ore prices fell from $US21.90 a tonne to $US16.10 a tonne. That is a fall of 26 per cent. Between December 1981 and August 1986 the price of lead on the London Metals Exchange fell by 39.3 per cent. Between January 1984 and August 1986 the London Metals Exchange price for zinc fell by 15 per cent. A most prominent example is sugar. Between 1978 and 1981 and 1985-86 the price for Australian sugar fell from $US390 a tonne to $US126 a tonne-down some 68 per cent. That is a very marked deterioration in those commodity prices and it is reflected in our balance of payments. I am sure that people in the Australian community understand that very well. Those falls in commodity prices have tended to underpin the difficulties we have had on our external account. However, I am not without hope, because there are clear signs at present that there is an improvement in the Australian financial markets and much of that is due to the acceptance of the Budget.

I wish to raise an issue that is of great concern to people in the Australian community and certainly to honourable members on this side of the House. It is also of concern to people in my electorate of Stirling in Western Australia, particularly those who seek housing. There has been continuing pressure by the savings banks to get this Government to lift the 13.5 per cent ceiling on existing housing loans. In April this year we lifted the ceiling on new loans, but this Government stands committed to retaining the ceiling for existing loans. It is a source of considerable annoyance to me and many Government members that the savings banks and, more recently, the Housing Industry Association have persisted with this campaign of pressuring the Government to lift that ceiling. From my point of view, that is non-negotiable. That 13.5 per cent ceiling is designed to ensure that Australians have access to reasonable housing finance and that we retain stability in the housing industry. That industry is a very big employer and there is a considerable multiplier effect. When one looks at the net operating profit of the banking sector, one realises there is little wonder why people in the community and in this Parliament get very annoyed at the banks when they put on this performance. Taking the year to September 1983 and comparing it with the year to September 1985, we find that the net operating profit of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd increased by 62 per cent from $179.9m to $320.2m. For the same period Westpac Banking Corporation recorded a 53 per cent increase in profits from $241.1m in 1983 to $368.1m in 1985. The National Australia Bank Ltd made a profit of $171.2m in 1983 and $332.1m in 1985-a 94 per cent increase. The Commonwealth Bank of Australia had a net operating profit of $152.8m in 1983 and $237m in 1985-a 55 per cent increase. Let me repeat those figures across the board: ANZ, a 62 per cent increase in profit; Westpac, a 53 per cent increase; the National Australia Bank, a 94 per cent increase; the Commonwealth Bank, a 55 per cent increase.

These are the same banks that are pressuring this Government to lift the ceiling on existing bank housing finance. In the face of those figures how could we look at such a proposition? This Government has some conscience about its operations and it recognises that it has a role in delivering housing to people. Yet the banking groups are pressuring Government to lift the 13.5 per cent ceiling. From the point of view of many of us on this side of the House-and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has recently reiterated his commitment to that position-this ceiling of 13.5 per cent is not negotiable. We do not regard the lifting of the ceiling as being an option. The banks must look at the picture they are portraying in the wider community. That picture is that the banks are looking for substantial increases in profits. We on this side of the House are not unhappy that the banking sector is making profits, but we do not believe that it can turn around and tell the Government that it should lift the ceiling on bank housing finance simply to increase its profitability further. That is not on. How would we stand in the eyes of our constituents? How would we stand in terms of recognising our responsibility to people's housing obligations? How would we stand in terms of providing stability for all those carpenters, bricklayers, tilers and others in the building industry, as well as the people who sell houses and who work in institutions connected with housing? I wish to make it very clear that from our point of view we do not regard raising the ceiling as an option at this time.

Let us look at the current interest rates for 90-day bills. These rates are falling substantially on the Australian financial market and they are now below 17 per cent. The Mitsubishi Bank Australia Ltd will drop its prime rate from 19 per cent to 18.25 per cent, effective from 13 October. This will be the lowest rate offered by any of the trading banks. The Australian Bank Limited will also move its prime rate from 19.25 per cent to 19 per cent, effective from tomorrow. If we look further into the financial market, we see the Australian merchant bankers bill rates. The quotation for the 90-day bill rate on 1 October was 18.41 per cent and on 8 October it was 17.75 per cent. The 120-day bill was quoted at 18.33 per cent on 1 October and at 17.63 per cent on 8 October. The 180-day bill was 18.07 per cent on 1 October and 17.27 per cent on 8 October. We are seeing a downward trend in interest rates. The Budget strategy of reducing pressure on the money markets by going for zero outlays is beginning to reflect already in the Australian finance market, coupled with the encouragement that must be seen in the increase in the value of the Australian dollar and a general stabilisation and improvement in commodity prices.

I support my argument by looking at the authorised dealers' bank bill rates. The quotation on a 30-day bill was 17.80 per cent on 1 October and this has fallen to 17.25 per cent on 8 October. For the 90-day bill the quotation was 17.75 per cent for 1 October and 17 per cent for 8 October. The quotation for the 180-day bill was 17.35 per cent on 1 October and 16.5 per cent on 8 October. Those clear financial indicators in the market show that the trend is downwards. Let us also look at the flow of funds into that sector, the savings ratio in the banking sector, where there is a very adequate supply of finance. The annual rate of savings for 1985-86 is 14.6 per cent compared with 15 per cent in 1984-85, 15.1 per cent in 1983-84, 13.3 per cent in 1982-83 and 14.4 per cent in 1981-82. One sees from the savings ratio that there is an adequate supply of funds in the banking sector. Let me deal with the whole picture. There is an adequate supply of funds in the banking sector and a downward trend in financial rates. I have quoted those rates as of today and they show very clearly that the trend is down. When we look at these factors and then turn to the question of the net operation profit of the banking sector, we come to a very clear conclusion: It is not on to deregulate the existing bank finance rates for housing. That sharp contrast must be drawn between those of us who do not support deregulation of the housing finance market and the Opposition which does support it. We could not countenance that degree of uncertainty and threat to the average Australian home buyer. We regard the ceiling as non-negotiable.

We recognise that the Opposition does not have a finance policy or a monetary policy. Even in that context Opposition members have not committed themselves recently to deregulation of the housing interest market. We would not countenance such a deregulation because we believe that the matter is far too important for the one million people out there who have housing finance. We believe that we have a responsibility to try to protect them, and we will do so. The clear message from this debate tonight must be that we on this side of the House do not regard the housing finance ceiling as negotiable, given the high level of banking profitability that I quoted earlier. In conclusion let me return to those figures. The ANZ Banking Group made an increase in its net operating profit of 62 per cent, Westpac 53 per cent, the National Australia Bank 94 per cent, and the Commonwealth Bank 55 per cent. When those figures are juxtaposed with the reasonable savings ratio of 14.6 per cent for 1985-86 and are put in the context of the fact that there has been a substantial amount of money lent for housing, they show the overall picture. We regard as very important, a benchmark in our approach to housing and the social structure, our wish to provide security for Australian home buyers who have existing loans.

In closing my remarks in this debate I want to make it very clear to those listening to and those who have participated in this debate that the 13.5 per cent ceiling will remain in place. We regard the overall context of the Government's fiscal, monetary and exchange rate policies as delivering the goods. The Australian dollar is improving in value, we are getting the J-curve effect into place, commodity prices are improving and the interest rates I quoted today on 90-day bills are below 17 per cent. There is a clear indication of a downward trend in interest rates. It is pleasing to be on this side of the House and be able to talk about these matters. I can assure the Australian community that we have a great deal of confidence and we can give people an assurance about our intentions on housing interest rates on existing loans.
