TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes that are allotted to me I should like to say something about the Department of the Special Minister of State, and particularly about the National Crime Authority. One of the great things about Australia is that we have organised our affairs so that the opportunity for political misuse of the coercive powers of the police are limited or non-existent. We have striven to avoid the sorts of things that we find in police States, and we have the National Crime Authority. The Authority has been supported by the Opposition, but we have been critical of the absence of certain powers in the Authority and equally we have been critical of the potential for political misuse that exists in the Authority. This is not merely my own view or that of the Opposition. I shall cite the remarks of Mr Moffitt QC, formerly Mr Justice Moffitt of the Court of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, who in 1973 and 1974 conducted an inquiry into the infiltration into Australia of overseas crime. He was deeply critical of the way in which the National Crime Authority Act is structured. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: An inquiry sought by a Government of one political party could involve persons inside or outside the State who are members or associates of an opposing political party, whether in opposition there or in government elsewhere. It could reveal and report matters damaging to the interests of an opposing party in government in another State.

Some of those around this House would say: `Really, is it possible that that kind of thing could happen in this country of ours?'. Let me remind the Committee of how the National Crime Authority works. A reference can be instituted by the Commonwealth Government, and the person who institutes a reference on behalf of the Commonwealth Government is the Special Minister of State now, alas, absent from the Chamber and no doubt enjoying his fiftieth birthday. If a reference is issued, which gives to the National Crime Authority its special functions, the Authority has coercive powers because it is a special investigation. For the purposes of the Commonwealth instituting a reference, it need only consult the States. I remind the Committee that when it comes to a vote on a reference, there is a majority in the States and in the Commonwealth which is controlled by the Labor Party. Questions as to a reference are decided by a majority. However, if the reference is against the interests of a State or against those of the Commonwealth, the State or the Commonwealth that is the subject of the proposed reference may blackball it.

There are currently seven references only before the National Crime Authority. Six have come from the Commonwealth as sole references and one is a joint Commonwealth-State reference. What does that mean? Does it mean that we have any concern here about the misuse of coercive powers or any concern about the possibility of political influence on the conduct of the National Crime Authority? Well, one would think not until yesterday. Yesterday, the Special Minister of State, who I regret is absent from the Chamber, answered a Dorothy Dix question, which we know is a question which is addressed to a Minister by a member of his own Party at the invitation of the Minister, with full knowledge of the terms of the question so that the Minister can give a considered and political reply. The question was asked by the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan), and it was as follows:

Can the Special Minister of State inform the House whether allegations in connection with the recent extraordinarily high defamation settlement between QTQ9 and the Queensland Premier have been raised with him for investigation by the National Crime Authority?
Let me pause on those words:
. . . raised with him for investigation by the National Crime Authority?

As I have said, that Authority is one for which the Minister is responsible. What did he say? One would think that a defamation settlement has nothing to do with the National Crime Authority. He said:

I thank the honourable member for Makin for his question, which I suppose is appropriate while we are on the topic of fringe benefits. I am aware of some speculation about the unusual aspects of the settlement referred to by the honourable member for Makin, but at this time--
I emphasise the words `at this time'--
no matters have been raised with me which would involve consideration by the National Crime Authority.

What are the implications of that answer? The first is that he had considered the reference to the National Crime Authority. The reference against whom? It was against a formidable opponent of the Labor Government, with an election in the offing. Today, the Minister, in his frank, casual, slap-dash and dangerous manner, said that we will hear more about the matter. Today we heard a little more about the elections in Queensland. He offered some gratuitous advice to anybody who might be minded to bring defamation actions in Queensland as a consequence of an electoral advertisement. I do not know what was in the advertisement. I am not concerned with it. But it was no casual statement made by the Minister yesterday. It was a deliberate course of conduct. He was saying that he considered the reference to the National Crime Authority. He was saying that there might be something in it because he said:
. . . at this time no matters have been raised with me which would involve consideration by the National Crime Authority.

He was saying that of the Premier of one of the States of this country with whom the Labor Party is locked in a political battle. He was saying it for the deliberate purpose of besmirching the reputation of the Premier. No other interpretation can be placed on his remarks. He was saying quietly, not overtly, that there might be something in it. He was not shutting the door to an investigation by the National Crime Authority. Could anything be more damaging, more deeply contemptuous of the process of law enforcement in this country? There is only one thing that the Minister can do, although we know that he will not. He could withdraw. He could say that what he did was a misuse of Parliament; that he falsely suggested, in the clever way in which he did, that possibly at some time in the future there may be a case for examining the Queensland Premier by the National Crime Authority. This was a gross, dangerous and wrong abuse of his position. He should come into the chamber and explain exactly what he meant by that answer.

The prospects are that we will get nothing apart from a trivial joke and avoidance of the issue. Many serious issues have been avoided by that man before now. We will see a few more serious issues avoided in the future. Could there be a more serious issue before this chamber than the covert suggestion by the Minister responsible for the administration of the National Crime Authority that at some time in the future he would keep in consideration the prospect of looking at the Queensland Premier through the glass provided to him by the National Crime Authority?

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has elapsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we have an opportunity to examine the appropriations department by department. I shall look at the expenditure set forth for the Department of the Special Minister of State. In response to the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), there are very strong reports about that the present Premier of Queensland will become a member of this chamber. He has said that it is his ambition to enter this Parliament. If that gentlemen does enter this Parliament, he will have to declare all his assets, as every member of this chamber has, and we will all know what settlement he received and what money he has allegedly invested in a company earning very high interest on the short term money market.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that it would be of some benefit to get on to the Estimates, because the Committee is dealing with them department by department. In turning to some of the minor items in the Budget under the vote of the Department of the Special Minister of State, I mention the allocation for national symbols. It is only a small amount-$259,000-but it is an important allocation for members and senators. It is particularly important for honourable members who arrange for local schools, churches, clubs, and charities in their electorates to obtain Australian flags, portraits of the Queen, tapes of the national anthem-Advance Australia Fair-and so on, free of charge. That excellent scheme is much appreciated. Local schools, guide groups, scouting groups and clubs appreciate being able to obtain an Australian flag. It was proposed that a limit be applied to the number of flags available to members of parliament. Fortunately, the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) decided not to press on with such a restriction.

I have said in this chamber before that I believe that free copies of the Australian Constitution should be included among the national symbols. I have always contended that when people assume Australian citizenship-whether they are British, Italian, Vietnamese, Greek or Lebanese-they should obtain free of charge a copy of the Australian Constitution. That is the basic legal document on which our society rests. It sets forth one's right to trial by jury and one's right, if aggrieved, to appeal at law against any Commonwealth decision. It is a basic document that should be given to all people who become Australian citizens. I commend this small extension in expenditure to the Minister to be considered in the next Budget.

Other important items that are funded from the Minister's allocation are the joint Commonwealth-State Task Force on Drugs and the political exchange program. The political exchange program is very important to our near neighbours in the Pacific and Asia. Many of the Pacific countries are small and their economies will not allow young political leaders or people who have entered Parliament or public life to visit Australia to appreciate some of the advantages of taking part in a political exchange program. An amount of nearly $1m has been allocated for the Standing Advisory Committee on Commonwealth-State Co-operation for Protection against Violence. That is essentially $1m for its operating expenses.

The problem I raise tonight was drawn to my attention by a constituent whose daughter was attacked while operating one of the after hours money dispensing machines at a credit union office in my electorate. Officially, the machines are called automatic teller machines. The young lady was attacked while operating a machine at 8 o'clock one evening. Admittedly, the attack occurred in the winter time but she was very lucky to escape with her life. She had no money on her, and the money had not come out of the machine. I have put it to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the banks which set up such machines cannot ignore their responsibilities. They should be allowed to establish automatic teller machines only in areas where a person operating them can do so with reasonable security. I draw this problem to the attention of the Special Minister of State as he has responsibility for the Australian Federal Police and the Standing Advisory Committee on Commonwealth-State Co-operation for Protection against Violence.

At my instigation, this matter has been brought before a committee. The Treasurer pointed out to me that it is called the Electronic Funds Transfer Working Group. It has looked into this matter but has washed its hands of the whole problem and has said that it is up to the customer. If the customer goes to an after hours automatic teller, he has got to watch out. That is not good enough. The banks make very big profits and they must be responsible for an 18-year-old girl who, in all good faith and innocence, goes to withdraw some money for the weekend and is attacked and robbed. I trust that the Minister will bring the matter I have raised before the Standing Advisory Committee on Commonwealth-State Co-operation for Protection against Violence.

Other grants in aid paid through the Department of the Special Minister of State are to the Royal Humane Society of Australasia, the Australian Institute of Political Science and the Australian Institute of Public Administration. An amount of $111,300 was budgeted for grants for non-government international conferences held in Australia. The Herbert Vere Evatt Memorial Foundation receives a contribution of $250,000. The Minister's department also covers the costs of the Remuneration Tribunal. There is an allocation of $136m for the Australian Federal Police, and an allocation of $36m for the Australian Electoral Commission.

Under our predecessors, the Australian Electoral Commission, or the old Electoral Office, was somewhat of a Cinderella of Commonwealth departments. This Government is proud to say that it has revitalised the Australian Electoral Office. It is now being called the Australian Electoral Commission. It has given the officers in that Commission a real sense of purpose and career. Their working conditions have been upgraded in many cases-certainly in the electorate of Lowe, and I am sure, elsewhere. The Commission has responsibilities for conducting industrial ballots and many other matters which come before it. There is an allocation of nearly $7m for electoral enrolments. This is a very big problem because all members of Parliament go to citizenship ceremonies. They see many people becoming Australian citizens. We all hope that these people fill out the necessary form to become voters in our electorates. It is to the credit of the Australian Electoral Commission that the staff does chase up people and gets them on the electoral role. The system does work. We have a very efficient and very effective electoral system. It has the occasional hiccup, as happened in the last Federal election, particularly in New South Wales, where there was great emphasis in advertising on the Senate vote to the detriment of the votes for the House of Representatives. This resulted in an unusually high informal vote in the House of Representatives elections.

The Special Minister of State has responsibility for royal commissions and inquiries. I note that nearly all of the royal commissions and inquiries are being phased out. The inquiry into the taxation of gold mining receives only a small allocation. Similarly, the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interception and the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia are also being phased out. An amount of only $5,000 has been allocated for the Greek conspiracy case, although in the past year the expenditure was nearly $500,000. That is a very good thing. The National Crime Authority, which is under the Minister's jurisdiction, has been allocated a very big expenditure of over $14m. Last year, there was expenditure of $11.4m. This has arisen from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the great work done by Mr Costigan.

I commend the Minister and draw his attention to the two matters I have raised tonight. I believe that copies of the Australian Constitution should be made available for everyone who becomes an Australian citizen, and copies could even be distributed in Australian schools. Young people come here and are feted, but they have no knowledge of the Australian Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In committee on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) we are discussing cognately two departments, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Special Minister of State. I was fascinated when listening to the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) when he said how good it was that the Australian Electoral Commission had upgraded accommodation in his electorate. I am sure that the Electoral Commission also thinks so. I could not help but think, as I was pondering the subjects that I am going to address this evening, what little joy that is for a lot of other people in the community in view of the sort of knocks they have taken in this Budget. The section to which I am going to particularly address myself is the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the provisions which specifically relate to women who get little joy indeed out of this Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, after the 1985 Budget, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan), caused to have circulated to members a document which outlined the effect of the 1985-86 Budget on women. There were many Press releases which I am sure you remember, Madam Chairwoman, on the subject of how good the Hawke Government was to women and families. This year, there has not been a word on that subject from the Government. There is no document outlining the effect of the Budget on women-or if there is, it has not reached my office. Perhaps I am no longer on the list; I certainly would have taken note of it. So I have had to go through certain documents and try to track the matter down.

In the time available of less than 10 minutes that has been allotted to speak on this Bill, it is not going to be possible for me to cover all the areas that could be covered in different sections of the Budget, but I am going to cover the subject of specific appropriations under the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and also some other areas as they link in with it. We see in the appropriation for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet that the Appropriation for the Office of the Status of Women has been reduced by 12 1/2 per cent. However, we are given a Budget inflation figure of approximately eight per cent-at least that. One is always interested in the reduction of expenditures at a time when a significant inflation rate and general government reductions are anticipated. As I have said, the Office of the Status of Women has undergone a reduction. It is apparently not having its offices refurbished as is the Electoral Commission in the electorate of Lowe.

The Interim Affirmative Action Agency also had its appropriation reduced by 40 per cent on last year. Only a few months ago we passed affirmative action legislation in this Parliament. It is a new program. There was, of course, a pilot program, but as part of a program under an Act, it is a new initiative by the Government. The Opposition supported that. I spoke in support of that initiative in debate in this House. Those two single appropriations, which come under the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, have both suffered significant reductions, which compares rather badly with an increase for the Department of 31.9 per cent. These appropriations are not down because the Department is down. Certain departments have gone down in this Budget in the Government's exercise, but not the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet; it has done rather nicely, with an increase of 31.9 per cent. But the two specific items that relate to women are significantly down. It is no wonder that we do not hear very much from the Government about women in the 1986 Budget.

However, other organisations have had a bit to say about this Budget and how it affects women. They have put out documents. The first I refer to is a document prepared by the Australian Council of Social Security entitled `1986-87 Federal Budget Community Sector Briefing Notes'. Again I emphasise that my time is brief, so I can only, in a sense, skim over the issues that are raised. I do want to quote from this document. The other document that I will be referring to is entitled `Women in the 1986-87 Budget' put out by Women's Electoral Lobby. Neither of them is complimentary to the Government. Quoting from the ACOSS document, under the heading `Women' it is stated:

The Budget will exacerbate existing inequalities and leave Australia unable to pick up the recovery when the present crisis is over. The Budget is particularly damaging to those on the margins, young women trying to enter the workforce, low paid women workers, and those attempting to reduce their dependence on pensions and benefits will be hit by reduced job opportunities, reduced options for training, and reduced incomes for those least able to afford it.
Unfortunately, the disadvantages will extend to children of largely female one parent families. A contractionary budget affects the disadvantaged most, and women are still structurally disadvantaged.

The document says that particular problems include, amongst other things, excluding single parents from the tertiary education assistance scheme if they are on the pension, and delaying the poverty trap reduction program.

It has always been the function of the Office of the Status of Women to advise the Government on the effect of its policies or intended legislation, particularly as they impinge on women and their families. It can be seen that the Office of the Status of Women clearly has not done very well this year when one adds up all the decisions made by the Government that will adversely affect women and particularly disadvantaged women in the community and in those disadvantaged sectors in which women form the great majority. The Office of the Status of Women has been singularly unsuccessful in persuading the Government to accept what I am sure was very good advice on the subject. I would hate to think what its fate will be next year when it gets an even lower appropriation and fewer resources to advise the Government. I also wonder, in view of the treatment of the Office, what will happen with the affirmative action policy and what it is supposed to do for women in the community enhancing their ability to help themselves so that fewer of them will be dependent on the Government. Let me elaborate a little on those points of concern that I have raised. The ACOSS document states:

ACOSS deplores the proposal announced in the budget that pensioners and beneficiaries will no longer be entitled to receive Tertiary Education Allowances. In the proposal, pensioners commencing studies in 1987 will only be eligible for $15 per week allowance. This presumably is supposed to cover extra costs such as child care and transport. Compared to the current arrangements a single pensioner with two children in full-time education will be $23 per week worse off.
This is an excessive disincentive to people wishing to improve their long term employment prospects and places further hardship on already overstressed and ill- supported persons.

I can tell the Government, as I am sure the Office of the Status of Women has until it was blue in the face, that that sort of action is extremely counter-productive for women. We hear a lot these days about how the Government wants to reduce costs in the area of the supporting parent's benefit. Indeed, a document on this was tabled yesterday which will be philosophically interesting to look at in respect of the assumptions it makes about women in our community. I say to the Government here and now, as has been said endless times in the past-I am sure it has been said by the Office of the Status of Women-if obstacles are put in the way of education, training and access to child care for disadvantaged people, we are ensuring that they are locked into social welfare and cannot find a way out of it even though many of them would want to.

There is a delightful statement in Budget Paper No. 1 in relation to how the Government will behave to get down the supporting parent's benefit costs. It is a wonderfully sensitive statement which I hasten to get into the record. I quote:

The Government has decided to improve the administration of supporting parent's benefit and widow's pensions by more regular reporting, to ensure continuing eligibility, and counselling which will assist the recipients to find work and thus reduce outlays. From October 1986 recipients will be required to report to the Department of Social Security on their circumstances each month during their first three months on benefit and quarterly thereafter.

What a wonderful thing to apply to a widow's pension! Within a month of a woman applying for a widow's pension, shortly after widowhood, she has to face up and explain whether her circumstances have changed. She will have to do that monthly for a while and then quarterly thereafter. Such is the insensitivity displayed in this Budget document. I reiterate that I am sure that the Office of the Status of Women would have counselled against this type of activity. I hope in debate on other departments to indicate some other areas where the Government has shown a total insensitivity to the position of women, particularly disadvantaged women-in this case bereaved women-in our society. All I can say is that I wish the Office of the Status of Women well. It will be a lot tougher and leaner at the end of the next twelve months because if it is to operate at all and make any sort of input it will certainly be in a three-legged race within this appropriation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my comments this evening on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 by indicating that I will deliberately concentrate my remarks on the very important role of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) and the positive things that he has done concerning the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority. This is a subject which honourable members opposite have either deliberately or negligently failed to address during this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn initially to the Australian Federal Police. I think that everyone-I do not speak just of people in this chamber, but everyone within this nation-is aware of the tight budgetary considerations involved in the 1986-87 Budget. This Government, while focusing strongly on the need to impose tight financial discipline, remains committed to the maintenance of its law and order programs, something that those opposite for so many years when in control of the Treasury bench preferred to turn their backs on.

In line with the strong public commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the 1984 election campaign, the Government has maintained real-I emphasise the word `real'-overall expenditure for the Australian Federal Police, particularly in 1986-87, while increasing further the actual level of available staff resources. It is interesting to note that this Government, since taking office, has increased Australian Federal Police manpower by some 462 officers, which represents an increase of approximately 18 per cent. A further increase of 100 in the financial year 1986-87 will bring the increase to just over 21 per cent. I pose these questions: Is that not a real commitment? Is that not an attack on crime in Australia at what one might call an international level? We have a clear and responsible commitment by this Government.

The responsibility of the Australian Federal Police, especially at airports, as defined in the national anti-terrorist plan, is to contain an incident until the State police response force arrives. As Australians we are fortunate in that such an incident has not arisen in Australia. Let us hope that such a situation will never arise or at least not for many years. The plan has been agreed to by the Commonwealth and all State governments. I believe that the Australian Federal Police manpower allocated to airports is consistent with both the requirements of the Government's anti-terrorist plan and the present threat assessment by intelligence agencies. The alleged Australian Federal Police Association statement that there is a total lack of protection from terrorist attacks on international airports is exaggerated and arrant nonsense. Australia does not have a domestic terrorist threat of the nature found in the centres of terrorist activity in Europe and in the Middle East.

In line with the Government's commitment to improve the effectiveness and professionalism of the Australian Federal Police, it commissioned a joint management review and a review of Federal Police resources. As a result, a number of organisational and administrative changes have been implemented. I will outline just very briefly some of them. The Government issued to the Australian Federal Police in August 1985 a new charter of objectives and priorities, emphasising the Federal Police development as a federal investigative body. Secondly, routine guarding functions have been removed to other agencies. Thirdly, a five-year deployment plan has been developed to ensure the most efficient use of the resources available. As a consequence, Australian Federal Police resources have been redeployed to effect significant increases in staff resources devoted to the high priority tasks of countering drug trafficking-something that everyone in this country finds appalling-organised crime, large scale fraud against Commonwealth revenue and the provision of criminal intelligence.

The achievements of the Australian Federal Police are cogent; they are clearly before the people of this country. One has only to look at major drug seizures, major fraud investigations, improved domestic and overseas liaison and intelligence gathering capabilities, better co- operation with other Commonwealth agencies, improved terms and conditions of employment for Australian Federal Police members and new accommodation in Canberra for the majority of AFP headquarters staff to see the positive initiatives of this Government. I now turn briefly to the National Crime Authority. It has a full work load and greatly increased resources, especially when compared with the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Government has given the Authority the resources it needs to continue the fight against organised crime and drug offences. In November 1985 25 additional staff members were allocated, and a further 30 this year, bringing the total to 258. In addition, 70 police officers and 14 clerical and other staff are on secondment from the States.

A key factor in the successful functioning of the National Crime Authority has been the Government's commitment to co-operation with the States. All of the States and the Northern Territory have passed underpinning legislation which gives the National Crime Authority powers to investigate State offences. Such co-operation through regular NCA intergovernmental committee meetings has resulted in several States granting references to the NCA. The Authority has had references on seven matters, six of which are in conjunction with one or more States. The National Crime Authority already has a number of runs on the board. At 30 June it had been responsible for laying 156-I repeat 156-charges against 41 people, a large number of which relate to drugs.

The Opposition continues to assert that the NCA lacks sufficient powers. The fact is that the NCA can investigate on its own motion any matter involving organised crime. Only if it wishes to use its special powers does the NCA approach the intergovernmental committee for approval. No such approval has been refused, once again illustrating the high level of Commonwealth-State co-operation that exists. Any change to this approach would result in a withdrawal of State co-operation, which would be a crippling blow to the effectiveness of the NCA. I have had very little time to mention the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. One of the most undereffective areas in Australia at present is that associated with youth. This Government is committed to tackle and has proven its ability to tackle that problem. In the near future, with traineeships and with the Priority One: Young Australia program coming into full flow, I have no doubt that the apportionment, the allocation to the area of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak about the portfolio of the Special Minister of State and in particular about the Australian Federal Police. Having heard the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) speak, I would like to remind him of the raging success that the Government's policy on youth, the Priority One: Young Australia program, has been. What a raging success it has been! It has been one of the great failures of this country in recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak about the Australian Federal Police. As honourable members will know, the number one priority of the Australian Federal Police is the war against drugs. The reason for that is that drugs in our society are slowly but surely eroding the very fabric of our society and indeed, it could be said, actually destroying our society. For an example of how bad the Australian situation could be, one has only to look at the United States of America at the moment. On Capital 7 the other day I happened to watch the television documentary entitled `48 Hours on Crack Street' filmed in the United States. If that documentary does not cause concern in every human being on this earth, I do not know what would. It showed that the situation in America is out of hand and that, if we do not do something here to fight properly the drug problem, what is happening in America and some other countries will happen here. Many people will say: `How could that be possible? Surely the drug problem in Australia is bad enough as it is.' The problem in Australia may be bad but it could certainly be a lot worse than it currently is. That is why it is so important that Australians be prepared to fight the drug war. That is why it is so important that we have a very effective and operational Australian Federal Police force.

Earlier this year in April the Government launched its drug offensive. It was launched by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Since April we have already seen that the drug offensive has been basically proved a fraud. In the House today the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) detailed a number of criticisms of the coalition's task force on drugs. I have made a personal explanation about that. His statement had no credibility because we have been able to prove that it is wrong. When the Prime Minister launched the drug offensive, he said that he would do much to increase and improve law enforcement through the AFP. When he launched the drug offensive he said:

The enforcement measures which are now being set up by the States and Territories include detection capabilities and penalties which are stronger than ever before. And there are other measures being adopted on a national scale.

What has happened to all these new measures? Where are the stronger penalties and laws? I say to honourable members that they have not eventuated. We have seen a great deal of posturing and heard talk of telephone tapping powers being increased. But what has happened? That has been buried in a parliamentary committee. Anyone who knows anything about the Parliament would know that, if one wants to bury something for a long time, if not forever, one gives it to a parliamentary committee to deal with. That is what has happened to the telephone tapping powers. We have heard of the recent initiative from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on access to taxation records. But that is all talk; there is no legislation before the House. No legislation has been put before the House as a result of the Prime Minister's promises to increase law enforcement that he made when launching the drug offensive in April this year. At the moment there is also a redraft of the Crimes Act. That was supposed to be a matter to be treated urgently. It started 12 months ago. But what has happened to it? We have heard nothing about it.

Today I asked a question of the Attorney-General about the Taillon case which involved an international drug trafficker who brought drugs through Australia but was released because our laws contained a giant loophole. That occurred 12 months ago and the Attorney-General promised Australians that an urgent review of our laws would be undertaken, that the matter would be settled once and for all and that such a situation would not happen again. Yet today in the House we heard that, despite the passing of 12 months and despite the fact that the Attorney-General acquired an independent legal opinion that stated that the Director of Public Prosecutions was wrong in that case, no legislation has been brought before the House.
Just how bad the drug situation is in Australia is driven home when one reads the report by the International Narcotics Control Board for 1985 from which I quote a passage:

Traffickers are increasingly attempting to use Australia both as an illicit market and as a trans-shipment point for heroin destined for Europe and the United States. Organised crime is becoming more and more involved in the growing international traffic and in its financing.

That is what the International Narcotics Control Board sees as happening in Australia. Organised crime and drugs are becoming worse in this country. The measures that are being taken by the Government are not enough. In April last year the Government had a drug summit out of which we were promised the enactment of legislation to permit more effective search of persons for concealed drugs. Since then the powers of the Australian Federal Police to search people for drugs have been reduced. Today one of the most popular methods of bringing drugs into Australia is to hide them inside body cavities. In recent times the Australian Federal Police have had their powers to authorise body inspections reduced. Furthermore, it is illegal compulsorily to X-ray persons one suspects have drugs hidden inside them. One of the other popular ways of bringing drugs into the country is to insert them inside condoms and to swallow them. But the police are not allowed to take X-rays and must try to bluff those concerned to have an X-ray. The police need powers of that sort. The Government gave an indication that it would give the police those powers, but they have not been given.

Nothing-absolutely nothing-has happened since the launching of the Drug Offensive. The Australian Federal Police have some serious problems. Recently the first shipment of crack came into Australia. We know what crack is and how dangerous it is. One would have thought that, as this was the first shipment, it should have been leapt upon to try to get the chain before it becomes widespread across Australia. The crack came in through the mail system. The AFP carried out a surveillance operation of the post office to which the mail was sent to try to capture the next link in the chain but, because of budgetary restraints, overtime limits forced the police to restrict surveillance of that post office to between the hours of 6 a.m. and 5 p.m. Unfortunately, the man came and emptied his post office box in the evening and the link in the chain was lost. So the first shipment of crack into Australia disappeared. We do not know to whom it went. Why? Because the budgetary restrictions on the AFP meant that it could not carry out proper surveillance techniques. The overtime funding for the AFP will run out by Christmas of this year with still six months of the financial year to go. What are we to do for surveillance in the six months after the funding runs out?

Another problem is an acute shortage of experienced personnel in the AFP. Officers are spread too thinly throughout the force. There s a shortage of vehicles, particularly surveillance vehicles. There is a ludicrous regulation that such vehicles are not allowed to have flashing lights and sirens. If a police vehicle is in pursuit of a drug trafficker through the streets, it has to stop at traffic lights. If the person who is being chased goes through the lights, the police have no ability, because their vehicle has no flashing light or siren, to go through the lights and break the traffic rules. A change could easily be brought about to give more power to the police. The AFP has been looking at what the Americans are doing. The Americans are now talking of legislation to allow illegally obtained evidence to be considered admissible if obtained in good faith. Such a step would increase the investigative powers of the AFP, and would cost nothing at all.

Another step could be taken to assist the police. Some years ago the police could use a general search warrant, but that has now been taken away. That warrant was given to selected members of the then Narcotics Bureau to enter premises if there were strong grounds to suspect that drugs were on the premises. We must get on with telephone tapping powers and with legislation to give the police access to taxation records. We must have more vehicles to enable the police to operate. We must consider additional powers such as those I have mentioned. We must also make more effort in the surveillance and capture of illegal immigrants. Powers are needed to X-ray people who are suspected of bringing drugs into the country. We have to be able to put more AFP officers into the drug capitals of the world and we must close the Taillon drug loophole that has been so neglected by this Government.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Murray Bridge-Pacific Island Nations-Compulsory Unionism-Mr Frank Moschella-Southern Bluefin Tuna Industry-Foreign Exchange Market-Telecom-Department of Social Security-Australian Archives-Mysoon Shaath-Labour Market Deregulation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often in this House that we have the opportunity to discuss the very fine South Australian town of Murray Bridge, which happens to fall within my electorate. It is one of the finest towns in South Australia, and indeed throughout Australia. It is extremely well managed by its council under the leadership of Ray Helps, the Mayor, and Ken Coventry, the District Manager. That having been said, it must be admitted that Murray Bridge is a town which at the moment is enduring certain local difficulties. Those local difficulties more than anything revolve around the problem of unemployment. That unemployment in turn is caused by the decline in the rural economy and in the small business sector throughout Australia, and also by a fairly rapidly growing population in Murray Bridge for which jobs are not easily available.

SPEECH.PARA: The South Australian Housing Trust has been building new houses in Murray Bridge and moving people there. I have no objection to that course, but it must be pointed out that many of those people on arriving in Murray Bridge find no jobs available in the town. If they are to get work, they have to travel all the way back to Adelaide day by day, and for many of those people that is too expensive a proposition. What the State Government at the very least has learned to do is to relate economic, housing and population development to the capacity of a community to provide jobs.

The people in the Murray Bridge community who are most severely affected by these developments are without doubt the young people. The level of youth unemployment there is extremely high, and where there are major problems in the town they are primarily, but not exclusively, found among young people. That is understandable. The young unemployed have nothing to do, they have nowhere in particular to go, and after a while begin to lose hope and confidence in their ability to progress. No group is more seriously affected by that phenomenon than are the young Aboriginal people in Murray Bridge, who have the added disadvantage of fearing some degree of discrimination against them, be it real or unreal. It is a matter which undermines their self-confidence.

In February 1985 I launched International Youth Year in Murray Bridge and in my speech called on the community of Murray Bridge to get together to set up some form of youth advisory committee to help young people in that town. Although that proposal has been discussed over the last 18 months, so far it has not proved possible to put together a particular package. However, I am encouraged by the activities of a Mr Terry Andrews supported ably by Peter Lewis, the State member for Murray-Mallee, who represents Murray Bridge. They have called a public meeting on 21 October at which the issues of the youth of Murray Bridge will be discussed. Their proposal at the meeting will be to establish a youth resource centre to provide easy information to young people, to help them build their confidence and to help them get jobs, find things to do and get to know each other. One sensible proposal that has been put forward is that such a centre could be community funded and community based. That will have to be examined.

An alternative has been put forward in the Federal Government's so-called Priority One program. Most of us assume that the Priority One program is simply a public relations exercise to win votes for the Government. This example will be a test of the veracity of that program. If the Government is for real about Priority One, perhaps it should nominate Murray Bridge as one of the towns for a CES youth access centre. So far there are only 37 such centres designated in Australia, three of which are in South Australia, all in Labor held areas-Whyalla, Elizabeth and Port Adelaide. I would like to believe that the Government would look seriously at the problems of Murray Bridge and would choose that town as the site for a further CES youth access centre if it is not possible at this stage to put together a community based youth resource centre for the town. In conclusion, Murray Bridge is a very fine town and in the words of the song it is `my kind of town'. I hope that honourable members will take the opportunity to go there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The central and south-west Pacific Ocean is home to a number of small nations. Almost every one of them has laid claim to a large exclusive economic zone. I name just four of these states-Niue, with an area of 259 square kilometres and a population of 2,000 people; Tuvalu, formerly the Ellice Islands, which is 26 square kilometres and has 8,000 people; the Cook Islands, which has 240 square kilometres and 18,000 people; and Kiribati, formerly the Gilbert Islands, which has just 823 square kilometres and a population of 66,000 people. Including its exclusive economic zone, Kiribati is wider than the continent of Australia. It covers 3.5m square kilometres of ocean straddling the Equator and the international date line. Kiribati is indeed poor. Its 66,000 people have an annual per capita income of only $A400 and total government spending is about $A16.2m a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Each of these nations has little paid employment. Most of the people have low cash incomes and in some cases insufficient food and fresh water. They have few schools and hospitals and limited internal travel systems. Each nation has received its independence within the last 10 years. Until recently, Western nations have been disinterested in their development.

In the meantime, the Soviet Union's presence has grown. Its facilities at Cam Ranh Bay are an expression of its military presence. The General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Mr Gorbachev, spelled out the Soviet claim to a major political role in the Pacific in his Vladivostok speech last month. The conclusion of a fishing agreement last year between the Soviet Union and Kiribati served to remind Western strategic planners of the importance of this region to international security. Discussions between Kiribati and the Soviet Union to renew the fishing agreement are now under way. This agreement did not include access to port facilities or aircraft landing rights, but these rights and facilities have been sought and may be granted elsewhere. In Vanuatu, for example, the Government has been negotiating a fishing deal with the Soviets for some months in which these matters have apparently been canvassed. Soviet trade officials recently visited Fiji for trade talks. These commercial openings and opportunities no doubt give the Soviets welcome opportunities to develop political relations in the region. Vanuatu has established diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union in recent months and maintains diplomatic links as well with a number of Soviet satellites, including Cuba and Libya.

Australian aid to the region is about $50m a year and Japanese aid is growing rapidly to about $40m. But these proud people do not want to be beggars or dependants. Even well intentioned aid, given in a paternalistic way, can antagonise them. A former Kiribati Secretary for Natural Resources, Omote Tong, told the Sydney Morning Herald on 1 October 1986 that:
The general impression of Australians is of neo-colonialism.

He contrasted Australian `arrogance' with Japanese `sensitivity' to island customs. What can Australia do? Money alone is not just the answer. We do not want to steal the islanders' culture or take away their self-respect. But we do need to help the small states to help themselves. More small scale aid projects aimed to help their people to develop are needed. More human resource development is required. One example might be a pre-matriculation preparatory year to train students for entrance into tertiary studies and government administration. Assistance could be provided to non-government bodies to develop managerial and commercial skills. Often frustration levels are high in the islands, particularly when bureaucratic procedures for our larger aid projects drag on for years. Recent attempts by Kiribati to show a group of aid donors what it wanted and by Tuvalu to set up a trust fund to provide a continuing revenue source should be encouraged strongly with funding.

The people of these small Pacific nations are generally Christian and certainly pro-Western. They are not pro-communist, or even radical, but they are proud of their heritage. Every effort should be made to show the Pacific island people that Australia's concern is genuine. We must give aid of a relevant nature and help their involvement in democratic institutions so that they themselves can manage their own development with dignity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Democracy is the defender of the great human freedoms-freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, freedom of worship and freedom to think and conduct one's personal affairs according to one's personal moral beliefs. Those freedoms are cherished by all enlightened liberal societies. The fact that such freedoms are available to its citizens distinguishes a democratic society from a totalisation society. Whenever individual citizens are denied the opportunity to exercise their own conscience on matters of personal belief, democracy itself it placed at risk. As citizens of a liberal democracy country, all of us in this place have the onerous responsibility to defend those great freedoms for the benefit of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for that reason that the Liberal Party of Australia strongly opposes compulsory unionism. Compulsion in such matters denies individuals the opportunity to exercise their consciences or free choice. It is pointless claiming that all Australians can exercise their own choice, when the choice is between joining a union or not having a job. We are on the point of totalitarianism when compulsion on such matters of conscience and free choice is demanded by Governments. That is now happening. Specifications laid down by the Victorian Road Construction Authority state:

The project site agreement requires all labour engaged at the work site to be a member of the appropriate union. All drivers delivering materials within the project site limits shall be a member of the appropriate union and shall carry evidence of their membership.

These conditions are laid down by the Victorian Government. Our own apathy has allowed such a fundamental freedom of choice to be denied to millions of Australians. But if we are to sustain a liberal democratic society in Australia, such denials of individuals free choice cannot be tolerated any longer.
The October 1944 conference which formed the Liberal Party laid down a number of principles that would guide the Party, and I quote some of those principles:
A free and Liberal Australian democracy shall be maintained by:
(a) Parliament controlling the executive and the law controlling all.
(b) Freedom of speech, religion and association.
(c) Freedom of citizens to choose their own way of living and of life, subject to the rights of others.
(d) Protecting the people against exploitation.
(e) Looking primarily to the encouragement of individual initiative and enterprise as the dynamic force of reconstruction and progress.

If Australia in 1986 is to lift itself above mediocrity that dynamic force of individual initiative and enterprise must be released and not squashed by a plethora of government and union rules and regulations. Australia has reached a point of near economic and social destitution because individual enterprise has been stifled. Not only has that soul-destroying process retarded our economy, but it has also at the very heart of much of the industrial disruption experienced in the past. Governments and unions must get off the back of the Australian people and allow our citizens to fulfil their full potential. Compassion for our fellow human beings demands nothing less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter that a constituent of mine, Mrs Dries, of Ashcroft, has raised with me. It concerns her husband, Joseph Dries, who suffers from Alzheimers disease. Mr Dries is a patient of the Delany Hall Nursing Home, Jersey Avenue, Mortdale, which is a division of Aspic Holdings Pty Ltd and I believe that that home has not fulfilled its duties to care for Mr Dries. Let me quote to honourable members from two letters that were sent to Mrs Dries on 16 and 19 September. The first one says:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to you in regard to the fee increase you will have noted in this month's account . . . The fee rise will appear more severe than it is in reality as there is a backdate of the increase to include 15 days of the month of September. I would like to take this opportunity to remind you that this is a Governmental increase.
The second letter reads:
I regret to inform you that due to serious cash flow problems, fees for all patients will be paid one month in advance. This will take effect form 1.10.86. I thank you in anticipation . . .

Both of those letters were signed by Mr F. S. Moschella, the administrator of the Delany Hall Nursing Home. This man could not tell the truth if he tried. This ghoul states that he is suffering from a cash flow shortage-what rubbish! It is obviously the only company which does not have a budget plan. Considering that there are 64 patients, each paying around $1,780 per month that is a total of $106,200 per month and $1.2m a year. I would not mind a cash-flow shortage like that.

Mr Moschella claimed that the money had to be paid on 1 October and a backdate of 15 days was to be included, which was a governmental increase. He must be joking! It was not a governmental increase at all. As well as sending those letters, he sent a bill for $1,588.53 which had to be paid by 1 October. Mr Dries's daughter questioned this and spoke to the administrator, Frank Moschella, who said: `Yes, that's right, it includes a bill for $515.30 that was not paid-it was from June last year'. Let me say that this cheat has been caught out. The cheque for $515.30 was drawn by Mrs Dries on 12 June and it was cashed on 19 June. The cheque number was 393268. Mr Moschella, alluding to the matter in a roundabout way, then went on to say that if the bill was not paid Mr Dries would be removed from the nursing home, virtually thrown out into the street. Perhaps this charlatan is the one who should be thrown out into the street and out of the industry.

I made inquiries with an officer of the Department of Community Services. When Frank Moschella's name was mentioned, the officer's response was: `Oh no, what's this dill up to again? Yes, we know him, he is well known to us. He is one of the sleaziest and slyest nursing home operators in the business'. That says a lot for Frank Moschella.

Mr Moschella is a member of the Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals Association of Australia. I hope they know how crooked this ghoul is. Fancy threatening to remove a sick man from a home-a man who barely knows what his name is-for not paying a bill which in fact has been paid! Only last night-this demonstrates the concern of this home in looking after its patients-Mr Dries was reported missing from the hospital and was discovered at 8.30 p.m. wandering the streets of Peakhurst five kilometres away from the home. That is really looking after the patients! Let me tell honour- able members the amount of money that Mr and Mrs Dries have to pay. Mr Dries's fortnightly pension of $234 goes to the home and an extra amount of $120 has to be paid to the home from Mrs Dries's salary, plus the Government subsidy of $42.80 per day, which is a grant total of $1,766.40 per month.

The misinformation campaign waged by this inept, confused idiot has failed miserably. Mr Moschella claims that there will be no increase in nursing home subsidies by the Government. He would be aware, as he is the most cunning operator in the business, that the Government will reassess the subsidy in November. He has harassed and threatened elderly people to get more money out of them to line his own pockets. I am not denying that costs have risen, but I object to the fact that this ratbag has run his operation in such a way. Frank Moschella and the company he represents should be made accountable for their actions. I have not finished pursuing Mr Moschella. I will raise the matter again in the near future. I hope that all people like Frank Moschella involved in the nursing home industry are brought to justice and receive their just desserts. I hope also that the Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals Association of Australia takes notice of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House would be aware that something is wrong with the southern bluefin tuna industry in Australia. A series of tactical blunders and plain irresponsibility on the part of the Department of Primary Industry in various negotiations has seen the catch of southern bluefin tuna diminish from 21,300 tonnes in 1982-83 to a quota of 11,500 tonnes this year. In comparison, the Japanese catch was 24,335 tonnes in 1983, yet Japan has agreed to reduce its take to only 19,500 tonnes this year. It is obvious that Australia is giving everything and Japan very little.

SPEECH.PARA: It is easy for this group of ivory-tower public servants to see the arguments in black and white, but I can assure the House that out in the field the decision to introduce a quota and then to allow transference rights has decimated the infrastructure of the industry and at the same time has built-up the strength of our overseas competitors. In Albany, Hunts Foods Pty Ltd closed down last year, sacking a work force of over 150 people. The decision to restrict tuna catches was the final nail in the coffin of that company. At the same time as the Government contributes to the closure of a cannery, our canned tuna imports continue to rise. Whose side is the Government on? Albany has now lost more than three-quarters of its tuna fleet. In 1982-83 it had a fleet of approximately 72 vessels, and it has now been reduced to 16 vessels. When an industry losses its infrastructure it is not economic to recommence that industry at a moment's notice.

The fishing industry is not represented only by fishermen. The industry comprises mechanical and refrigeration engineers, shipbuilders, processing factories, packaging and sales distribution, and even props-up a bevy of public servants. The fish processing industry falls into the category of adding value to our exports. It is a section of the industry which has a high capital involvement and should not be disregarded in essential decision making, as this Government continues to do.

It is against this background that I want to describe to the House an arrangement between Japan, New Zealand and Australia which the short-sighted public servants in Canberra are thrilled about. Last week Japan, Australia and New Zealand wound up negotiations on access and quotas to prevail in the southern bluefin tuna industry. As the argument goes, Australia has been catching too many immature southern bluefin tuna and this has caused a depletion in stocks. Australia is geographically positioned in the fishing grounds where immature tuna swim and our fishing fleet is geared-up for polling the smaller fish. The Japanese, with their long liners, are geared-up for catching the larger fish.

This year the Japanese industry agreed to pay around $830 per tonne for Australian fishermen not to catch fish. In effect, Australian fishermen will be happy to surrender 3,000 tonnes of their quota for doing nothing. I am glad to say that this option is not being taken up by the Albany tuna boat owners, which will mean that they may still have an industry left in a few years. It is one thing for the Government to pay its producers to stay out of an industry, but it is quite a different matter for another government to pay Australian producers to stay out of our own industry. Why does the Japanese industry not pay us to totally get out of tuna fishing? At special devaluation rates it would cost only about $A12m each year and the Japanese could have the whole world's southern bluefin tuna catch to themselves, and we will import what we need. Why do we not look around for other industries to give away? It is all really too silly for words.

This is not a decision from which the Department of Primary Industry should have stood at arms length. It is a decision that the Government should have a right to determine on behalf of all those involved in the industry, such as the food processors and the various service industries. Many industries will be affected by nobbling the quotas on southern bluefin tuna. In effect, it will mean that canneries will continue to import fish to maintain their operations, as they have done since the introduction of quotas in 1983. The joke is that we now import about 3,000 tonnes of frozen fish to can because domestic supplies are denied by government agreements. Even after we have canned those fish we still import more canned tuna for domestic consumption.

This is a time when the Government must stand up for the rights of the industry. Australia should not be the bunny all the time. I know that there are convincing arguments for restricting the Australian catch; arguments mainly from experts who confound the industry. There is no doubt that we must manage our southern bluefin tuna sources at sustainable levels, but I believe that it is total sovereign irresponsibility to give an inch when our trading partners do not. The Japanese catches are open to question. They are unshackled by Government regulations and while we have halved our catch for their interest, they have reduced their catch by a paltry 10 per cent. This Government has been pathetic in the extreme and I hope that it takes seriously what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has had to say about incompetents in government service losing their jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to express some concern that I have about the evidence that exists concerning the degree of speculation against the Australian dollar generally through the foreign exchange markets. A fairly rough method can be used to determine the extent of the turnover of foreign exchange through the foreign exchange market that is necessary to support legitimate transactions through the balance of payments. I know that this rough method is not necessarily foolproof. I do not know of any particular approach that could be foolproof, because any one transaction involving exports or imports of either goods or services or capital movements generally sets in train a series of exchange transactions, especially to provide cover for some types of risks. Those transactions that are then set in train can range from forward trading hedges to swaps; for example, various types of option arrangements can exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take, for example, the month of June and look at the balance of payments transactions during that month. In order to do that, we need to look at the exports and imports of commodities, services credits, services debits, transfer credits, transfer debits, and then the balance on capital account as well. The total of legitimate transactions through the balance of payments comes to just over $9,000m for that month. During June, there were 20 trading days for the foreign exchange market. If one divides 20 trading days into the total volume of turnover that would have been the minimum necessary in order to support those legitimate transactions through the balance of payments, the amount comes to $456m per day. That is a pretty critical figure, because I am sure it will surprise honourable members to know what the actual volume of foreign exchange transactions on a daily basis was.

I have indicated that the volume necessary to support legitimate transactions through the balance of payments was less than $500m per day. The actual volume of foreign exchange transactions was just under $17,000m per day. When I saw that figure come out I was stunned, as I think everyone should be. That indicates the situation that exists in Australia now. If there were any doubts on the part of any people that there are operators in the foreign exchange markets who, to a very large extent, have speculated against the Australian dollar, I think those figures should disabuse them of those doubts.

As a result of increasing concern being expressed about the possible extent of that speculation, honourable members will be aware of the fact that more recently the value of the Australian dollar is said to have stabilised. Why has it stabilised? One of the main reasons is that the speculators have turned their attention now to gold and silver, and they are speculating against them. We see the changes that are taking place on a daily basis in the prices of gold and silver. A fair amount of equity capital is coming into Australia at present as well, to take advantage of our local financial and share market circumstances. So the speculators are very selective.

The last point that I want to make in connection with that matter is that through world foreign exchange markets we have now reached the point where the daily foreign exchange turnover is $300 billion. In 12 months that has increased from $150 billion per day, a sum which is vastly in excess of the amount that is needed to support legitimate foreign exchange transactions which are necessary to support international trade and international capital movements. There are international financial institutions which have the capacity to mobilise and move vast sums of money in order to speculate through those foreign exchange markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to tell the Parliament of a problem experienced by a citizen and involving the Department of Social Security and Telecom Australia. In April 1985, a constituent left Hervey Bay to live within the Fisher electorate. In moving, he notified Telecom of his new address and applied for a telephone in the area. At the same time, he personally visited the offices of the Department of Social Security in Maryborough to see whether the phone rebate could continue on his new service. He was assured that this would apply automatically and that the rebate would continue in his favour. Unfortunately, this turned out to be far from the truth. In November 1985, following a change in my constituent's economic circumstances, he approached the Department of Social Security to have his pension increased. Imagine his surprise when he was advised that, instead of getting more due to his lower income, he was told that he would lose $22 a fortnight. Understandably, my constituent did not let the matter rest. After approaching his accountant, he was told that, according to the guidelines, the Department of Social Security was short changing him by $22 a fortnight. After telephoning the Department's Nambour office to complain, it was admitted that a mistake had been made and that he would be reimbursed. In due course, $180 was forwarded to him.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be logical to assume that, by this time, the matter had been settled. However, this was not the case. Telecom entered the picture again, this time writing to advise that my constituent was not now entitled to a telephone rebate. Apparently, the error made by the Department of Social Security, which resulted in a pension reduction, now meant that the phone rebate was also cut. Once again, my constituent contacted Telecom to clarify the matter. Telecom revealed a communication breakdown between it and the Department of Social Security. The latter apparently advises when to cut out the pensioner rebate but never notifies the reverse situation. Because of bungling, a citizen not only had his pension reduced instead of increased but also had his phone rebate stopped improperly. Unfortunately, Telecom, through not being advised by the Department of Social Security of its error, withheld the entitlement for nine months.

Telecom and the Department of Social Security must get their act together; they must learn to talk. People's interests cannot be ignored or treated with contempt. As my constituent said to me in a letter:
If you allow anyone to walk over you once, then the second time doesn't seem to hurt as much and the third time you don't even notice.

Telecom and the Department of Social Security need to reappraise their attitude and approach to people urgently. Until they do so, they, as part of the public sector, will continue to be viewed as large, impersonal, inefficient and acting as a law unto themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual reports for 1985-86 of the Australian Archives and the Advisory Council on Australian Archives were tabled in this chamber recently. As honourable members may be aware, I am a member of the Advisory Council. These reports revealed the wide range of interests which the Australian Archives services. Reading the reports, I cannot help but be struck by the scale of the contribution which the Archives makes to efficient government administration. There is a tendency to perceive the function of the Australian Archives as simply to provide access services to members of the public who are wanting to see government records for research purposes of one kind or another. This is a most important function, servicing a steadily growing demand; but there is another important function, namely, that of providing economic, cost-effective services to all other agencies of the Federal Government. It is this to which I want to refer briefly.

SPEECH.PARA: There now exists an enormous volume of government records-not just paper but also computer tapes, maps, microfilms, sound recordings and even objects. This material is not kept for the sake of it; it is essential for administration. It records activities of governments; it helps people establish their rights and entitlements and has considerable educational value. If these records are not economically stored, not destroyed when no longer needed, not easily retrievable, and not available for use when required, cost penalties must follow. By a series of management initiatives, the Archives is seeking to reduce and eventually to avoid these penalties. I read from the Australian Archives' report that the Archives is now managing over 400 kilometres of records in its repositories and bulk stores alone throughout the country, is providing for the orderly disposal of more and more records and handled well over half a million records through its lending service for Commonwealth agencies during 1985-86. I note also that the Archives has been managing the massive and unique undertaking of surveying all Commonwealth Government records in Australia and overseas. The survey data gathered will provide a basis for more effective arrangements for the control, accessibility, retention or destruction, custody, storage and conservation of records as well as assisting the internal management of agencies. The data will be drawn on to help the Archives to plan its bulk storage facilities and services to Government agencies.

In these areas, the Archives is very much in the business of cutting costs. It provides an essential underpinning for the business of Government and its work involves assisting members of the public who have an interest in or need to learn about the activities of governments. I am sure that honourable members will agree that these areas of efficiency and economy are worth commenting on in the current financial climate. As a member of the Advisory Council on Australian Archives, I think it is important to recognise this behind the scenes work of the Australian Archives which is not widely known or strikingly visible outside departments and other agencies of the Commonwealth Government. The term of the members of the Advisory Council has expired and I should like to pay tribute to the members who have served on it. My term has a little time still to run. I pay particular tribute to the staff of the Australian Archives, especially the Director, Mr Brian Cox.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the Australian people need to know why Mysoon Shaath was in Australia recently. Mysoon Shaath is a member of the Palestinian National Council and a member of the General Union of Palestinian Women. I shall quote to the House statements that she made in Melbourne. A article about her visit reads:

SPEECH.PARA: `We refuse to be called terrorists,' she said yesterday at the Palestine Information Office in Melbourne. `We are the most peace-loving people in the world.'
The article continues:

She did not think the Istanbul synagogue and Karachi airport massacres, which have been linked to Arab terrorist groups, necessarily harmed their cause. `I'm saying we are against terrorism, and against the murder of innocent civilians,' she said. `But whenever these incidents happen, they say it's a Palestinian who did it. I say ask yourself why he did it.'

This lady admitted that the acts were carried out by the Palestinian Liberation Organisation. The Palestinian National Council is the so-called Palestinian National Parliament in Exile. It has representatives of guerilla trade unions, trade and student groups and other groups as well as its members. The PNC created the PLO in 1964. As the House knows, Yasser Arafat is the PLO leader. In addressing the Palestinian National Council on 29 November 1984 he offered his resignation to the Speaker of the PNC. The Speaker of the so-called Parliament reported Arafat to the National Council and Arafat described his resignation. The article states:

`It is only you, the representatives of the Palestinian people, who decide whether or not to remove me.' The auditorium of the Royal Cultural Centre, where the PNC is holding its 17th session, then erupted into thunderous applause and chants of: `We have no leader but you. We want you and only you.'
That was the reaction of the PNC. The article continues:

Mr Arafat, 55, was hauled from his third-row seat by men from the Palestinian refugee camps and the Israeli-occupied West Bank. They carried him on their shoulders to the stage amid shouts of: `You stay, you stay.'

I think that there is a clear link established between the PNC and the PLO and the way in which these organisations interrelate. In the Senate Estimates Committee, Senator Peter Baume questioned officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs about the entry of Mysoon Shaath into Australia. A Mr Harris said:
There is no reason to believe that that person required any greater scrutiny than that accorded to the normal visitor.

I think it is time that Australians knew what the security arrangements are for visitors entering Australia. I do not care whether they are members of the PLO, the Irish Republican Army or any other terrorist group. We must have rules that are understood clearly by Australians and applied by officers of the various departments. I do not know who makes the decisions on entry. I do not know whether they are security decisions that are made by internal intelligence, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs or the Department of Foreign Affairs. I have made inquiries of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and I have been told to make a request under freedom of information. I know how long that will take and how little information that process will yield. I shall conclude my speech by quoting to the House remarks made by Mysoon Shaath in an interview with Bill Hartley on 13 September 1986 on radio 3CR. Bill Hartley said:
Mysoon Shaath is on the line now from the PLO information office which itself has been in the news. Good morning Mysoon.
He continued:
I think that you had better tell us about the General Union and its place in the PLO.
The lady replied:
Well it's one of the bases of the PLO and I am a member of the Executive Committee of the General Union of Palestinian Women.

There is a clear link there between the PLO and the General Union of Palestinian Women. I am not accusing this woman of being a terrorist, but she could easily have been a terrorist on an active mission. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs did not appear to know about her entry into Australia and no one seems to care. It is time that the so-called Security Committee of the Cabinet considered these matters. One of its own members has been threatened, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). It is time also that the Australian people know what the Government's security rules are. I call on the Government to establish clear guidelines for security and for the entry of potential terrorists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to make a few points in the couple of minutes that remain this evening on coalition policy which seems to be developing on labour market deregulation. I am concerned about how this policy will affect small country town economies. The proposal seems to be that those who employ fewer than 50 people can opt out of awards and conditions under the present arbitration system.
—You are doing it. You know that you are doing it.

—I point out to the honourable member that the two-tier system does not involve the opting out that is proposed by the Opposition. The proposal will hit employees, particularly in small country towns. One can imagine an employee who is locked into a position, perhaps in a shop, and the less scrupulous employer who perhaps says: `Look, I am sorry, I can only afford to pay you $10 above the dole. You can take it or leave it. I cannot afford to pay you any more'. Think of the position that the employee would feel himself or herself to be in when faced with that sort of challenge by an employer.

SPEECH.PARA: Employers will be hit also by the proposal. Most employers appreciate a fair and minimum wage, as I did when I was in business. Let us hark back to 1907 when Mr Justice Higgins made an historic decision on clothing needs, food needs and minimum frugal comfort. Are we to return to the days of pre-1907? I believe sincerely that employees throughout Australia will recognise that such a policy would be wrong. It is our duty as a Government to make clear the Opposition's policy. If implemented, it would take Australia back to the last century in industrial regulations and rules. Most of all, the proposal would hit local economies. If employers are to reduce the incomes of their employees, the family take-home pay will be reduced substantially. This will mean that local spending will drop. This is a lesson that we have learnt time and time again. Let us not depart from the historic 1907 Higgins decision. Let us reject the proposals of the Liberal Party and the H. R. Nicholls Society to return to such measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., the House stands adjourned until 10 a.m. tomorrow.
